author: {'steamid': '76561197991556719', 'num_games_owned': 681, 'num_reviews': 214, 'playtime_forever': 109, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 109, 'last_played': 1595184188}
review:
Unfortunately, RNG reigns supreme. The premise is interesting, it involves mainly around resource management while you jump from planet to planet and keep your ship in one piece. Along the way you'll run into random encounters that unveil a bit of the storyline or force you to make a decision. The game also punishes (or rewards) you for no reason whatsoever without any of your doing as is common in these games. Very annoying to suddenly take 20 damage. Very pleasant to receive 100% oxygen but really, just artificially spiking up the difficulty without providing a challenge that can be overcome means nothing in the end to the player. It's poor game design.

The game doesn't feature any combat whatsoever which means that although similar to FTL and Derelict, you'll mostly spend your time looking at the same type of planets and clicking the same few buttons over and over without any thing to get really good at. Yes, you'll learn to plan more effectively but that's about it, you can't outperform random encounters any better than the guy that just started unless, of course, you memorize all of them. Not anyone idea's of fun, I reckon.

The art direction is okay, the music and sound is atmospheric and the storyline does seem interesting. You can uncover bits of alien language but unfortunately, these are lost when you die so you'll have to rediscover the language all over again. Some persistence here would have been nice. You can, however, select an option before you start your game that will allow you to board your old ships when you die. Nice touch.

I ended up playing a game where I had traded in my ship for a ship that could jump with very little fuel and oxygen requirement. I ran out of fuel because I couldn't jump far enough to get to the next system and I ended up running low jumping back and forth trying to find a way out Fortunately, I ran into yet an even more powerful ship and boarded that one and continued playing for a bit, jumping from system to system (ones I had already visited) to get back to where I left off just to find out that this ship couldn't make the jump either! 

There simply wasn't a way forward no matter where I went. I went backwards to check and no, couldn't jump there either. I figured that perhaps I could just buy another "space folder" but no, you can't actually upgrade your ship unless you've discovered the technology beforehand during your current game.

This is where I pressed the quit button and the thumbs down. RNG to the point where it can break the game is obviously there to hide the lack of skill in writing a half-decent AI to provide the player with an interesting challenge. Might as well play a slotmachine, at least you'll be able to finish your game each round.

I did not pay full price for this game and neither should you. it is definitely NOT worth the asking price to any degree.

author: {'steamid': '76561198030755187', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 732, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 270, 'last_played': 1597717188}
review:
This game is fun, quick, and hard. Really enjoy playing in the moments where I have 10+ min to blow off (after 4 hours, that's quite a few runs) - still have not reached earth yet... oh well.

BIGGEST COMPLAINT about the game is that its audio is in MONO!!! I get it for mobile games, but common - sound designers and music composers really work in a stereo field, I would think most of us play with headphones or at least speakers - can we please make a stereo version of the audio for this!!!

author: {'steamid': '76561198070580358', 'num_games_owned': 491, 'num_reviews': 84, 'playtime_forever': 93, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 93, 'last_played': 1590275853}
review:
It might be ok for mobile gaming (i dunno i don't play games on my phone) but for PC it's too simple. Gameplay consists of:
- reading tons of boring text written in comic sans font 
- drag and dropping squares with chemical elements designations
- clicking on stars and planets. 
Your progress depends mostly on RNG and you don't really have to put any effort. I have no idea why this thing has positive reviews.

I think steam should warn players with huge red letters on the store page that this a mobile game, i wouldn't buy it if i knew.

author: {'steamid': '76561198074613709', 'num_games_owned': 824, 'num_reviews': 82, 'playtime_forever': 1006, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1006, 'last_played': 1589974282}
review:
I've known this game on mobile for like 8 years and i'm pretty happy about the PC Version. Only problem for me would be the price, get it on a sale !

The game might be super-random at times and it might be hard to get to certain objectives but once you start to understand how the game works it's pretty easy to do everything. Look for guides/wiki on internet, you'll get most of the knowledge you need to make decent runs.

author: {'steamid': '76561198439796494', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 1580, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 432, 'last_played': 1676140110}
review:
Very atmospheric game about space as it should be:

- lost all my fuel (big ship) - dead.
- lost all my oxygen - dead.
- at the far end of the map i have broken my super-duper engine and had no way to fix it, it works, but jumps poor - dead.
- did not find Fe on planets - dead.
- long jump twice - at destination no Gas Giant, at nearby systems too, so no fuel - dead.

Being a developer (web stack, not game dev) , sometimes i thinking about own game about space - and "Out there" is a game I like.

author: {'steamid': '76561198194167174', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 223, 'playtime_forever': 1594, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1594, 'last_played': 1580624493}

author: {'steamid': '76561198065254738', 'num_games_owned': 272, 'num_reviews': 250, 'playtime_forever': 241, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 241, 'last_played': 1454041778}
review:
It probably should have stayed out there too.

---

It feel kinda like FTL, but without the fun and just resource management. Your knowledge of alien language resets every run so you have to guess your way through interactions with them. Other than that getting along does seem to rely on sheer luck, no matter how good you are at managing your supplies.

author: {'steamid': '76561198037222947', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 3017, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1330, 'last_played': 1588806175}
review: Saw this game recommended on Extra Credits and very glad I checked it out. I'm amazed at how gripping this rogue-like MUD/RPG manages to be with absolutely no combat.

author: {'steamid': '76561198005760542', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 87, 'playtime_forever': 28, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 28, 'last_played': 1588122456}
review: A weak premise with an even weaker execution. The "gameplay" simply consists of a series of random dice rolls with no meaningful decisions or narrative attached to them. Frustratingly punishing with no payoffs or influence on the player's part.

review: Very pretty, interesting story, easy to grasp yet difficult to master. My one complaint is that nothing carries over playthrough to playthrough. author: {'steamid': '76561198153942555', 'num_games_owned': 191, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 876, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 746, 'last_played': 1587845206}
review: Whilst the game banks a lot on luck, many of the problems can be circumvented by always thinking about the worst possible situation and planning wayyy in advance. The community is active and there are plenty of extremely helpful guides available. If you're someone who likes a bit of pain and the satisfaction that comes with a fully completed run, then this is for you

author: {'steamid': '76561198110916067', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 493, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 493, 'last_played': 1585256936}
review:
In current version the whole gameplay is a pure random. You decided to get another ship? Hahaha! What a mistake! Okay, okay, now you decided to use the very new, thoroughly thought-out strategy. Ahahaha! What a mistake, again! Okay, once again. Use this ship and that strategy, don't make this decision but make that, and yeah, here we are! Wait, what? WHAT??? The fuel is out because of some random event? Again? For the 100500 time? Stop. If it's called a game, then why can't I control anything? And if I can't control anything, then why it's called a game?
The time has come, so put this game aside, finally, and don't run it never, ever, ever, ever again.
You're welcome.

author: {'steamid': '76561198002302509', 'num_games_owned': 7614, 'num_reviews': 369, 'playtime_forever': 1128, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1116, 'last_played': 1705696378}
review:
[quote]If you would like to read more of my reviews, check out and follow the [url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/27264611/] ùìïùìæùì∑ùì¥ùîÇ ùìôùì™ùìµùì™ùìπùìÆùì∑ùì∏ùìº curation page [/url] as well as [url=https://steamcommunity.com/groups/FunkyJalapenos] joining the Steam group[/url], feel free to say Hello to the community on the Discord server! [/quote]

[h1] ‚ñÄ‚ñÑ‚ñÄ‚ñÑ‚ñÄ‚ñÑ Out There: Œ© Edition ‚ñÑ‚ñÄ‚ñÑ‚ñÄ‚ñÑ‚ñÄ [/h1]

[u][b]TL,DR Review[/b][/u]

The control scheme for PC players using a mouse is really tedious so play this on the Switch, Mobile, or Tablet instead. This version of Out There may actually be great candidate for the Steam Deck but time will tell.

[u][b]Full Review[/b][/u]

Will this resource focused FTL-like experience be worth your time? Well....

Out There: Omega Edition has you playing as a space explorer who has recently awoken from cryogenic sleep and has stumbled across an advanced piece of technology called the Space Folder. This allows rapid traversal from one interstellar body to another.

The gameplay loop comprises of you investigating planets, derelict ships & more after each jump in search of resources for fuel, oxygen, & repairing the hull of your vessel. There are objectives, alien lifeforms and random events that could also occur after each jump which can easily ruin your run, be prepared to fail a lot.

The story itself is interesting, there are multiple plots to follow if you can survive and progress long enough. The art is appropriate for what it is with a comic book-like presentation. The soundtrack isn't bad but becomes quite repetitive after a few runs.

The largest problem and what has caused me to uninstall this game multiple times is the UI. Much like Tharsis, Out There was clearly designed for touchscreens however it's much more severe in this case. It is so tedious to navigate this game using a mouse, this is especially bizarre when you consider that this game has been ported to consoles. If the UI can't be redesigned for PC, can we at least get controller support? How hard could it be to patch in if the work has already been done? There are also bugs still present in the game, the most problematic being that when you are comparing the cargo of your ship and a derelict ship, the inventory of the ship that you had in your last run appears behind your current ship's inventory. You can actually move any of the materials out of your prior ship if it extends outside of the layout of your current ship. You can then move the material to the derelict ship and use it there or on your current vessel as if you got it on your current run. The game has become stuck on event prompts and has caused me to close out of the game and relaunch, it does auto-save prior to each jump so that particular issue isn't that bad.

I cannot stress how much the UI drags down the whole experience, it makes multiple runs of the game almost intolerable. Out There is on mobile platforms, I would strongly suggest to play it there which I'm sure would be a good experience. There is good content worth checking out in this game, but I would not play this on Steam unless you plan to use a touch interface.

author: {'steamid': '76561198091114262', 'num_games_owned': 658, 'num_reviews': 113, 'playtime_forever': 247, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 247, 'last_played': 1581040020}
review:
Feels narrow in scope and narrow narrow in features. If you are coming this way from FTL or some other notable exploration game it will strike you as quite insufficient on all fronts. 

For a game that can tap into the creativity of text based choice systems its lacks any interesting depth. If perhaps you haven't played similar games this is a good one to start with. Can give you an appetite for the more complex ones.

author: {'steamid': '76561198064338165', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 40, 'playtime_forever': 2889, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2866, 'last_played': 1583686012}
review:
This is a good game.  

If you are worried due to reviews stating that there is too much RNG - I would take that with a grain of salt.  This game has RNG but it is very manageable with the correct playstyle, the ones who complain are approaching the problem the same way every time and do not get far.

author: {'steamid': '76561198010389137', 'num_games_owned': 2545, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 504, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 208, 'last_played': 1582806398}
review:
Others aren't wrong that the bulk of gameplay is out of the player's control, and determined by RNG. Nor that the resource harvesting, which is at the core of the game, is tedious.

What's worse, though is the controls. Everything takes at least one more click than it should. I think this is mostly the legacy of being developed for mobile, but I couldn't say for sure. If you want to know what elements are for, you have to click - tooltips are not implemented. If you want to go from resource harvesting to cargo, that's two clicks: one to go up from the probe screen to the planetary screen, and another to go from there to the ship screen. Why does the mini menu disappear when probing? I have no idea. Then you want to jump to leave the system: that's one click to go up to planetary, another to galactic. 

For that matter, why do I need to change screen at all in order to deploy resources? Both the probe screen and the ship screen show my cargo, so...? And there are no keyboard controls whatsoever. 1 for galactic map, 2 for system map, 3 for ship would be logical. Not done

I dunno, guys. I liked the idea. I love emergent narrative. Can't recommend the execution at all

Final comment: why on earth do alien conversations disappear rather than stay onscreen after you've learned some of their words?

author: {'steamid': '76561197972251641', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 39, 'playtime_forever': 30, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 30, 'last_played': 1581882057}
review:
Pure RNG, tiresome gameplay, and tedious tasks of refueling and repairing the ship. FTL does a much better job a this kind of genre by keeping you at least hooked with challenging combat.

In "Out There" you just get randomly punished by visiting constellations. This raises the difficulty artificially to a point where it kills my enjoyment.This game was clearly made with mobiles in mind and as such might be enjoyable by some folk. Considering the price of 14,99‚Ç¨ I just cannot recommend this game to anyone at this time.

author: {'steamid': '76561198035717993', 'num_games_owned': 2086, 'num_reviews': 106, 'playtime_forever': 174, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 174, 'last_played': 1578047588}
review:
It has some nice parts, but they don't really add up to a satisfying whole.

There is the gameplay - heavily RNG influenced, though you can learn from your mistakes, and know what kind of thing to avoid. But the gameplay loop involves you playing, dying, losing everything, rinse and repeat. 

The writing - the story is basically that you have 'amnesia' and you want to get to the other side of the galaxy. There is some ok writing here, but in the 3 or so hours I played, I didn't feel that I learned much. There is mostly a lot of well-written descriptions of random things happening to you as you travel through space, or the player character pondering their situation.

There is nothing terrible about the artwork. Static backdrops when you land on planets. A nice map of each solar system. Cool animations as you fly through space. It's all kind of basic, but it looks ok for an indie game.

I don't have a strong objection to grindy/repititive gameplay, thin writing, or simple art in a game. I've played games which had worse/less on one or more counts, and had plenty of fun. However in this case, these three parts did not mesh together in a way that made me want to keep playing. I just got bored.

review: Nice to see a roguelite that doesn't focus on combat. The game is about trying to get to your destination without running out of fuel, or oxygen, or hull integrity. The art is nice. Seems to be a neat story too, though I'm just starting.

author: {'steamid': '76561197971589114', 'num_games_owned': 223, 'num_reviews': 61, 'playtime_forever': 534, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 534, 'last_played': 1570419578}
review:
This is an extremely entertaining and frustrating roguelike good for two or three full playthroughs... and countless failures getting there. The interface, gameplay and even plot are deceptively simple, but very rewarding.

Because of its simplicity, replay value is limited (I beat it just twice before losing interest)... but even so the 9 hours I spent on this game was easily worth the price of admission.

author: {'steamid': '76561198080849193', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 1032, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 655, 'last_played': 1628332343}
review:
Out There is a great game with about 10-20 hrs of gameplay. I would recommend you to buy it if you enjoy strategy games. 

Some people here mentioned randomness and overall difficulty of the game. The reality is that the game is pretty easy once you  learn the ropes. The issue is that you have to learn it all by yourself which can be frustrating as you often dont even know about some game mechanics like for example changing omega for 25 fuel/oxygen/hull or the mechanism of the blackhole drive. If you keep losing constantly just read some of the great guides out there (pun intended).

author: {'steamid': '76561198005129009', 'num_games_owned': 245, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 2459, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1574, 'last_played': 1570197953}
review:
This game has a reasonably steep learning curve. With a bit of research about the likely composition of different star systems, and figuring out ways of maximising my cargo load - I finally managed to start making some decent headway.

I had an awesome ship, an array of different technologies at my disposal and was on my way to completing my first mission.

I built myself a "Wormhole Generator" - which turns black hole systems into shortcuts to other black holes. All at the cost of 1 "Omega". The games ultimate resource. Once I had take a travelled a few wormholes - I arrived at the "Blue" mission system.

This was the homeworld of the "Enemy People" and I was the arbiter of their doom. I planted the "Death Seed" into their home system's sun and enjoyed my first victory on Out There!

Only three more campaigns to complete. I wonder what is in store for me...

I highly recommend this game if you like FTL. It doesn't have the action - but it definitely has soul.

author: {'steamid': '76561198057653068', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 146, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 129, 'last_played': 1566206182}
review:
Tr√®s bon petit jeu, avec un petit c√¥t√© rogue spatial fa√ßon FTL mais sans combats et surtout ax√© sur la narration et l'exploration...

Mais il a quand m√™me un "petit" probl√®me, vous l'aurez sans doute devin√©s si vous y avez jou√©s..


La moiti√© du gameplay repose sur la chance...ET C'EST SUPER FRUSTRANT, RAAAAAAAH !!! *kof kof*

Le nombre de fois ou tu te tape des pannes de carburant alors que tu viens enfin d'√™tre √† l'aise avec un vaisseau super (avec quelques upgrades, mais √©trangement jamais celles du t√©lescope) car tu enchaine trois syst√®mes avec juste une plan√®tes rocheuse et rien d'autre, pour finir par mourir en d√©rivant dans l'espace comme un sac... Et ce n'est qu'un exemple, quand ce n'est pas une cascade de pannes random que tu ne peut pas r√©parer avec ce que tu a; mais le pire reste le syst√®me de langue ou a moins d'avoir un guide ou noter les pattern, c'est pile ou face au d√©but du jeu pour savoir ce qu'ils veulent.
En attendant on a quand m√™me moyen d'avoir des plan√®tes gazeuses tailles pegasides qui n'arrivent pas √† te faire le plein d'hydrog√®ne malgr√© tout...

Bref sympas, avec un univers de SF franchement pas mal; mais vite aga√ßant; je ne le recommanderais qu'√† ceux qui ont le courage de supporter l'aspect al√©atoire (car non, l'al√©atoire n'est pas de la difficult√©, seulement arriver √† s'y adapter en supposant que ce soit possible)... ou alors prenez des calmants si vous √™tes facilement sur les nerfs comme moi (voir juste une table solide pour votre pc quand vous taperez une √©ni√®me fois du poing sur la table).
M√™me avec l'option pour drop les vaisseaux en cas d'√©chec (en supposant que ce soit bien √ßa), tout ce que j'ai r√©ussis √† faire pour le moment c'est semer un cimeti√®re de vaisseaux en panne s√®che √† travers la galaxie alors que je ne pouvais franchement gu√®re g√©rer le carburant mieux avec les donn√©es que j'avais...

author: {'steamid': '76561198148644390', 'num_games_owned': 142, 'num_reviews': 40, 'playtime_forever': 343, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 256, 'last_played': 1626701936}
review:
J'ai peut-√™tre que quatre heures sur ce jeu, mais c'est le temps qu'il m'aura fallut pour d√©bloquer l'une des quatre fins (je crois que c'est quatre). 
Le jeu est compliqu√©, d√©pend beaucoup de la chance, vous fera vous demander si vous auriez pas mieux fait d'acheter FTL, qui est une comparaison de choix en parlant d'Out There, mais au final vous resterez et vous tenterez jusqu'√† avoir les r√©ponses √† vos questions sur l'univers, berc√© par une OST tr√®s bonne et par des situations assez ... Sp√©ciales (genre un ver g√©ant dans l'espace, ouaip.) 
BREF. Sachez qu'il y a beaucoup de RNG mais beaucoup de moyens de la "modifier" via les am√©liorations de votre vaisseau. Bon jeu !

author: {'steamid': '76561198147269775', 'num_games_owned': 193, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 331, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 312, 'last_played': 1565429770}
review:
A lot of reviews focus on the fact that bad luck can make you lose this game no matter what, and this is indeed true. However, I don't think it's fair to say that that's all there is to it. By stockpiling the right resources, strategically visiting some systems and not others, installing the right kinds of equipment, you can drastically improve your chances. The game does very little hand-holding, so you'll have to figure these things out by dying a number of times in unfortunate ways, but personally that doesn't bother me too much.

The only thing that I'd like to see added to this game is custom markers that you can put on systems.

author: {'steamid': '76561198052204825', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 224, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 224, 'last_played': 1563838693}
review:
Au d√©part c'est un jeu sympa avec une histoire qui se d√©couvre petit √† petit et avec de la narration amusante. 

Cependant pass√© 3-4h de jeu on se rend vite compte qu'il est tr√®s difficile de progresser au del√† de l'√©toile 25 et que tout le jeu est bas√© sur la chance.

M√™me si le jeu te montre des possibilit√©s de progression int√©ressantes avec de nouveaux modules, de nouvelles missions, etc.. √ßa devient tr√®s accessoire et inutile √† c√¥t√© de la n√©cessit√© absolue de stocker du carburant et du soin. Pas de place pour un nouveau module dans ces vaisseaux minuscules. 
Il n'y a qu'√† prendre un plus grand vaisseau vous me direz ? Et bien cela ne change rien puisque qu'il faut encore plus de carburant pour d√©placer ces gros vaisseaux, et donc stocker encore plus, etc.. 
Bon bref ce jeu para√Æt cool au d√©but mais lasse tr√®s tr√®s rapidement car aucun espoir de voir la fin sauf peut-etre 1 fois sur 1000  quand tu as beaucoup beaucoup beaucoup de chance.

author: {'steamid': '76561197997014523', 'num_games_owned': 409, 'num_reviews': 70, 'playtime_forever': 404, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 404, 'last_played': 1563974149}
review:
Extremely amateurish, you can really tell it was a mobile game. When the game's RNG goes against you, it goes all-out. When it goes in favor, it only works if you have inventory space (a big problem in the game, though it's reasonable that you don't have enough room) or your stats (fuel, oxygen, hull) aren't full - also gathering resources on planets takes fuel, and you can't spend it on the ship to free up inventory before leaving the loot screen, which forces you to ditch perfectly usable stuff simply because of the idiotic menu design.
If you want to spend your iron to fix your ship (and open up a slot) before mining a planet but leave just enough to fix the mining equipment in case in breaks, tough luck. If you have a free slot, you can split it, but most of the time you'll be stacked and forced to throw stuff away when there's no real need for it. Even on a planet with atmosphere you can't leave things just lying there for a sec while you refuel/resupply your ship or install new equipment after which you're ready to dispose of a resource you don't really need anymore.
The writing is riddled with bad spelling and especially random use of capital letters, it's obvious no one ever bothered to spell-check this.
Protag is a total idiot and breaks equipment all the time, which can be a bitch to repair because of how resources are stored in this game. You can store up to 20 of one resource in one slot, but it won't be enough to store two pieces of two different resources. Storage is really limited on all ships, which would've been perfectly fine if it was based on actual size and not slots. Also, with the protag being such a clumsy idiot who is really casual about all the deadly stuff that happens to him it's pretty hard to relate to him.
Creatures of all races across the galaxy, except human, speak the same language that you very slowly learn as you go and it gets reset on every new playthrough.
RNG, of course. Find a nice, high quality of life ship that unfortunately uses a different resource for fuel and it can only be mined on planets with atmosphere? Well you're in trouble if you stop encountering those for no real reason.
There is just so much artificial difficulty here. If you want a good space roguelike game, go for FTL and avoid this.

author: {'steamid': '76561198050016554', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 517, 'playtime_forever': 734, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 734, 'last_played': 1563788755}
review:
Out there: Œ© edition est un die and retry d'exploration √† peu de choses pr√®s pacifique qui se focalise sur la strat√©gie de gestion de ressource pour alimenter la propulsion, respirer et r√©parer. Cette course aux ressources nous maintient dans une ambiance assez pesante typique de ce type de jeu, soutenue par des √©v√©nements fr√©quents et un apprentissage linguistique d√©licat au fil des rencontres mais qui aidera √† acqu√©rir de nouvelles technos. La RNG de r√©partition des plan√®tes peut √™tre fr√©quemment punitive avec le vaisseau de d√©part, il faudra un petit coup de pouce du destin pour trouver dans un d√©lai raisonnable un vaisseau capable d'aller au bout sinon... dans l'espace, personne ne vous entend tomber en panne s√®che. 

Le gameplay souffre cependant d'avoir une phase r√©p√©titive de collecte aussi fun que de faire le plein √† la station-service du bout de la rue, l'odeur de gazole en moins.

Les joies du stress de l'explo hasardeuse l'ont emport√© sur ma lassitude face √† la r√©p√©titivit√©, avis positif.

author: {'steamid': '76561198143257798', 'num_games_owned': 181, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 292, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 292, 'last_played': 1563659290}
review:
having some luck involved in your games makes them more replayable.
making your game completely luck based makes me want to never play it again.

so my first few runs were me running around in the dark trying to understand what is happening and i died 3 times in a row because the game didn't explain the importance of stuff, so i was carrying around stacks of completely useless materials (there is no way of knowing how useful something is, and how much you should risk for it, unless you played the game before)

then i died 4 more times because i just got unlucky. you can just fly into systems where there is no fuel which is a death sentence unless you have some stored up (there is no way to know what a system has, or how much)

now, this game probably sounds really unfair at this point, but don't worry! you can get more info about systems and stuff with tech! how do you get tech you ask? you get it through either a text event (complete RNG without prior knowledge) or aliens (complete RNG for the first 7 or so meetings).

which leads me to the run i had just now where i managed to get a stupid OP ship and a stack of  nearly every resource in the game after reaching critical mass with tech where i could actually make informed choices. i could do anything i wanted at that point.

well, actually, i couldn't because i wanted to do some sidequests but the game doesn't let you look at the star-map, so you just have to hope you're going in the right direction. there is no way to turn back, either. you would run out of fuel instantly.

but at least i got to finish the game, right?
nope. i was missing a necessary bit of tech that i needed that i needed to get over to that system.
it's not a story thing i'm overlooking, i got it randomly in a past run.

go play poker with the money you would have bought this game with. poker has some skill involved and is not nearly as frustrating.

author: {'steamid': '76561197966557804', 'num_games_owned': 1250, 'num_reviews': 208, 'playtime_forever': 319, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 318, 'last_played': 1580004879}
review:
This is a rouge-like travel game. The narrative conceit is that you've overslept in your cryogenic coffin travelling from Earth to Jupiter, and are now lost in space. Fortunately, some aliens give you a new technology --- the Manifold Something-or-another --- which allows you to travel between the stars more quickly. Your ultimate goal is to get back to Earth, though in terms of plot I wonder if Earth is even still inhabited by homo sapiens given we don't really know how long you've been asleep.

Almost every time you do something, you consume resources. Resources seem to be elements (e.g., O, Fe, Pt), and if nothing else you'll remember your Periodic Table of the Elements after playing a few hours of this. Each ship requires fuel, oxygen and hull materials. Different engines consume different kinds of fuel. You can also build new technologies, but have only so much room in the hull of your ship, barring a particular  technology which expands your hold size (but I can't recall its name). These technologies will grant some source of advantage, usually in terms of revealing more about your environment or reducing the speed with which your ship consumes resources. 

Each solar system contains either a star or a black hole (or maybe quasars, too, but I didn't go to that start system when I saw it). I've seen red dwarves, yellow dwarves, blue dwarves, though I can't tell if star type influences the number or kinds of planets in that system. Each system can contain any combination of a space station, wreck, garden world, mineral-rich world, or gas giant. Unlike any other item in the game, the space station will refill O2, fuel or hull to 100% repeatedly. However, it will only refill one of these kinds of resources. Planets produce resources, assuming you have the appropriate tech, but at a diminishing rate of return. Thus, returning to an already-visited world will not greet the player with a rejuvenated world, but instead at the resource level you left it at before you skeedaddled. The only exception to this is oxygen at garden worlds, which refills your O2 tanks. Garden worlds also contain intelligent aliens who might trade with you.

Aesthetically, the game employs a minimalist, comic-book-like cut scenes whenever something weird happens. Music is ok. 

I've put in a few hours at the time of writing this, and it is enjoyable in short bursts. RNGesus will sometimes smile upon, and other times crucify you. Once I misjumped and end up in a cluster of stars which were not close enough to other stars so I was stuck. Occasionally I've found a better ship (i.e., more storage and better technology). If you run out of resources, you might still move, but the game will probably end.

Currently I am annoyed with the game, as I've just died for probably the 10th time in an hour or so. However, it is a rouge-like, so what did I expect?  Anyway, I recommend the game, especially on sale. 

ps None of the game guides are current, as in 2019 it was reconfigured for the Twitch, which added new content.

review: Ce n'est pas que le jeu est difficile... C'est qu'il est Cruel ! Alors, pour ceux qui aiment le sadomasochisme, ce jeu est parfait pour eux !! Mais quand on te dit que tu peux aller jusqu'√† ta destination alors que tu n'as plus de carburant, et que c'est seulement une fois que tu as voyag√© qu'on te dit que finalement, non t'as perdu... J'ai envie de dire : pourquoi m'avoir laiss√© esp√©rer, mec !?! Sans compter ton pilote qui n'est pas foutu de piloter son vaisseau correctement, les emmerdes qui se multiplient au fur et √† mesure que tu t'enfonces dans la m***e... Franchement, ce jeu est terriblement d√©cevant par son c√¥t√© Vicieux, alors qu'il a un bon sc√©nario. Du Gachis, c'est tout.

author: {'steamid': '76561198322709726', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 102, 'playtime_forever': 473, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 177, 'last_played': 1654982707}
review:
Ce rogue like est un digne repr√©sentant du genre. Sans concession et √¢pre, il n'aura de cesse de vous humilier au moindre faux pas, vous pouvez traverser une dizaine ou une quinzaine de syst√®mes et ne pas trouver ni vaisseau ni technologie (ce qui posera des probl√®mes d√®s lors que vous approcherez des lieux de missions jaunes/rouges/bleues). Et refaire une partie et trouver au bout du deuxi√®me saut un vaisseau particuli√®rement ample.

De la m√™me fa√ßon, il suffit d'une combinaison malheureuse d'events (m√™me en facile) et de sauts dans des syst√®mes ou occup√©s, ou peu fournis en carburant pour que ce soit la fin de l'aventure.

Alors recommencer encore et encore peut vite lasser (m√™me si vous pouvez r√©cup√©rer vos vaisseaux lors de votre nouvelle progression), c'est ce que je sanctionne ici pr√©sent. FTL permet de r√©duire le c√¥t√© al√©atoire tout en gardant une difficult√© pr√©sente.

review:
Un jeu qui ne cesse de surprendre le joueur durant toute ses parties. Les aventures dans l'espace sont certes, al√©atoires et peuvent tant√¥t vous pourrir la vie comme vous sauver d'une situation d√©sesp√©r√©e. Bon, j'esp√®re pour vous que votre chance sera au rendez-vous, de ce cot√© le jeu ne vous fera pas de cadeau et ce m√™me en mode facile... 
Et si vous aimez tout ce qui touche √† l'espace...

review:
It looks fun but I encountered a bug that makes it impossible to play after early-game :/
The scrollbar of the screen to upgrade your ship (technologies) is broken, which means I'm stuck with ~8 basic technologies for the entire game.

I digged a little and the bug was already known back in 2015 so I have no reason to think it will ever be fixed.

I'll just ask for a refund.

author: {'steamid': '76561198003519799', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 56, 'playtime_forever': 323, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 323, 'last_played': 1559978748}
review: This is a game about flying around in space, things happening to you, and resource management. Unlike most games in this genre, it's less based on pew-pew space opera but on a weirder and more laid-back tradition of science fiction - Captain Blood, Moebius, there's even a ship quite reminiscent of The Fountain.

author: {'steamid': '76561198005576643', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 168, 'playtime_forever': 182, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 152, 'last_played': 1666753300}
review: As some sort of mixture of old sci-fi gamebooks (Ian Livingstone style) that were pretty popular in my childhood in the '80s and limited resource / ship management, it is a pretty great and pretty challenging little game. Absolutely recommended for any sci-fi fan.

author: {'steamid': '76561198413696044', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 907, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 350, 'last_played': 1559029563}
review: Tr√®s bon jeu mais les beugs sont bien trop pr√©sents et surtout handicapants!.... deuxi√®me partie o√π je suis tr√®s avanc√©, proche de la fin jaune et rouge et mon jeu crash totalement...

author: {'steamid': '76561198032323996', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 30, 'playtime_forever': 633, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 199, 'last_played': 1558643220}
review:
Relies for too much on RNG and not skill. You can be doing just great, then suddenly 3 or 4 systems in a row without one vital ingredient (oxygen, iron, or fuel) and even if you had totally full bars and ALL your cargo maxed out, you'll die. Unbalanced.

Shame, because with just a little more emphasis on tactics rather than luck, it'd be fun. 
Also the inability to fuel or repair when you're using a probe is INFURIATING and often game-breaking.

Essentially, you're battling the dice here, and nothing else.

author: {'steamid': '76561198000103988', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 189, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 189, 'last_played': 1557614126}
review:
While story-rich part of the game have my approval, illogical interaction at the encounters, when character should have full control - is not. Game waist player time and give nothing back.
On top of that, for the Sci-Fi game pilot protagonist environment is extremely poor. No sensors. No databases. Not even ability to mark explored systems on map. Nothing to plan and nothing to improve on ship without mysterious all-mighty aliens schematics. Game had potential, but it was wasted.
Play only if you have time to spend on meaningless interaction with random generator in pursue of storyline.

author: {'steamid': '76561197978732460', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 812, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 578, 'last_played': 1557820839}
review:
This is not an easy game. I usually play games I can win at by playing at the easy level. Even at easy you'll likely run out of fuel, air or something and then die (you go back into cryosleep). Start over. 

But once you learn how to find what you need and how to get a new (bigger) ship you start to make progress. And since it's all random it's fairly a luck thing. But it has provided me with hours of entertainment. And the various endings are hilarious. 

I recommend the game to those looking for something like this.

author: {'steamid': '76561198091563632', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 539, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 472, 'last_played': 1683481231}
review:

author: {'steamid': '76561198097499155', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 242, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 17, 'last_played': 1580567185}
review: The idea of this game is actually beautiful. There are a lot to explore and the plot is not bad. Yet the difficulty of the game makes it kind of unbeatable. Not having a save option makes it really hard to beat the game. You need to be really lucky in order to have the opportunities to beat the game. You must land in neccesary planets and systems and find good sources and ships. And they're completely random. There are random choices that you make during the gameplay, they also need lots of luck to actually face with something useful. But besides the difficulty problem, the game itself is gorgeous. Facing with different lifeforms, choosing between different endings, collecting different elements in order to put out new technologies, finding new abandoned ships; they all make you enjoy the game. To sum up, don't expect much of a playtime, and be ready to rage quit because of the events that you can't even interfere. You'll be having a great time trying to explore the galaxy and seeing different endings. Can be purchaseable if caught on a discount.

author: {'steamid': '76561198053547790', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 75, 'playtime_forever': 73, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 73, 'last_played': 1555938180}
review: This plays like a mobile game upscaled to PC, and I'll bet that's exactly what it is. The only thing you do is click on things, and watch your fuel go down until it hits nothing and you die. There's very little you can do, and the difficulty is entirely through the fast deterioration of resources that only random chance will give back to you. A masterclass in how NOT to make a roguelike.

author: {'steamid': '76561198018297138', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 2195, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 193, 'last_played': 1696425807}
review: Un FTL like en plus simple au niveau de la microgestion, mais beaucoup plus dure en terme de survie, le manque du moindre gramme de ressource peut vous tuer, je recommande pour tous les amoureux de Rogue like qui veulent passer un moment au calme devant un jeu qui ne mets pas une pression constante.

Really great concept and art. but a bit luck based game & Heavy management based with mix of survival. Easy to understand, but really hard to master (especially to achieve most of the story ending).

Really worth my time.

review: Out There est un tr√®s bon rogue-like. Attention pour commencer, c'est un jeu difficile. Le die-and-retry est tr√®s pr√©sent et vous allez devoir faire pas mal de parties pour apprendre √† savoir quand r√©cup√©rer des ressources, chercher de nouvelles technologies, ou changer de vaisseau. L'histoire du jeu est tr√®s belle et pleine de philosophie. La qu√™te, en apparence binaire, dispose de fins multiples et qui changent la fa√ßon de jouer et d'aborder le jeu : sprint, marathon, exploration, interactions. Pour ce qui est de la philosophie, le journal de bords et les diff√©rentes fins nous offrent des cl√©s de r√©flexion sur la place de l'Humanit√© dans l'espace, et c'est tr√®s sympa. Un jeu qui permet de m√©diter, et de s'amuser.

author: {'steamid': '76561198048678654', 'num_games_owned': 1542, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 284, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 265, 'last_played': 1555807516}
review: 95% of gameplay is based on searching for fuel/iron and annoying inventory management so you don't run out of juice/HP. Even when by some miracle you end up fully stocked with resources, there simply isn't anything else to do - the game offers little to no exploration. Jump to the next system - drill for fuel - probe for hydrogen - jump - repeat ad nauseam. While the "one more run" syndrome is present here, it quickly gets very boring and repetetive. It's ok as a 4.99 USD mobile game, but selling this at 2,5x the price on Steam is a ripoff.

author: {'steamid': '76561198138751517', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 40, 'playtime_forever': 173, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 78, 'last_played': 1559620621}
review:
I paid less than 4 dollars for this game, which is about as much as it is worth if it actually worked....as is, it's sort of like playing a game of chance every minute or so, with the odds stacked against you about 70-30 maybe.

Basically, in order to survive, you need to maintain three resources:  Iron, Oxygen, and fuel.

The first two aren't really that hard to get, though there is always a chance you might run out....but fuel is incredibly hard to get, and even worse....pretty much everything you do consumes a significant amount of fuel.  Want to drill?  that'll be 5 percent of your fuel please.  Want to get MORE fuel?  Yes, you'll need to pay fuel to get your fuel so you can fuel!  

It's just silly because you will constantly run out of resources and have to restart over and over again.  And again.  AND AGAIN.

It's sad, because the premise is really quite cool, and the actual gameplay is fun...except for the main part, the "resource management" aka, hope you get lucky and find enough resources everytime you enter a new system, because, well, eventually you won't, the odds are just against it.  

I'd get a refund but it only cost me a few bucks and maybe I'll play it some more to give it another chance.

author: {'steamid': '76561198019092670', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 844, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 527, 'last_played': 1601169348}
review:
Pros: storyline, ambiance, creative game mechanics
Cons: BUGGY
7/10

DISCLAIMER: I initially installed this game on WIndows 8.1 and had a very frustrating bug where the mouse didn't work after launching it once on any of the subsequent launches. Game was unplayable, so I uninstalled.

Eventually I upgraded my system to Windows 10 and decided to give it another shot. Game ran much more smoothly and I played for hours before I noticed another small bug. It is immersive and addictive and continue to offer a surprising variety of encounters when you would expect it to become repetitive. The mechanics are great in that you learn and hone your strategy as you play, but there is always an element of chance to keep runs distinct from another. The game offers a lot for how deceptively simple it is.

author: {'steamid': '76561198006536707', 'num_games_owned': 359, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 232, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 232, 'last_played': 1545887772}
review: My girlfriend walked in on me playing this and rather quickly had to ask "Why are you playing this? I hope you didn't pay anything for it."  I could eloborate on why this is not a good game but there is so little actual gameplay it is embarassing.

author: {'steamid': '76561198049966313', 'num_games_owned': 276, 'num_reviews': 48, 'playtime_forever': 47, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 47, 'last_played': 1546275867}
review:
I'm less annoyed by the intended frustration and hard difficulty and more by every turn basically being the same.
You fly to a new area, something breaks. You'll have to either repair that equipment or rebuild it
Mineral rich and Gas rich planets are always the same. You fly there, extract ressources and continue. 
Interactions with aliens are always the same. They say a sentence of which you may have learnd some words at that point. You get to choose between agreeing and disagreeing. If you chose the right one you unlock a new blueprint and some extra words.
As you progress you upgrade your ship.
It feels like im doing the same thing over and over again. There's barely any variety in interactivity with the world

author: {'steamid': '76561197970389552', 'num_games_owned': 713, 'num_reviews': 54, 'playtime_forever': 195, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 156, 'last_played': 1599719223}
review:
I do recommend Out There, but with an asterisk.

It is hugely dependent on luck and rng-esus. No amount of prep or thought will keep you from getting your self killed. One of the options lets your dead derilict selves float in space for you to rediscover giving the game a bit of rougelike feel but the option isnt on by default. It makes for a better experience but still leaves you boned often

author: {'steamid': '76561198105785707', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 332, 'playtime_forever': 635, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 566, 'last_played': 1549214270}
review:
[h1](follow my curator page [url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/33882793/]GenXPlayers[/url] for more retro and indie reviews)[/h1]

This game has been described as a pacifist version of FTL, which is correct. Most of the multiple choice options are non lethal. It also reminds of the old french game 'Captain blood' by some of the themes. It has a lot of interesting illustrations and tons of lore narration and the whole game is trying to bring an existentialist mood to that 'alone in space' adventure.
The musics are also very good if you're into that space ambient/star trek style.

Unfortunately the game mechanics are not very good.
First of all everything costs too much in terms of ressources. Everything costs fuel and/or oxygen and/or hull points. Sometimes the game doesn't even notify you that you're losing points, like when you're landing on a garden planet and losing hull points.
The game ergonomy is also very bad and absolutely not optimised. Every action needs way more mouse clicks than they should. you pretty much spend you whole time clicking useless dialogs and subdialogs. The main tasks (such as refilling ressources into the ship) are not automated and you have to spend a lot of time dragging blocks into squares.

The ressources are , not too scarce, but the work to get them uses up some more ressources, very generously so, so  it's very difficult to win againt the odds without a good ship. Going on a gas giant to mine fuel can deplete up to 45% of your hull ! Nothing can justify this. and you have to be mining for fuel constantly.
The tech upgrades are rare and they will require you to mine rock planets which will use up your precious fuel.
Some of the tech upgrades let you jump further, but at the cost of more fuel, so they are actually dangerous to use.

All the narrative texts, interesting at the begining, end up becoming tedious to read, especially when they're written in a rather familiar and sometimes vulgar tone that clashes with the mood of the  game.

The game is finisheable, but it relies on your luck to stumble upon a good ship pretty early on. And the gameplay is too dreary to retain the attention long enough to try and unlock the alternative endings which seem rather interesting.

author: {'steamid': '76561198116413026', 'num_games_owned': 306, 'num_reviews': 56, 'playtime_forever': 1439, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1219, 'last_played': 1579831132}
review:
Un jeu assez √©pur√©, beaucoup de gestion de stock, un peu de chance, pas mal de connaissance et pour ma part le mode cimeti√®re (pour nos vaisseaux d'ancienne partie qui trainent dans l'espace) pour arriver au bout du voyage √† fin multiples. 
Car la douille est la, parfois vous avez le vaisseau parfait pour la fin x mais vous √™tes sur la y. Bref, respect si vous battez le jeu sans la chance de refaire le stock sur un vieux vaisseau.

author: {'steamid': '76561198013738000', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 224, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 186, 'last_played': 1674611939}
review:
Out There is a neat, procedural exploration game that has a few annoying warts. 
First, the 'pathing' between star systems is something of a crapshoot. In two of my playthroughs I've run out of fuel simply beacuse the game led me down a dead end. Very frustrating. 
The gameplay elements are simple, rewarding, and feed into one another nicely. 
There are several frustrating issues with the UI, such as not being able to scroll through a menu of available technolgies, which make it impossible to fully upgrade a ship. 
Inventory management is a chore and you spend more time than expected doing that. 
You'll see I've only spent about 3 hours playing this, but they've been 3 hours of moderate frustration interspersed with both genuinely interesting moments and abject "are you fucking kidding me?" moments as well. 

If you want an indie space game, buy FTL. It won't fight you to enjoy it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198035182410', 'num_games_owned': 1144, 'num_reviews': 372, 'playtime_forever': 155, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 155, 'last_played': 1541450319}
review:
After 3 hours and respectivly 17 games where "my journey ended" cause I didn't have fuel anymore, I concluded that is is actually a pretty bad game. 

Art Design and soundtrack are really great and the reason you might as first be drawn to this. But it turns soon out that gameplay wise you bought a hybrid of Inventory Teris and dice roll simulator. 

You can't even begin to imagine how clunky the inventory in this game is. Everything you do needs fuel (He or H). So you need to carry fuel at all times or you'll die. Which means on each star that has Gas Giants you need to stop and probe 2-3 times until the Gas Giant is depleted (yes really). 

But you can't just press probe 3 times, no that would be too easy! You need to drag them into your inventory first or its gets overwritten. Problem: You have like 3 free places, the rest is filled with gold and copper. You don't need gold, copper and Thorium until you get the high tech stuff. But then if you don't have it you will run out of fuel trying to find a planet that has gold again. So you keep it. 

So in order to just get fuel you have to probe it, then you go to a different screen to refill the fuel to clear the inventory. Then you go back to the star screen, select the planet again so you can probe again. Do that 3-4 times in each system for 100+ stars and you will gadly take that game overscreen over the actual game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198026083507', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 338, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 338, 'last_played': 1532005688}
review:
A most assuredly fun game. The various endings are fine, the gameplay is reasonably simple, and it gets frustrating failing halfway through a journey. And yet despite that, I find this game absolutely wonderful, a pure joy to play. Why is that? Well, to be frank, it's the journey, the music. I play, that music rolling through my mind, and find myself calm, no matter what happens. Sure, it's mostly about mining and trying to choose what to do. About selecting upgrades, and trying to keep that ramshackle thing ya call a ship flying. And yet I enjoy it so much. I want to go through, see how far I can travel. And find that, though the journey was long, and I've run out of fuel an hour in, I'm still happy.

It's not for everyone. It's a calm game, no major action. Everything is mostly shown in text, and the occasional shot of an alien life form or such. But I still can't help but be enthralled. I feel like it's sense of vastness is wonderful. Basically, this is a game that focuses on resources as you travel, upgrades, and trying to figure out what everyones sayin. I think, if you want something relaxing, a bit challenging, and with a beautiful soundtrack, then this might just be for you.

If nothing else, I love the feeling that everything is vast and new and unknown...it's just...enthralling to me.

author: {'steamid': '76561198049616421', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 182, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 182, 'last_played': 1534254875}
review: I want my three hours back. Great idea, but lack of content and poor execution. The UI is frustrating, you're always clicking back to maintain you ship. Space is so tight and you can only do it on the one screen, so if you forget to maintain before every refueling, then your going to have to throw something out to make room. Everything you do costs resources, too much resources, you could go through all of your fuel exploring 3 systems. Eventually I got a cool ship and was doing good. But I couldn't make the jumps... They were just far. I had the tech for longer jumps, but no Thorium. Before I found Thorium, aliens stole my tech. Got tech again, still no thorium, lost tech again, found thorium. Had backtracked all the way to the start by then. Whatever. Needs more story and better resource system. Would not recommend, waste of time, delete delete.

author: {'steamid': '76561197969837233', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 1749, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1464, 'last_played': 1553006473}
review:
What can I say?  This game has far too much RNG, and far too little player agency.  Almost every game handed me multiple blueprints that I simply could not ever build because, despite actively trying to get the resoures needed, going to places that would presuably have them, the RNG simply would not ever give me what I need.  And there really arent many options available to you otherwise.  A single run is made or broken based off how your starting situation is.  If itdoesnt give you anything, your screwed.  If it gives you anything at all, that thing itself needs something else to be useful.  Most commonly, this is in the form of blueprints for technology that has exceedingly precise resource requirements.  You have absolutely zero control of what resources you get.  I think 80% of my playthroughs can be characterised with me running around to find those specific resources, even looking up guides to see what planets to look on, and still getting RNG-fucked out of everything.  And you need these technologies, as the starting ship is utter crap.  In the end, I simply never felt like any of my decisions mattered in any capacity, and my survival was exclusively decided by the RNG, and never any decisions I made.  And what kind of decisions are there?  First, choosing what stars to visit.  Despite various supposed propensities for what kind of planets will be found, there is still an RNG factor.  And you never now what resources will be found on each planet, beyond the most basic element of rock planets having metals, and gas giants fuels.  Once you go to a planet, you get to decide how much fuel you spend drilling/collecting resources, but even that is absurdly RNG-dependent, and really only offers a slight bonus to how much you get.  And again, you get absolutely zero control of what kinds of resources you DO get.  
Then, when you meet alien life, you get two dialogue choices; approve or disapprove.  But the aliens speak their own language, which you unravel literally one or two words at a time, and this alien dictionary itself is reset on each playthrough, so when your in that ever-critical early game, dialogue choices are just a complete coin-toss.

With so many random factors, you will rarely ever get far enough for many options to open up, and after trying to play this game for long enough, I've simply gotten tired.  There is just too little player agency early on, and the RNG is simply too cruel to ever let you see a slightly better endgame.

Oh, and the random text-adventure events are just awful.  Almost every one of them uses an utterly cheap twist ending or some kind of deus ex machina to betray whatever your choices are, regardless of whether you try to play it cautious or bold.  It may not be as much player vs rng in this case, but instead its player vs asshole choose-your-own-adventure authors.

author: {'steamid': '76561197990725997', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 360, 'playtime_forever': 526, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 526, 'last_played': 1531535117}
review:
I've had the game since it came out and I come back to it every now and again to delve into the narrative and atmosphere of lonely space. I enjoy it for what it is, the art is great, music is great and yes the mining is SUPER repetitive and you almost never have enough and then suddenly when you got everything you hit a meteor and damage something and you're like well then...

I only got to the end once. Full price may be a bit much, but def support these developers. They are providing some good hours of fun and narrative.

author: {'steamid': '76561198027267313', 'num_games_owned': 1838, 'num_reviews': 4460, 'playtime_forever': 357, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 357, 'last_played': 1643041523}
review:
Tags: Tactical - Space Crew Sim
Additional Tags: Delete Local Content & Remove from Library

TLDR: FTL without combat, instead triple survival gauge+cargo space management. You can unlock alien words for translatin and the odd ship upgrade you can craft using survival gauge mined materials. 

Jump between hotspots, go to planets to probe fuel out of the air, and drill for elements. Get the odd upgrade through random event. Craft upgrades, swap ships when you find an abandonned one. Reach last hotspot to win. Three survival gauges, limited cargo space makes the game a tad tricky and subject to RNG of what planets you find and what elements they hold. No combat, much of the fluff text from finding new systems has no consequence or choices, encountering life forms yield vocabulary words from alien if you are polite with them, which helps translate incomprehensible alien text over time. Good idea. Otherwise the game is mostly empty of other distractions or content. Gets repetitive and a tad boring but taking risks will almost certainly doom you, so only way to progress is to be conservative, take it slow, and mine everything you can for what you need and carefully packrat your cargo hold. That is all there is to this game.

The inventory management left me the most flustered. You need a ton of material for your cross-galactic journey and are constantly running out of space to carry your hard looted and randomly generated yields from drilling or probes, there are many types of materials and you cannot upgrade your ship without a collection of them, or even repair broken components.

I also found the galactic map hard to use as you cannot see past your ship's radius much, making plotting courses, or reaching quest-event hotspots more aggravating than it should be.

Conclusion: This is way too similar in mechanics to FTL. So I recommend you play the better execution in the original concept instead. The art was nice, the social aspect was nice and the game is somewhat relaxing without the combat but it just is too empty, hollow and repetitive to really warrant slogging through, especially once you have beaten the game once.
https://store.steampowered.com/app/212680/FTL_Faster_Than_Light/

author: {'steamid': '76561198301815890', 'num_games_owned': 306, 'num_reviews': 38, 'playtime_forever': 914, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 651, 'last_played': 1652854072}
review:
I got this game during the 2018 summer sale for a low price and it was very much worth it.

The game has amazing exploration, finding new aliens and having random events makes exploring the galaxy as we follow a great story incredibly interesting. The customisation of ships is an important part of the game and is part of what seperates skilled and unskilled players. I find it very exciting to play and I will sink many more hours into this game in the future.

Please be warned, the game is quite difficult and is not very forgiving.

author: {'steamid': '76561198031719573', 'num_games_owned': 104, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 2453, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2405, 'last_played': 1637084627}
review:
Great and very challenging game! Has a gigantic atmosphere and a well told story. If you like [b]Space[/b], [b]Exploring[/b], [b]Managing Resources[/b], encountering unforseen twists and are looking for a challenge this game is for you! 

Keep in mind though that this game is very random sometimes. For beginners, this can result in death very quickly, but you keep on getting better each round and find ways to prepare for unexpected twists!

There are different Missions you can complete, varying in difficulty.

author: {'steamid': '76561198067725186', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 49, 'playtime_forever': 698, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 698, 'last_played': 1524950406}
review:
It is an enjoyable game, but even playing on "easy" every game ends with me getting cornholed by the universe somehow.

After putting a bunch of colonists in a pocket universe attached to my ship for extra storage space, guess which module was damaged and lost all of its contents on the next turn... Yup, goodbye colonists.

I get to the "end" of the universe and can't jump to my goal as it is too far away. All  I need to make the jump is one ton of copper. I jump to over a dozen worlds, none of them have copper. Finally, due to random damage, I run out of iron and need to scavenge my engines to make a drill. Drilling gives me the needed copper, but not enough iron to rebuild the engines. Game over.

This game should offer a line of pillows. I could sit on them while playing to ease the damage it does to my bum everytime it fucks me.

author: {'steamid': '76561198300747804', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 250, 'playtime_forever': 1341, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 542, 'last_played': 1606854810}
review:
Intriguing and detailed space survival game.  The game combines sci-fi novel elements and has a rich story line.  There is no combat which is great as far as I'm concerned.  The game is composed of exploration, resource management, making choices in a wide array of random events, and gaining knowledge of a made up alien language.  There are several missions to complete so you can replay several times.  There is enough complexity in the game strategy to keep improving as you play.   The atmosphere is beautiful, desolate and strange.  The text elements convey a sense of a lonely wanderer in a vast alien universe.  The artwork and music are retro sci fi and very captivating.  I'd recommend to anyone who enjoys the sci-fi genre!

Hint: technologies that are based on others will work better if placed next to the base technology in the ship.

author: {'steamid': '76561198051546064', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 130, 'playtime_forever': 1432, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 789, 'last_played': 1667761269}
review:
I loved this game!
Its different and fresh. It has tremendous fun factor, there is plenty to this game. 
Its a space adventure game where you struggle to keep enough resources to survive, you gradually accumulate technology and develop your ship. 

I think there was a Dr. Strangelove reference embedded in a technology!

Totally recommend this game at full or sale price for a great developer based in France.

author: {'steamid': '76561198006526801', 'num_games_owned': 471, 'num_reviews': 42, 'playtime_forever': 412, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 412, 'last_played': 1524344785}
review: Way too repetitive. Feels like it has way more content than it actually does, and mostly just boils to an endless loop of jumping to the next system and hoping you get enough fuel. It's FTL without the combat, or anything else interesting going on.

author: {'steamid': '76561198047637890', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 106, 'playtime_forever': 4399, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1491, 'last_played': 1670904104}
review:
Kind of a precursor to "The Long Journey Home" by Daedalic Entertainment, but with more luck than skill to solve it, though good decision making especially resource-management a must.  

The main design flaw I find in the game is that the stuff acquired from drilling or probing cannot be used for refueling/repairing "Fuel, oxygen, or hull" that I could figure out...so it seems alot of resources are wasted, especially if you have so many resources already.

Swapping ships is crucial to the game, but be warned that some ships are woefully fuel hungry, leaving you stranded, even though they can jump further, unless you are assured of a gas giant, every couple jumps.

I enjoy this game alot, though I have yet to finish it...and sidequests can vary a lot...and can even extend the game or divert the game from the main initial goal.

I found this game by way of FTL recommendations.

author: {'steamid': '76561198205241445', 'num_games_owned': 71, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 408, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 408, 'last_played': 1523933577}
review: Many people recommended this game as like FTL but more narrative driven and without combat.  While this is accurate, the narrative is barely more interesting than FTL's and combat is replaced by a repetitive resource mining game.  In fact, the pattern of mining for fuel, jump, mining for fuel, jump etc is most of the game.  It was fun for a bit, but im glad i got it on sale for 5$. Played it for one afternoon and then got bored.

author: {'steamid': '76561197994365694', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 160, 'playtime_forever': 25, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 25, 'last_played': 1523826968}
review:
People think this game is a copy of a game called FTL but actually the "original" game of this style (as far as I'm aware) is a German board game called Starship Catan so you could say that both this and FTL where "inspired" by Starship Catan.

Regarding "Out There" well... it's a rogue-like so if you're a fan of the genre you'll probably enjoy it and if not you'll be bored after the 1st or 2nd try.

Worth it for fans if discounted or found on a bundle.

author: {'steamid': '76561198188013223', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 34, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 34, 'last_played': 1522945723}
review:
I played this game on my Kindle about 2 or 3 ago and really liked it. Unfortunately I can't recommend this game as it is right now on PC because it's unplayable. The mouse click do not register after entering the game making it impossible to play. This has a game breaking bug that seems to have been known by the community for a while. 

Until the developers fix the bug that disables mouse clicks, I can't recommend this game to anyone. I'll update this review when they fix the bug. Until then DO NOT BUY!

author: {'steamid': '76561198036375614', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 44, 'playtime_forever': 13, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 13, 'last_played': 1522298633}
review:
Disclaimer: I have played 6 hours or so of this game. I played it offline when the internet was down which is why it says I have played a lot less. Check my achievements.

I Have to say im disappointed with this game. It offers some promise but ultimately boils down to a resource management game. The language thing is quite cool. It in fact it has a lot of the same mechanics as No Man‚Äôs Sky. Both in how you pick up words for alien language and the fact that the core of the game is mining for resources to survive the next jump. Its a bit of a grind

Even with the grinding the does not seem particularly long really showing the lack of content. To stretch the playtime further the game ends on completing one of the quests. This is frustrating as there is no warning. On my last playthrough, I had reached a point that I could easily complete two other quests and I was pretty disappointed to find out that I will have to play again to that point to find out how the other endings would have gone. If the general gameplay was fun that would be fine. But the gameplay is just about adequate to keep you going with some music or a podcast in the background. A decent time waster for that. For a mobile game its perfect, a good way to twiddle your thumbs and a decent loop mechanic in discovering the next system, but for a laptop release, it was just a bit lacking with many far better options in the market. 

Pros:

- Good selection of ships. All the ships are well designed and play a bit differently. They are not 'made equal' though and some are far more viable than others. But it was always a pleasure finding a new design to try out. The way the ships would use different resources was a nice trick as well. Oxygen can be used as fuel? Nice! Not so nice when your ship hull needs a rarer metal to fix though!

- The upgrades are well balanced in terms of resources to buy and do feel good/rewarding when you get them. 

- The alien system was a nice idea and fun at first. I liked learning the language.

- Nice premise for the storyline. With decent lore that you have to uncover as you go along.

Cons:

- Feels a little RNG heavy. If you get no gas giants three warps in a row you are in a bit of trouble. Unless you have got the right tech

- Repetitive gameplay. All the solar systems are basically play the same. Occasionally you will find something but not enough events and discoveries to be worth it

- A lack of depth. Both in gameplay and upgrades. A few more would be good. Doesnt make it warrant repeated playthroughs. The absolutely key thing to get right in rougelike and rouge-lite  games 

-Just does not offer enough for a game at its price range. You can find better, more detailed, and in-depth games at half the price. 


Overall it just doesn't have enough to it. None of the ideas here are particularly fresh and the world isn't immersive enough to get away with it. Its much of muchness. But its a fairly competently made game and a decent time waster if you have got it free or in a bundle. The devlopers new game Sigma Theory looks potentially interesting. I hope the developers have learnt from this game and will grow and gain confidence in their future projects. Would have liked to see a bit more ambition here! 

As for people looking to buy it. I would look elsewhere. FTL is better if you want a large number of build and ship designs. If you want a space adventure game and dont mind a bit of a grind try Infinite Space. If you want to give it a go fine but remember this is a resource management game, and an only slightly above average one at that.

author: {'steamid': '76561197984230894', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 25, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 25, 'last_played': 1519693817}
review:
I love space exploration, I love text based games, I love roguelikes and I love games with quiet, lonely atmospheres (I'm one of those weird people who enjoys games like 7 Days to Die and Ark when I'm playing them by myself as a sole survivor), so with Out There being something that incorporates all of these why don't I love it too?

Because, sadly, it's not a very interesting game and it's mechanics wear thin very quickly.

I can appreciate that they intended for limits on things such as fuel and oxygen to immerse the player and give them feelings of dread, tension and despair but it just turned what should have been an enjoyable journey through the stars into a neverending test of luck to keep your bars full ending either with reaching your destination or the game screwing you over and deciding that oxygen is obviously something only an evil Communist would ask for (and then giving you a wordy 'YOU DIED' screen).

In the trailer and other reviews I see other people praising the game for 'not being violent' (ignoring the fact that death by asphysxiation/explosive decompression is pretty damn violent) but I don't think that dedication to non-violence really did much for the game, in fact, it only really compounds the shallowness of the mechanics by cutting off what could have been another avenue for your journey to take if you should so wish (or should misfortune fall upon you). I have no issue with a game deciding to not include violence or combat based mechanics but this also means that there should be something to fill the void that combat otherwise would have filled (something I don't think Out There really delivers on).

The artwork is very beautifully done and the animation is excellent for what kind of game this is but those just push my summurisation of this game to be a case of 'style over substance'.

author: {'steamid': '76561197980091650', 'num_games_owned': 381, 'num_reviews': 79, 'playtime_forever': 232, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 218, 'last_played': 1531022660}

author: {'steamid': '76561198069730783', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 823, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 823, 'last_played': 1510281182}
review: So disappointing.  If you like a challenging game based on RNG go play Darkest Dungeon.  I was so into this game when I first bought it.  Cool lost in space and time storyline/premise.  Descent survival mechanics.  Weird alien life.  Just a fun Sci-fi survival.  However, after my 6th death or so (including a fantastic streak of what I realize now was absolute pure luck followed immediately by devastating losses) it hit me like a ton of bricks; it's just terribly easy to end up in situations where no amount of planning, strategy or resource hoarding can help you succeed.  Why?  Because everything you do is random.  End up in three systems in a row with no oxygen, you die.  Three in a row with no iron, dead.  Three in a row with no Hydrogen or Helium... you guessed it, so very dead.  To sum up, any sort of fun or strategy is laid to waste by the dreadful and literally random game mechanics in which this game is based.

author: {'steamid': '76561198043512270', 'num_games_owned': 803, 'num_reviews': 36, 'playtime_forever': 1523, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1523, 'last_played': 1502964921}
review: I enjoyed first few playtroughs, but it got repetitive fast. There isn't much to do in this game, get resources>move to other planet>get resources>repair/refuel>move the other planet and so on, till you get to the ending planet. This game depends too much on RNG, especially early game, but even late game, when you are prepared for every scenario, you still can get screwed with few unlucky rolls. Comparing it to FTL is a joke, because this game has no replayability, and the only reason why I have 25 hours played is because I did 100% all achievements(and I regret doing it).

review:

- Multiple ways to die, kind of.
- Requires logic and strategy.

Cons:

- Apparently I'm too dumb 'caus I can never finish this game.
