author: {'steamid': '76561198027315434', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 356, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 342, 'last_played': 1552822700}
review:
Out There is more like doing Russian roulette with some awkward resource micro-management than playing a game.

The "gameplay" is driven by a random number generator which seems to be completely unbalanced. Because of this it's not possible to plan or prepare for anything so unless you are extremely lucky, you'll die very soon -- needless to say, you cannot load a previous saved state to try something else, you can only restart. Perhaps there is a mathematical chance for the events to unfold in a way which would let you progress so that you could employ some strategy eventually, unfortunately I don't have any illusions about it and can't say I'm enjoying my time with this game.

If you wish to experience Out There without spending any money, just follow these simple rules:

* Roll a 6 sided dice.
* If the result is 1, you can roll again, otherwise you've lost, game over.

If you had fun with the above "demo", definitely go ahead and buy this game, you won't be disappointed.

review: Been playing this for a very long time since the mobile version and probably only finished it only three times ever since. Recently finished it by figuring out how to effectively collect resources and managing inventory. The richest resources become redundant once you know your ship is outfitted enough to get you to the end which is having a high quality probe, drill, telescope and the upgraded space folder (I think the tau stasis is the one that upgrades it) then you're all set. all you have to do is farm for fuel, iron and oxygen on your way to the end. unless well, you meet an unfortunate event that permanently destroys your technology and erases it out of your memory.

author: {'steamid': '76561197971115936', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 57, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 57, 'last_played': 1514258396}
review:
The mouse control stops working after the first menu. I have a touchscreen laptop, but some non touchscreen users have reported the same problem. I have found posts about this problem dating back to 9 months.

It's a shame because I like the game, but buyers should be warned that the game requires a touchscreen. This should be made clear on the store page.

author: {'steamid': '76561197971942916', 'num_games_owned': 358, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 357, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 357, 'last_played': 1513450134}
review:
I would describe the gameplay as minimalist. There are no fast paced action parts, although running out of fuel and oxygen can still get very nerve wracking. This game is a good example on how you can create an enjoyable space exploration game with only a very simple core loop. You jump from star system to star system trying to find resources to fuel your craft, repair it, oxygen to breath etc to keep going on your journey. Every action takes a certain amount of resources (fuel and oxygen most of the time). Ships, modules, items wise it of course it is deeper and more varied, but the core loop is still always this.

Overall I enjoy it and can recommend it with just one caveat. There is a constant pressure on finding resources, everything runs out very fast. There is never enough resources and never enough space on the ship etc. Which means due to RNG you quite often do not get far in the game at all.

Personally I'd enjoy the game a bit more if it were a bit more relaxed, ships had more room, landing took less fuel etc. Would be the perfect nice calm game to relax with. But I understand this is a matter of taste and I've still enjoyed this game quite a bit.

author: {'steamid': '76561197966974971', 'num_games_owned': 155, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 199, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 199, 'last_played': 1508801054}
review:
I love this game! Music, the visuals and gameplay. I only discovered this after someone had written online to try this instead of No Mans Sky. I have played NMS, but did not enjoy that, and they have taken a lot from this game!

I have completed all of the 4 endings, really enjoyable, not too hard. Easier then FTL to compare it to something.

author: {'steamid': '76561198013865579', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 94, 'playtime_forever': 560, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 560, 'last_played': 1509920801}
review:
The tree ship which allows you to use carbon as fuel is by far the best ship in the game. One strategi I started using when mining for fuel was to start just at lv 5 mining then go lower and always end with doing alot of lv 1 mining until all was out. mining lv 1 cost 1 fuel and you always get at least 1 H which gives you 2 fuel. :)
The bad things about the game for me at least is that I started getting bored towards the end and also I got frustrated that doing one of the 4 objectives ended the game. I did not know that, So after doing one of them I just looked the other endings on youtube.

author: {'steamid': '76561197987500240', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 30, 'playtime_forever': 1043, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1043, 'last_played': 1539410104}
review:
Finally getting to this game and I couldn't stop. This roguelike wants you to reach the other end of the galaxy as resources are scarce, enemy aliens abound, and the universe itself is uncaring. 

Every ship you send out with the hope you'll run across a new event to spit you out farther in the universe or find a derelict alien craft with precious technology or resources. Maybe you'll even find one of your own ships from a previous attempt. 

The music is great as well, which helps you forget how much time you're going to spend trying to get one (or all) of the 4 endings.

author: {'steamid': '76561197991329661', 'num_games_owned': 941, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 1067, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 660, 'last_played': 1579235789}
review:
I got this game on a recommendation, and didn't play it for a while.  I've got to say it sat on the shelf far too long.

This game is a short, focused masterpiece of immersive gameplay.  The exploratory element, continuous risk, emergent gameplay are all superb, and the whole thing hangs together in a narrative that seems at odds with its procedurally generated nature.

Playing this game is a lot like being lost, alone, in a distant galaxy, struggling against all odds to stay alive; but not without purpose or direction.  There is always a goal, whether the micro-goal of not dying on the next jump, or the macro-goal of discovering what exactly is going on out here, anyway?  The fabulous soundtrack only adds to the experience.

Anyway.  As I said, it's a masterpiece of short fiction.  You'll probably only get 10 or so hours out of it, but they will be very rewarding hours.

author: {'steamid': '76561198019715411', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 172, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 172, 'last_played': 1509860678}
review:
this game would be a lot of fun if the RNG weren't so abysmally lop-sided. I have yet to get past even 12 systems playing on the easiest difficulty and trying multiple strategy ideas. There is no strategy. there is no skill. It's just an RNG simulator with pretty backdrops in space for a few frames, then you die.

It's probably best to save your money and download some jpegs of pretty alien worlds, put them on a slide-show while playing space-themed music, and roll some dice. Remember: if the dice land with any numers facing up, you lose automatically!

review: Absolutely terrible game. Great premise, but the randomness means that you could be having a great playthrough, until a random event happens that destroys all your fuel, or all your oxygen. Essentially there are random "Lose instantly" events that happen and there's nothing you can do about it. You essentially just travel from planet to planet gathering fuel and hoping that you don't instantly lose. Not fun at all.

author: {'steamid': '76561198036811612', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 259, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 167, 'last_played': 1513052283}
review:
I wanted to like this game. I love space! Sci-fi! Awesome!

But I can't recommend it, however. It seems the game has a few too many defects/bugs the developers aren't key on fixing, and one of these bugs hit me pretty hard when I was playing the game.

Here is the defect: when you have too many items, you literally cannot scroll through them. Items are left "off screen" - but viewable enough that you see them - yet you can't access or view them. Let that sink in. A huge failure in even basic UI.

Can't recommend until this title gets some love from its developers.

author: {'steamid': '76561197971523424', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 747, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 203, 'last_played': 1684816953}
review:
Beautiful artwork and a fantastic soundtrack.  I got this game on sale for less $4 on a steam sale and I couldn't be happier with the purchase.  The gamplay is really simple, just click on the different actions/responses you want to take.  The game essentially comes down to managing your resources, you need fuel, air and iron to continue on your trip.  Along the way you'll gather other resources that will let you buld components from technologies you've learned.  As you explore, while it's mostly free roam, you will occassionally encounter a scenario where you are provided with a destination that will add to your story.  Each game is unique because of the procedurally generated maps.

It's not a deep or complex game, but it is challenging (though not overly difficult) enough and there are enough suprises to keep you engaged.  The artwork and soundtrack add to it and make this game a pretty engrossing experience.

author: {'steamid': '76561198119716509', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 692, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 646, 'last_played': 1612144880}
review:
Un juego excelente para todos los amantes de las historias espaciales y el descubrimiento.
Parecido a FTL, este juego simple y ligero esconde una historia entra√±able y excitante, donde pondras a prueba tu mente para organizar tu invetario y seguir vivo un d√≠a m√°s.

Un juego que te har√° pasar horas tratando de encontrar las respuestas a universo que estas explorando, que te har√° asombrarte por sus buenos ambientes y dise√±o de personajes.

Es un juego que se puede terminar en un s√≥lo d√≠a, si es que tienes suerte, o que puede tardas semanas, todo depende de que tanto quieras conocer el universo y la historia que se te presenta.

La verdad lo recomiendo mucho, ya sea que lo consigas por descuento o lo compres a su precio normal, te aseguro que no vas a desperdiciar tu dinero, claro, si es que disfrutas de este tipo de juegos, si no, dale una oportunidad a este ;).

author: {'steamid': '76561198030521658', 'num_games_owned': 94, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 679, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 649, 'last_played': 1505944895}
review: After playing FTL I came across Out There. This exploration/resource management game lacks the combat components FTL has. For me, this wasn't a let-down. Out There is a challanging but soothing game with excellent atmosphere and enough diversity in events and gameplay. It's pretty rough in the beginning but once you get the basics down it becomes quite enjoyable.

author: {'steamid': '76561198083824217', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 129, 'playtime_forever': 88, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 88, 'last_played': 1502890884}
review:
Les satellites joviens, un voyage paisible, un travail sans encombres pr√®s de la grande Ganym√®de, c'√©tait un jour d'exploitation mini√®re comme un autre jusqu'√†...

Le module de cryog√©nisation activ√© apr√®s de p√©nibles heures de minage, vous vous √©tendez pour vous ressourcer lorsqu'un signal se met √† retentir quelque heures plus tard.

Il se passe quelque chose d'√©trange car √©videmment vous n'√™tes plus sur Ganym√®de, mais √† proximit√© d'un √©norme cube de l'espace.
Par quelle technologie inconnue avez-vous pu √™tre transport√© l√† ? 
Peut-on vraiment emprunter un pont EPR ? 
Qu'est-ce-qui a bien pu arriver √† ce vaisseau flottant perdu, d'une envergure de montagne avec un corps d'aigle ?

De nombreuses questions se mat√©rialiseront dans votre esprit mais fier d'√™tre ce que vous √™tes, vous continuerez votre √©pop√©e pour rencontrer la vie ou non...

-Nomad mon fid√®le destrier, ouvre-moi cette voie pav√©e de miasmes cosmiques hostiles et dirigeons-nous vers cette structure innommable √©tincellante. 
Je sens des r√©ponses, je r√©soudrai cette √©nigme cosmique, au p√©ril de ma vie.

"RPG" gestion - espace - √† la FTL, aux d√©cors intersid√©raux somptueux.

author: {'steamid': '76561197993299536', 'num_games_owned': 378, 'num_reviews': 46, 'playtime_forever': 209, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 36, 'last_played': 1502449284}
review:
It plays a lot like FTL but focuses more on exploration so it's pretty chill. It feels like a mix of No Man's Sky and FTL minus the combat.

I can see why people would get frustrated at this game. Discovering new tech, lifeforms, and planets is satisfying, but In the end it's technically RNG. The strategy is all about priorities. It requires good inventory management. You have to balance the collection of rare resources to build new tech, space in your ship, and vital resources like fuel and oxygen. You have to judge when it's best to invesigate and land on planets and do random events vs. just moving on, ignoring everything except vital resources and then racing towards the end until you have to slow down because of bad luck, then possibly adding or replacing tech because you get a new ship or discover something worth taking time to craft. It creates a nice cadence.

The story is pretty good. Each time you get to a new solar system there's a random event. Sometimes it's choices you can make, but other times it's just story elements about what you as the character are going through being in such desolate isolation for months, even years depending on how long you take, and how your sanity begins to degrade. You start hallucinating, stuff like that.

If you have a really good run, the game is beatable in as little as 2 hours start to finish, but it would be incredibly rare to finish in a single run the first time around. I've only beaten it once so am not sure if there are multiple endings, but the one I got was satisfying.

It has a fair amount of replayability as well. For $10 I think it was worth it.

C'est une succession de tableaux, toujours les m√™mes grosso merdo mais pourtant on s'acharne √† progresser, √† d√©velopper une strat√©gie, √† tracer sa route d √©toile en √©toile. author: {'steamid': '76561197999313733', 'num_games_owned': 186, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 1298, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 684, 'last_played': 1570251210}
review:
This game is a totally different game from FTL. FTL has just one single objective and one single ending.
This game has different objectives, no crew management, alien languages to learn and multiple endings. It is a unique game and really well implemented.
Yes, it is hard, and you will get punished for your mistakes.
If you want to compare this game to any other game, It reminds No Man's Sky, if no NMS was a good game.

Une belle exp√©rience de jeu, qui peut s'appr√©cier par petites sessions ou en longues parties (ou successions de parties). 

A vrai dire j'ignore si je serai capable un jour de le finir vu que ce n'est pas bas√© sur les skills du joueur mais vraiement sur des rencontres al√©atoires... C'est assez culott√© comme syst√®me de jeu. J'adh√®re. ;)

author: {'steamid': '76561198005705060', 'num_games_owned': 682, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 106, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 106, 'last_played': 1500216033}
review:
It's another game in the style of FTL and Weird Worlds, but this one has a bad interface that requires too much clicking and screen swapping to do simple things.

And it has a towers of hanoi style inventory management system, which forces you to keep swapping items around so you can use them, because you can only build using items in your hold.

Graphics are nice, but gameplay is not.

author: {'steamid': '76561198031314461', 'num_games_owned': 646, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 247, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 15, 'last_played': 1558210387}
review: Leider ein reines Trial- and Error- Gl√ºcksspiel mit hohem Frustrationsfaktor.

author: {'steamid': '76561197962017563', 'num_games_owned': 519, 'num_reviews': 32, 'playtime_forever': 1451, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 515, 'last_played': 1688685019}
review:
Die, because you are running out of oxygen or fuel, no planet with those things is around and every jump will bring you exclusively into systems without planets.

Die, because a random event just destroyed all your fuel or oxygen and no planet with those things is around.

Die after a random event sends you into a system that you can't leave, your jumpdrive can't make the distance to the next system. Or maybe it can, then you will die, because all system you /can/ reach are completely void of fuel and oxygen.

Die, because you never get that new jumpdrive you need and can't go forward, while all the systems /behind/ you are now picked clean of fuel and oxygen.

I guess you get the gist by now. No matter how carefully you progress, no matter how closely you watch your resources, at some point you WILL die, simply because the RNG hates you.

author: {'steamid': '76561198210050417', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 36, 'playtime_forever': 69, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 69, 'last_played': 1490823582}
review:
Wouldn't recommend. Feels like something some talented people got together to make, but not enough effort was put into making the players decision feel important to make the runs entertaining.

At first glance it looks like a stylized FTL. But its a mobile/tablet game with not alot of content and it hides it well with a randomness that makes it brutally tedious to get far in. Unlike FTL, its not satisfying dying because you have significantly less control over your fate. FTL's risk/reward system leaves you reflecting on your decisions that lead you to die, in this game you will find yourself annoyed that you didn't get the resource you needed despite probing 20 planets and tearing your ship apart for it... in most every game. It sucks because the music is awesome and the stylised art is good too. But it gets boring fast. Maybe a little tweaking of the RNG would make it better or maybe that would just reveal more problems. Don't buy.

author: {'steamid': '76561197961046376', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 376, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 376, 'last_played': 1499540521}
review:
it has quite nice visuals but the game itself is just punishingly unfair to a degree that it is just not fun anymore.
I dont know how often you have to try until you make a successful run, but after 6 hours i never made it to the later game, always after 1-2 hours tops i would simply die out of bad luck. also there is no real progression you will always start with the same simple stuff over and over again. 
not recommended

author: {'steamid': '76561198063211496', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 398, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 300, 'last_played': 1536191268}
review: Despite the fact it has alot of good ideas and mechanics, the fact that its so punishing for being so short and having such abrupt endings really means i cant recommend it. Its cheap enough that its worth it to buy it, but it could do with alot of improvement

author: {'steamid': '76561198001614017', 'num_games_owned': 1165, 'num_reviews': 200, 'playtime_forever': 356, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 356, 'last_played': 1460335215}
review:
Game was initially somewhat enjoyable, but got old fast. 

Realistically, I really need to stop bothering with games that are ports from mobile. They almost always end up disappointing. I mean, I guess the real problem is figuring out that they *are* a port from mobile, since the devs almost never reveal that to be the case on the Steam page.

author: {'steamid': '76561197998156934', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 47, 'playtime_forever': 27, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 27, 'last_played': 1498898341}
review:
I don't really get what people say about the game having a problem with excessive RNG. In my - admittedly limited -
 experience I've encountered several problems but not an evil RNG...

What were my problems:
[list]
    [*]Fuel is EXTREMELY hard to come by and very difficult to procure.
    [*]The suns all say they are rich with fuel but there is NOTHING to do in orbit around them. The game simply lies to you!
    [*]The GUI often glitches, not letting you refill your oxygen or so.
    [*]Cumbersome interface to many clicks to do everything.
[/list]

Refunded.

author: {'steamid': '76561198120326155', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 2805, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 573, 'last_played': 1692926143}
review: I really wish there were some way to mark the star map with important locations, like (Hey, this is where I found the X) but otherwise, this game is addicting fun that always seems to have something new to offer just when you think it's all getting old.

review:
It's a fun little game.

while there is a lot of rng, once you work out how things work rng starts to be a nonfarctor and you can very consistently win the game. there will be plenty of moments of omg I run out of x resource while you learn how the game works, but once you do the game becomes quite easy.

author: {'steamid': '76561198066295007', 'num_games_owned': 415, 'num_reviews': 55, 'playtime_forever': 259, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 259, 'last_played': 1428532777}
review: Played it for a few hours and was having a great time once I got the hang of it, encountered a game breaking bug that caused me to get stranded on a planet with absolutely no way of continuing. I didn't run out of resources, no ship components were missing or broken or anything, my game was just bugged out and there was nothing in range of me even though I just traveled to the planet in my current ship. I didn't touch the game after that, hoping the dev would update the game to fix these issues that I have seen many others report. He never did. Never will.

author: {'steamid': '76561198103264863', 'num_games_owned': 1228, 'num_reviews': 94, 'playtime_forever': 5798, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1783, 'last_played': 1673904416}
review:
[h1]It's Tough Out There[/h1]

I remember playing the original Out There on my Android phone a couple of years ago, and when I saw this game come to Steam I was tempted to buy it again because it works well as a phone game, but isn't quite the pick up and put down fun I enjoy when I'm on the go.

Actually, this game is a little too deep for its original platform, but also almost little too simple for its own good.

Out There: Œ© Edition is about being stranded and not dying. You navigate 'Systems' which are typically a type of star (Yellow Dwarf, Supernova, Red Dwarf, and more), collecting precious resources to upgrade, fuel, and maintain your ship and yourself. Every jump to a new system begins with an event, whether it's a random encounter that gives you a choice, a random encounter that is just commentary, or a random encounter that will betray you and chance ending your journey.

It is a bit of an unusual game. Consider this a kind of Choose Your Own Adventure with a hard roguelike twist. Every jump can be a disaster that is totally out of your control, and you will probably hate your character intensely before you've finished your first four or five games. He's just awful. Sometimes he will do something that will not only damage your ship or cost you resources, but could even end your game, and there's usually nothing you can do but read the text describing what happened and why it's ended your journey.

And that, friends, is half the game right there; random nonsensical, painfully awful circumstances. This game will punish you, even when you're doing well, and if you're not doing well it will only punish you. Every jump can feel like walking into a pitch black room with no sense of what's in there, what will bite you, or where a hole in the floor awaits to trip you and break your leg. Out There: Œ© Edition isn't about winning, it's about eating shit and asking for seconds.

This is also where the game really shines.

Out there space is cruel, but if you are patient, careful, and the odds rolled favorably, you can go on, even if by a thread. You learn the value of every resource you get and it is always possible that your abundant oxygen reserves or buckets of fuel will run out in three jumps and end you. There are tactics I've used on my phone version, like finding a fuel beacon and using it as a 'tether' to keep me going as I scour all nearby systems for anything to help me along the way, but such tactics will not be enough.

This game depends heavily upon chance, and you will take quite a lot of those on the way. Halfway through the game you will even have a mandatory encounter that will cheat you, [i]badly,[/i] but you can recover, and even win. I've done it on my mobile version, I will do it here.

The music and presentation are great here, but the textures on the planets are awful. Obvious seams, and blur are problems that were evidently not dealt with before moving this game to PC. Certain other issues just feel lazy, like the way the tutorial stage instructs you to 'Tap' an icon rather than 'Click'. This smacks of being a lazy port, and for the price that's a pretty bad deal. There can also be some rather laggy load times, and the narration in the intro wasn't matching up to the subtitles. There were some sound effect issues, specifically a loss of quality from the original mobile version of this game.

My number one gripe has to be the ugly font. Seriously, it's an eyesore. I work in print and writing, certain fonts are actually easier on the eyes sheerly because of their 'weight' and kerning, and some fonts are infamous for being difficult, even causing eye fatigue to the reader. The font used in this game is awful, sharing some of the very dubious qualities that make Comic Sans a tough one on the eyes. The balance of the font, kerning, etc are worth addressing because of the sheer amount of reading involved with playing this game. I can appreciate wanting to go with something original, but the font here is atrocious. If it is at all possible I hope someone will write up a guide on how to change it. A clear serif font would be welcome, but even a crisp sans-serif would be an improvement.

I truly enjoy this game, and while I have a difficult time with some of the lazier aspects of the port from mobile, and the font, I still enjoy both the feel and the style of this very unusual, often brutal game.

[b]Pros:[/b]
[list]
    [*]Interesting concept
    [*]Great music
    [*]Potentially engrossing
    [*]High replay value
    [*]Never the same experience twice
    [*]Minor customizations for game play
[/list]

[b]Cons:[/b]
[list]
    [*]Horrid font
    [*]Unfair difficulty based on chance more than skill
    [*]Information about ship upgrades a bit ambiguous
    [*]Weak writing
    [*]Lossy graphic and audio quality
    [*]Not a very deep experience
    [*]Not enough customizations
[/list]

[b]Verdict: 6/10[/b]

A difficult game to recommend, definitely a work in progress and not worth the full asking price. If you go into it with an idea of how it plays and accept that the odds are against you it can really be a fun adventure despite its shortcomings.

Dies kann teilweise sehr frustig sein, macht manchmal aber auch Spa√ü.

Nach ein paar Stunden hat man alles gesehen und nur Freunde von Achievements werden hier noch Spa√ü haben.
Spiel macht ca 3 Stunden Spa√ü. Wer alle Achievements machen m√∂chte ist hiermit nach ca 15 Stunden fertig.

Die Story ist 08/15 und nicht erw√§hnenswert. (bis auf ein paar kleine Momente)

author: {'steamid': '76561198073327674', 'num_games_owned': 199, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 989, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 103, 'last_played': 1668552379}
review:
I've played this game for hours on my phone and when I found out it was on steam I had to buy it. It's a great game that does require alot of "grind" to be able to survive and make it to your goal. It's pretty difficult to manage your resources properly and you do need luck on your side for some situations. 

I know this review isn't in-depth but I would reccommend this game to anyone who loves astronomy and is looking for a game to play when you wanna chill.

author: {'steamid': '76561198048521710', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 807, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 807, 'last_played': 1493537372}
review:
This game has some interesting elements to it, but I can't recommend it for two reasons.

The first is that while there is a little skill involved with managing one's resources, in the end it all comes down to luck. You can be carrying as much fuel and iron as your ship can carry and still get screwed because you hit 10 systems in a row that don't any fuel. It's really irritating to have been playing for over an hour and have your game suddenly end this way.  It doesn't matter how well you prepare or what ship you are flying. Also, your success or failure largely depends on deciphering the alien language in order to get new tech. This is also a random process where you simply guess at the meanings of words until you get lucky enough to figure some out.

The second reason I don't like it is that is that on the rare occasions when things are going well, it's repetitive and boring. Fly to new system, probe for fuel, land on garden planet to refill oxygen and communicate with aliens, fly to next system, and repeat....  Throw in the occasional ship change and drilling for minerals and that's the whole game.  It gets old fast.....

If you want a better version of this type of game, try The Curious Expedition.

author: {'steamid': '76561198051083217', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 633, 'playtime_forever': 19, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 19, 'last_played': 1490487387}
review:
PROS:

Soothing ambient music.
Minimalistic, but good comic-graphics.
You actually really have to care about your resources...otherwise your jounry finishes pretty soon.
Nice Story.
No nonsense.


CONS:

No voice-acting...like the majority of Steam games...
I have no Pizza at home.



SUGGESTIONS:

I suggest to make it able to double click things instead clicking on them and then clicking for example "orbit". Slows things down unneccessarily.

review: A beautifully rendered game, with a great almost comicbook like atmosphere to its art direction. But in the best sense of that. It's gameplay mechanics are simple resource gathering and management, trying to build the right tools for the job, get the right ships, and just survive. In time, you might learn to thrive and make it to one of the endings, but at first it's better to focus on survival. Exciting wit ha lot of story depth, this could be considered a story rogue-like.

author: {'steamid': '76561198350347520', 'num_games_owned': 275, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 233, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 233, 'last_played': 1491504687}
review:
I am changing my review to positive because game stopped crashing and its stable and fun now :)

You are a lonely human lost in space by unfortunate turn of events.
Far away from home, farthest that has any human ever been you can only put trust into your wits, luck and..maybe, just maybe...your ship.
Events, misfortunes and fortunes that happen to you are like from the pages of golden age sf novel.
Everything happens at random and you cant be sure what can you expect on your next jump.
This game is procuderally generated rougelike, so no saving, expect one autosave when you enter a new system.
Your basic task is to find enough resources (fuel, oxygen, iron for hull) for you to keep going on system by system basis.
You can get different ships, and multitude of upgrades for your ship that make game interesting in their own way.
Appart from that, you encounter various forms of life, learn strange alien words, fly into black holes, have al kinds of encounters and experiences that had lighted up the pages and screens of science fiction for decades now.
But dont get me wrong, it isnt boring or "i have seen this before" feeling.
Its refreshing, coomic book like short events that really make the game interesting and vivid.
Writing is really good, concise but fun and interesting.
Music is good, a bit dreamy, just right for exploration of unknown vast space.
I havent got time to play it longer and explore more of Out There, but what i saw for now, i am sure this is going to be a game that ill pick up every now and then for 20 minutes, or an hour and make few jumps wondering what awaits me in the next system.
If you like golden age sf, if you like games that you can play while waiting for your wife to get ready same as play for horus at time...and you like procedurally generated rouge like exploration.... buy it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198167052960', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 33, 'playtime_forever': 1691, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1606, 'last_played': 1677920586}
review:
Ce jeu est formidable, mais il ne plaira pas √† tout le monde !

C'est un jeu d'ambiance et de gestion. Il est assez difficile, sauf pour les fous comme moi qui jouent avec un petit cahier et notent tout, m√™me ce que disent les Aliens !!

Ne serait ce que pour l'ambiance et la d√©couverte du jeu, si vous le choppez √† 5 euros, je pense que √ßa vaut le coup.

Mais attention : Il faut √™tre tr√®s rigoureux. Si tu joues bourrin, tu cr√®ves vite fait. 
Le jeu est assez r√©p√©titif au final. Tu vas en pomper de l'Helium !!! Mais comme l'ambiance est g√©niale, √ßa peut le faire pour certain.

Je regrette juste l'aspect un peu frustrant du manque d'espace sur le Vaisseau. C'est la base du jeu et ce n'est pas un concept tr√®s satisfaisant. Tu passes beaucoup de temps √† essayer de faire de la place sur ton vaisseau.

Mais malgr√© tous ses d√©fauts, c'est une exp√©rience ludique planante √† laquelle je reviendrai probablement de temps en temps !

author: {'steamid': '76561197970744075', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 45, 'playtime_forever': 234, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 234, 'last_played': 1487474892}
review:
Absolutely captivating. Simple game mechanics, a fun system I'd say would be comparable to FTL, with a similar chaotic touch of randomization to make it replayable. Though unlike FTL, lacking combat with others, but rather a system of choices. Learning languages, and how language structure works amongst the interstellar community. Captivating story, and somthing with a twist. The multiple endings offer different information to how the game world is composed, and can be achieved in different ways. Just try it- you might like it. Some times you'll be swearing, when everything was going so right- based on one bit of technology you had, which ends up breaking from somthing out of your control. Heartbreak. Yet... with cunning, you can get away with it.

Try the game.

review:
there should be a proper map of the galaxy system. Anything in this game wasn't helpfull at all, I haven't even found a tutorial. Instead of finding interesting places, most of my time is consumed by wondering were I am and worrying about my fuel, oxygen and the state of my hull, which seem to deteorate at an alarming rate. My ship seems to be made out of tinfoil.

the game doesn't run that well either. 


I'll see if it get's any better after some more hours.

author: {'steamid': '76561198082373954', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 394, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 298, 'last_played': 1506454061}
review:
It is very relaxing game, I like the idea although it is a bit difficult.
There are some rules if you follow them, your game is less frustrating so I suggest you to read the guides.  E.g.
* don't visit every planet just if you need it
* have spare fuel and oxygen
* drill depth, you might have valuable materials and Fe is cheap
* before drilling always fill up the oxygen and fuel tanks and make room for the valuable materials
* backup your save file if you made a good progress :)

author: {'steamid': '76561198119657021', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 50, 'playtime_forever': 1392, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 920, 'last_played': 1555859964}
review:
Nice game....IF you had a chance. Now after playing for awhile the best i have managed is getting to close to 20 systems then im out of resources, nomatter what and how i have done it, and this was on easy setting!!!
The game is too hard as you need to use too much resources and/or find too little of them when you search for them.
I actually were about to quit the game some time back, because of the hardship, but i thought that this coudnt be right, so i kept playing the game, changing tactics and so on, but no matter did it help, so now i am over the time where i can get refund through Steam, i am hoping for a nice good patch, because it is badly needed if the game is gonna keep having the price it have on Steam.

author: {'steamid': '76561198053535654', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 131, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 131, 'last_played': 1485671888}

author: {'steamid': '76561197983740996', 'num_games_owned': 746, 'num_reviews': 180, 'playtime_forever': 1433, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1121, 'last_played': 1486073453}
review:
You awake blinded by colours, shining from the armatures in your space ship. As you emerge from your cryo sleep chamber you realise something is wrong, very wrong. You were on your way to Ganymede, one of Jupiter's moons but you awake in an unknown area of space, far away from the solar system. What's going on?

'Out There' puts you at the edge of the galaxy without help or guidance to find your way back to earth. This however, is a difficult task. Find a way to remain sufficient amounts of oxygen, fuel and steel for hull repairs as you conquer the stars on your long way home.

You can learn to play 'Out There' in three minutes but it will take you many hours to master the game. The game is tough on 'easy' difficulty, leave away 'normal'. But the game is also addictive. You want to continue, moving deeper and deeper into the unknown, continuously revealing pieces of the story that led to your current situation. And every time you die - and you will die - you instantly feel the urge to try again. 

Given the fact that 'Out There' is a very simple structured game, it's astonishing how much fun it can be. But be aware, 'Out There' is a strategy game. You need to learn the rules of the game in order to outmanoeuvre it. This is not a simple indie game that you can beat in a couple of hours. It takes patience and learning in order to beat this game. 

Pros:
- nice graphics
- good music that supports the atmosphere
- mysterious
- addictive
- high replay value
- alien language changes every time you restart
- very interesting game concept
- interact with alien races
- learn their language
- learn new technologies
- find and board new ships
- expand your technologies
- terraform planets
- destroy entire solar systems and create worm holes
- travel through black holes

Neutral:
- only one save file, but that's intentional and fits the concept of the game

Cons:
- gets repetitive after a while

author: {'steamid': '76561198048035257', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 1985, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1441, 'last_played': 1488760695}
review:
What I like:

* nonviolent yet draws you in
* exploring, upgrading

What I don't:

* 90% of all game-losses being due to running out of gas or orbiting a gas giant to gas up and your 30% remaining hull hitpoints not being good enough to weather the mad damage of orbiting t3h gas giantz.
* The rare moment I thought I'd gotten lucky and found an awesome ship with a ton of space only to scuttle everything on my old pretty good one for upgrades and then discover that it cost twice as much gas to make a jump.
* Copy editor. Get. A copy. Editor.
* When there's no violence and it's a sci-fi game, you really need to stay on top of the science. If the time-distorition consequences of relativity are somehow relevant to a folding engine which basically bends space rather than accelerates stupidly to almost the speed of light, dude, you need to explain that.

author: {'steamid': '76561198037043596', 'num_games_owned': 1279, 'num_reviews': 64, 'playtime_forever': 657, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 657, 'last_played': 1452353780}
review:
Simple, nice and original gameplay. 

The fun fact is, IMHO, that [url=http://store.steampowered.com/app/275850/]No Man's Sky v1.0[/url] basically copied the gameplay - ship storage system, same principle with basic chemical elements, mechanic learning alien languages.

So in the end... It's great idea if it gets copied so soon :)

author: {'steamid': '76561198024792500', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 61, 'playtime_forever': 2300, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1291, 'last_played': 1606999253}
review:
Playing Out There was a lot of fun. Sure, the mechanics aren't the deepest out there, and with 20 hours to see everything the game has to offer, including all achievements, the game doesn't exactly last an eternity either.

But for as long as there's new stuff to explore Out There is a pretty darn fun game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198035779393', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 1487, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1071, 'last_played': 1488666281}
review:
I will leave my initial review in place, below, but I think it would be appropriate to update my review after finishing the game a couple of times.

While I still recommend the game, it gets repetitive much faster than a game like FTL.

A "full win" (of exploring the entire galaxy) can take a solid gaming-day, so you'll get your money's worth, if you intend to pursue all of the possible endings.

But unless you are interested in pursuing a high score via better play, "winning" is easy enough serious players of the Rogue genre won't replay the game much after they finish the Achievements.




[INITIAL REVIEW]

This is a well designed space-themed rogue-like that takes on the opposite concept of FTL.

Where FTL focuses on faster-paced ship management during combat (and crew management, as well), Out There goes for slower-paced exploration and cargo/space management (where you never have enough space to do everything you want to do).

The solar system exploration sometimes feels like a "solo run" of a game like Master of Orion 2 or Ascension. (a good thing)

And the ability to "manage a fleet" of derelict ships is an interesting feature that opens up a range of strategies for winning the game.


A little more forgiving cargo management would have made the game less frustrating.
But it is definitely winnable and balanced, as is.

Definitely worth playing for fans of rogue-likes, or even space-based 4X games.

author: {'steamid': '76561198033995360', 'num_games_owned': 2161, 'num_reviews': 441, 'playtime_forever': 776, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 776, 'last_played': 1484445784}
review:
Au tout d√©but, Out There fait plut√¥t bonne impression. Et puis les choses se g√¢tent. Son interface n'est pas belle, on atteint trop vite les limites de son gameplay (en environ six minutes), ses runs sont trop al√©atoires et ses p√©rip√©ties ne sont pas toujours bien √©crites. Un comble pour un clone de FTL qui a pr√©f√©r√© en troquer les phases de combat contre davantage de lignes de texte.

Pourtant, apr√®s avoir r√¢l√© contre une malchance de trop et insult√© les dieux √† quatre ou cinq reprises, le chat du voisin et sa souris d'ordinateur, on se promet que la prochaine tentative sera [i]la derni√®re pour ce soir[/i]. Evidemment, ce n'est qu'√† ce moment que les plan√®tes d√©cident de s'aligner. Relev√© d'un coup de pouce de ces m√™mes dieux qui nous torturaient la demi-heure pass√©e, on sautille de bonne surprise en coup de veine, fait le plein de ressources √† chaque escale et progresse plus vite et plus loin en un voyage qu'en quatre parties. Fascin√© par notre baraka, on fixe l'√©cran les pupilles aiguis√©es comme le bout du diamant d'un laser, on ne r√©pond plus qu'en [i]oui oui[/i] aux gens qui vivent autour de la chaise de bureau, trop occup√© √† croiser les doigts pour s'int√©resser au monde r√©el. Amoureusement, on d√©vore chacune de ces lignes qu'on ne faisait que survoler quand tout allait mal, on prend le temps de r√©fl√©chir au prochain clic de peur de tout g√¢cher en une inattention, on se passionne pour chacune de nos aventures qui tourne bien. Alors la musique, l'ambiance, l'histoire de cet homme qui a d√©riv√© si loin de son syst√®me solaire nous fascine. En un miracle seulement, le jeu qui √©tait si ennuyant est devenu addictif.

Out There est cette fille que vous avez pris le courage d'aborder. Si elle vous dit oui, elle pourrait devenir votre plus belle femme du monde pour les 5 heures √† venir. Sinon [i]d√©gage, saIope. Je t'ai jamais aim√©e et en plus t'es moche comme ta m√®re[/i]. S'il conviendra mieux aux amateurs de [i]gamebooks[/i] qu'aux fans hardcores de Faster Than Light, Out There a suffisamment de qualit√©s pour nous tenir √©veill√©s le temps de rencontrer cette chance n√©cessaire √† la r√©ussite. Aussi, son gameplay limit√© √† un clic nous assure de pouvoir tranquillement y jouer depuis une tablette Windows ou au [i]touchpad[/i] d'un vieux mini PC. L√©ger de 500 MB, pas gourmand en ressources, d√©pouill√© du stress des affrontements et donc jamais dynamique, il a tout du jeu d'appoint id√©al √† jouer sur des syst√®mes que vous ne r√©serviez auparavant qu'aux visual novel et jeux d'objets cach√©s.

Al√©atoire, d√©paysant au d√©but mais trop vite routinier, ce voyage intergalactique n'est finalement que l'histoire d'un trajet retour √† la maison : il peut √™tre grisant comme une autoroute de feux verts ou aussi exasp√©rant un soir d'embouteillages.

author: {'steamid': '76561198089922646', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 494, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'last_played': 1514047678}
review:
Quel jeu √©trange, envoutant, dramatique aussi, fataliste m√™me...
C'est avant tout un jeu d'ambiance, on choisi dans quelle direction de cette galaxie perdue on souhaite mourir, et si on a de la chance, ben on meurt finalement pas. Mais pendant ce temps, il se passe des choses dans l'espace, des choses √©tranges.
Un jeu auquel on accroche ou pas, tant il est hors norme. Il rappelera un peu aux plus vieux d'entre nous l'Arche du Capitaine Blood, mais en jouable ;) pour l'aspect exploration, et d√©couverte d'extraterrestres abscons.

A noter le travail particulier apport√© √† l'ambiance sonore, et aussi au visuel. Le budget d'un jeu ind√© impose forcement des contraintes de simplicit√©, ce qui parfois abouti √† un rendu un peu d√©cevant, ou, comme ici, on a droit √† un contournement de la contrainte par le haut, grace √† la cr√©ativit√© et au talent des graphistes. Le jeu est superbe tel qu'il est, fait de belles images en 2D.

Pour moi c'est une  petite perle ind√© comme on en voit passer de temps en temps, j'aime particuli√®rment ce genre l√†.

author: {'steamid': '76561197993410421', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 189, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 189, 'last_played': 1483539520}
review:
RNG at its worst. The story is great and I really do want to get to the end but after repeatedly losing because of a bad roll of the dice I can't continue. (Not being able to reach new systems and not having the tech to reach further is a non progression bug, randomly damaging both my methods of resource gathering and having no way to repair or rebuild them is a non progression bug.)
The game plays like a great choose your own adventure book where you roll a die after each page and if you get a 1 you burn the book.

author: {'steamid': '76561198097123761', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 6607, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 234, 'playtime_at_review': 3359, 'last_played': 1712447471}
review:
The artwork and the music of this game alone, beeing utterly beautiful, make this a game worth buying.
Art and music in combination with the story of many events you will encounter adds to the unique feeling of galactic eternal infinite loneliness this game is able to convey.
That aside it has some interesting game mechanics around ressource management, crafting and survival. While not beeing overcomplex it can most certainly be a challenge for most people in the beginning.
The only contra for me, having almost archieved everything in this game, is that there is not even MORE different events/technology/anomalies to discover. That is not to say this game doesnt feel satisfying as it is to me.
After playing some more i can say there are some bugs in this game, but not really gamebreaking ones, and the dev's have actually moved to fixed some over time, so i am hopeful. This doesnt change this review beeing favorable though.

author: {'steamid': '76561197976716282', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 369, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 369, 'last_played': 1483473748}
review:
It'd be nice if steam had a "indifferent" option instead of yes or no, oh well. Out There is an interesting game, it's all about space travel and resource management. There is a lot to see, and I want to see more of it... except, it's kinda hard to do just that.

This game has a tendency to screw you over with random effects. This game is filled with things that are determined based on RNG. It can be fine to do that for certain things in a game, but the more things that are determined by the RNG the more it compounds on itself. For example, early on in the game you're super pressed on space since your starting ship is fairly small in cargo space. So naturally the goal is to find a new ship, except, you need some much later game tech in order to see if there is a ship in a solar system before jumping there. This means that you can fly around for quite some time in the early game with no space to build all the fancy tech you find, nor the space to carry the resources for them.

There are also random events that happen as soon as you arrive at a new solar system. So as a kick in the gutt the game decided take all of my efficent fuel I had in my storage when I arrived at a star..., which had cost most of my fuel reserve to get to. The system in question is empty of any planets, it turns out. So I fly back to the last one which had a spare ship lying around. I get there and have around 0 fuel, that is to say, not enough fuel to orbit it. I try anyway and the game takes me to the screen where I orbit the ship, now at 0.... At this point you'd imagine I could just grab the other ship, right? I mean, that is what would make sense to me. But no, instead the game declears that I have lost since I have no fuel left, despite the fact that there are still valid moves left to do. This is incredibly frustrating, and the game should definitivly be able to do a better job at detecting it's own lose conditions. :/

Another time I lost after my second jump in the game, because the two systems gas giants decided to be the kind that provides you next to no fuel (basically at a loss for orbiting it). That was also quite nice..., not.

Basically, this game could be quite interesting, but the RNG just throws you around in a very non-compelling manner.

author: {'steamid': '76561198009847919', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 863, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 863, 'last_played': 1483400183}
review:
[b]Summary:[/b] I had my good fun with the game. While some parts are indeed tedious when you get to the 2nd+ playthrough. Now I'm off to question existence of life itself, as if I wasn't prone enough to such topics anyway. I should stop playing space games.

PS: When too much trouble, simply play on easy mode!


[b]Review:[/b] A strangely relaxing, throught-provoking but also stress-inducing game.

The written storylets are intriguing (and painful if you choose unfavorably) and set the overall atmosphere of not knowing what to expect. The colorful style and soundtrack help to make you feel curious about what's coming next, either with fear or with joy, depending on your situation.

The current 4 endings range from easy to hard(er) to achieve, all except one requiring a certain (combination of) tech to be used. Unlocking can be pretty hard sometimes, as gained tech is random (alien encounters, landing on rocky planets, events in new system) and for beginners, resource management is pretty harsh on normal mode, which makes it seem quite unforgiving. Also several techs are pretty useless and as such take up space which could be used for fuel, repair or more useful upgrades.

After the second ending though, to shorten my play time, I resorted to quitting the game when unfavorable events happened or I mined/landed on a planet with little resources, which reverted the save state to when you arrived at a new star system (also includes Alt+F4 when getting into bad events after travelling to a new star system, also reverts back to previous star system). I was surprised how often I had to quit to get the most favorable outcome, even more with the alien questions when you have no translated words available yet, making the tech collecting harder than needed.

author: {'steamid': '76561198017964932', 'num_games_owned': 1254, 'num_reviews': 44, 'playtime_forever': 24, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 24, 'last_played': 1480631574}
review: Touted as a "lonely, amospheric, single-player FTL" I was disappointed by this. You travel between stars in the hope you can find enough fuel to get to the next star. There's a crafting aspect which is ruined by the fact you don't get enough fuel so you can never carry enough materials, plus the tech tree is completely random so you can miss vital things for most of a playthrough, if you ever get that far, which you won't. RNGesus is not kind. Thumbs down from me.

author: {'steamid': '76561198020691011', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 412, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 206, 'last_played': 1482533749}
review:
Intriguing world but weak and non-satysfying gameplay

I really tried to like this game. Fine story, interesting world, nice graphics and music were all sucking me in. But gameplay really lacks. Controls and UI are clunky: it is easily recognisable that this is mobile port. It's rogue-lite but many deaths seem completely random without nothing I could do about it.

I can almost recommend it. Almost, but it still falls too short of a good game.

review:
M√™me si mon avis est positif, je pr√©f√®re pr√©venir : malgr√© d'ind√©niable qualit√©s, ce jeu comporte aussi d'important d√©fauts, parmi lesquels : 
-La r√©p√©titivit√© : une fois les m√©caniques de jeu comprises, le cycle exploration / carburant / r√©paration / oxyg√®ne devient un peu lassant tant la course √† ces ressources est r√©currente, et in fine gache un peu l'int√©r√™t de l'exploration 
-Les rencontres aliens : extr√™mement r√©p√©titives, peu inspir√©es, trop peu d√©velop√©es (tous les aliens parlent la m√™me langue ?)
-L'univers mis en place, bien que faisant l'objet d'un traitement int√©ressant, l'univers aurait gagn√© √† √™tre un peu plus d√©velopp√©. 
-L'absence totale de combats : m√™me s'il s'agit l√† d'un souhait des d√©veloppeurs (sans doute pour se diff√©rencier de FTL), l'absence de combats n'est pas totalement coh√©rence avec l'univers mis en place, ni les technologies que l'on trouve. 

Ma conclusion : 
13/20

Une suite qui am√©liorerait les √©l√©ments de gameplay, de technologie, augmenterait les rencontres, pourrait comporter une partie "survie du personnage" et des combats dans l'espace pourrait vraiment avoir un excellent potentiel !

review:

This game (unlike most rougelikes) doesn't irritate me when I die, I'm driven by what the last star could be. Very relaxing game, definatly worth the $10 investment. The tutorial is solid and teaches you everything you need to know. Definatly give this a try if you are bored and have $10 to use.

author: {'steamid': '76561198004261249', 'num_games_owned': 279, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 276, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 276, 'last_played': 1480700904}
review:
I've always appreciated FTL, but I find that I always bounce off of it after a little while. The combat elements take up a lot of time and I find them stressful (and being able to pause it and queue up actions? I'm unsure if it gives me less or more anxiety, honestly). What I did enjoy was charting a path through the stars with limited resources and running across random events in space - I loved the bits that felt lonely and isolated, in which I could really feel like an explorer.

Out There is pretty much just that part of FTL, but tuned and perfected. The resource management game is magnified to encompass the entire mechanical side of the game. Random and strange encounters are delivered in a steady drip through the whole experience. I find myself completely in love with the game - it does not frustrate or worry me like FTL does.

author: {'steamid': '76561198011947195', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 47, 'playtime_forever': 75, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 75, 'last_played': 1473267881}
review: Cool game. I like the animation and the music, sometimes it just feels like an artsy version of FTL.

author: {'steamid': '76561198045854843', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 1163, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 583, 'last_played': 1690165790}
review:
I don't tend to write reviews but play Out There has made me feel like in this case I should. I'm not actually writing this because it's an awful game, but neither am I able to say that it is a good one and due to the very on the fence nature of the thing, I can't help to say that this side more with the negative.


All the more so becuase you really real like there is something sratching away at the surface that could be great but it is never given the opportunity to shine. Ultimately that is the biggest sin of Out There, it feels like a game that was put together but never played through properly by those creative minds. I really like the idea of collecting elemnts that can be used to further your progress and status of your ship, but really all the different ships that you encounter for the most part are simply larger cargo holds to cram in more tat that you may never use. Admittedly there are the occasional different ways to fuel these ships but it isn't something that is really explored in-game, this makes parts of it are frustratingly mundane, but anyone who likes a rogue style game is more than aware that the micro management side of such properties is simply a part of the style of gameplay to one degree or another, but in playing this game you find yourself punished not for the choices you make but just the plodding on of your quest. 

There have been several playthroughs in which I have been forced to backtrack almost my entire journey back the way I came, usually just because of an upgrade that is missing or in some cases becuase you just cant go any further. All the more hair-pullingly frustrating becuase you can't zoom out of the starmap to anything other than your own current radius POV, even if you have already visited many places behind your route. lIttle things like this make for a real stalling in the gameplay and it creates that awful feeling of just having had enough of this trudgery, as does the fact that you don't seem to have any quick way of transferring cargo back and fore to your ship, all the more niggling when you are grinding single items at a time to squeeze the most fuel from probing stars and gas giants for your vital costly journies between systems.

If like me you manage to pick the game up cheap then I guess that it can be worth it, the artwork is certainly beautiful and it creates a nice atmosphere but for me this doesn't cover up the real flaws in the game, which frankly don't get any better when you do reach one of the few conclusions to the story and find yourself shrugging at the time wasted on a couple of exploratory dialogues and then promptly ends, asking you to do it all over again following some different, but achingly simlar route to another finale.

author: {'steamid': '76561198008361945', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 32, 'playtime_forever': 3888, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 914, 'last_played': 1693498522}

author: {'steamid': '76561197985137397', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 172, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 172, 'last_played': 1432248250}
review: Far far far too random, inventory type mechanics tedious, it's hard to know what's actually worthwhile to cart around, some story related things take up too much inventory space and it can be totally impossible to reach that ending anyway. The "learning language by individual words slowly" concept seems cool but you end up missing out on a lot of stuff and if you don't get lucky in learning the right words you'll never understand what the aliens want (and that's totally random, again). Some of the story and ideas are cool but randomness plays way too big a role, the decisions you do make aren't fun and you don't have enough knowledge to make decent strategies. Just too frustrating.

author: {'steamid': '76561198204178756', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 72, 'playtime_forever': 296, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 271, 'last_played': 1480205510}
review:
This game's art, writing, and music are all excellent. Unfortunately, the core game loop is weak, and there is no progress to be made from run to run, which i think will discourage most players into just giving up and moving on after a few hours of frustration. If you get lucky and find a ship with a ton of cargo space and can implement some upgrades, you can experience some of the game's superb writing and can maybe even achieve one of the game's endings. 

If you can get the game for less than $5, I think it's worth it to experience for a few hours, but otherwise there are more thoroughly developed experiences to be had elsewhere.

author: {'steamid': '76561197993928746', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 39, 'playtime_forever': 644, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 644, 'last_played': 1479935931}
review:
This is a game of resource balancing, unfortunately when I last played it, everything you did came with a cost. Pretty much e very resource you need comes at the cost of spending other resources. After a while you can get used to the proper balance of fuel/oxygen/other requisition, but until then it can feel like you are just postponing your death as you play rock, paper, scissors with resource gathering.

With that said, the game has a very interesting pulp sci-fi feel that makes the tedious gathering worthwhile.

review:

Si certains √©l√©ments font penser √† FTL (vue 2D du vaisseau pour voir les ressources, navigation par saut), il est pourtant tr√®s diff√©rent. Je dirais m√™me compl√©mentaire. Ici il n'y a pas de combat, non vous √™tes seul perdu dans l'espace, votre seul ennemi est l'espace et vous devez g√©rer vos ressources (tr√®s limit√©es) pour continuer votre voyage. Les √©venements al√©atoires (tr√®s bien racont√©s, et en fran√ßais) viendrons compliquer votre aventure. author: {'steamid': '76561198021742664', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 761, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 761, 'last_played': 1479344725}
review:
Tonally, this game is great, the artwork, writing and overall theme all work well, creating a distinctive and engaging atmosphere of loneliness and mystery.

Unfortunately, for me, the experience stopped there.  As a game, this simply does not work.  Options are limited and an impossible slide into defeat can only be turned aside by technological advancement, or stumbling across a new ship.  If you do that in a timely fashion the game changes from impossibly difficult to trivially easy.

A successful roguelike or roguelite can definitely tolerate some of the design decions present in Out There, the reverse difficulty curve of a tough start and easy late game can work well - just look at FTL or XCOM.  A heavy reliance on randomness is also not in-and-of-itself a deal breaker, so long as that random element can be mitigated through player knowledge and a transparent game mechanic.

Unfortunately Out There does not provide this mitigation.  Luck is luck.  If you need fuel and you don't come across a fuel source, you're done.  If you need a ship upgrade and the game doesn't decide to give you one, you're done.  There's no consistent and gradual accrual of resources, no ability to cut your losses when your choices aren't working out, you roll the dice and after 20 minutes you are told you're a winner or loser.

For me, that's not fun.

On top of that the game features a highly opaque resource management system that consists of micro managing whether you spend 1 to 10 fuel for an unspecified risk and unspecified reward when mining for metals or probing for gases.  This system doesn't provide player engagement, or meaningful feedback on how your choices work and how to improve them in the future.  It doesn't even provide basic informantion on the chances of success or failure.  Given the large amount of the gameplay that this mechanic constitutes, I found the complete lack of player engagement baffling.

author: {'steamid': '76561198043174699', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 2071, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1387, 'last_played': 1589640288}
review:
This game is great. After 21 hours play time, I just got one of the not bad endings... and felt disappointed I did not go on to the harder ones. But man, that felt great.

Epicly sucks you in with simple game idea and to be honest, the difficulty. Because it's so hard I was convinced there had to be a knack to it, and there is of course. It seems like there's no depth but getting good at it is hard.

Highly recommend if you're patient and like to die a lot, i.e. are a Rogue.

author: {'steamid': '76561198063621588', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 277, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 211, 'last_played': 1503219926}
review:
If you liked FTL you'll like this game.  Admittadely this game is hard just like FTL. If you are a whiney crybaby that cant stand to lose you're gonna have a bad time.  Learning from your mistakes and decision making are required to play this game. What sepperates this game from FTL is the immersive storyline, the artstyle and the lack of spacebattles (don't worry theres pletny of action). The music is amazing. Gameplay is amazing. Storyline is amazing.  10/10 would reccomend. This game needs to be signal boosted.

Coinceidentally it looks like Hello Games stole alot of ideias from Mi-Clos Studio

review:
Jeu bien sympa, quoiqu'un peu trop difficile m√™me en mode facile et √† force c'est vraiment chi... de ne pas progresser et de devoir toujours refaire les m√™mes √©tapes de d√©but de jeu.

Il ne manque pas grand chose pour que cela soit parfait, la consomation de carburant est trop pr√©sente et g√¢che le plaisir ... author: {'steamid': '76561198133803207', 'num_games_owned': 487, 'num_reviews': 76, 'playtime_forever': 136, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 136, 'last_played': 1480796280}
review:
"Out there: Omega Edition" est un petit jeu, que j'ai achet√© en soldes (comme d'habitude) √† <50% ou 75% de son prix faciale. 

Le caractere assez lyrique de ce jeu va bien ensemble avec une grande simplicit√© d'utilisation, mais qui demande neanmoins une certaine reflexion (notamment l'utilisation de l'espace de stockage des vaisseaux, le choix des ressources/am√©liorations, le choix des planetes visit√©s, etc.).  Dans le jeu il faut explorer les systemes extrasolaires, recolter differents ressources necessaires pour am√©liorer son vaisseau et pour survivre. Dans ce sens le jeu rejoigne toute la famille des jeux du "survival sandbox" de type "Don't Starve" ou encore RymdResa (bien que celui ci est beaucoup plus "arcade").

C'est un tr√®s bon jeu pour quelqu'un occup√© par la vie r√©elle, avec peu de temps, mais qui aime bien se plonger dans un monde different de temps en temps, sans pour autant investir beaucoup de temps dans la maitrise des m√©caniques du jeu. Le jeu m'a sembl√© reposante, avec une ambiance particuliere, agr√©able √† jouer, sans prise de tete et pourtant attirante pour en d√©couvrir plus.

Ce jeu est difficle par ses evenements al√©atoires, qui peuvent rompre une partie assez intempestivement. Graphiquement c'est assez simple mais suffisante, de meme pour les effets sonores.

Je l'a recommande ... surtout en soldes pour quelques euros.

author: {'steamid': '76561198053083938', 'num_games_owned': 417, 'num_reviews': 124, 'playtime_forever': 2109, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1160, 'last_played': 1580012498}
review:
tl;dr: A wonderful game, not just because it is great, but because it is filled with wonder.

Out There is a really good game in the rogue-like genre where most games in the genre are too tough and quite frankly bad. Often times too many games are fail simulators dependent on dice rolls loaded against you. This game, however, is fairer but can be tough at times.

The gameplay involves traveling from star to star and planet to planet picking up vital resources and new technology that improve your capabilities. Eventually you will need another ship and as a result will leave your old ship behind but the base components are pretty much the same. And this continues until you run out of a resource or meet some other untimely demise.

One of the best features of the game is the constant storytelling and worldbuilding. Each log entry, random event, and sentient life encounter enriches the gameplay experience. After 20 or so hours I'm still getting plenty of new stories and notes to be pleasantly entertained. 

Other features of note: good soundtrack, great artwork, and fun little choices here and there which can very loosely be called side quests.

I'd say this is a solidly good game with a definite yes recommendation for fans of scifi stories, rogue-like simulators, and survival-type games. I'd rate this a 8.5/10 and I consider myself a pretty tough grader.  

Last thought: I really want a sequel, and I want it yesterday.

author: {'steamid': '76561197978923182', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 52, 'playtime_forever': 230, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 214, 'last_played': 1477064225}
review:
Great little game. I¬¥ve only played 2 hours so far but i really enjoyed it thus far. Its like FTL without the fights and completly focused on ressource managment and exploring. What I personaly enjoy the most, is the story it tells you.



The gameplay is pretty minimalistic. Jump to a star, salvage the planets, use the salvage to keep yourself jumping. For some strange reason, I like the fact that there is no combat at all. Its relaxing, telling you a  story if you¬¥re willing to hear it. The only thing I dislike is the "roguelike" stuff, where you have to start over and over again, if you run out of fuel or something. I can imagine that I someday will be fed up with the beginning over and over again, but for now I want to see more of those little storys the game told me so far.


I bought it while it was on Sale for 5‚Ç¨. I can recommend it without a Doubt.

author: {'steamid': '76561198016663970', 'num_games_owned': 807, 'num_reviews': 38, 'playtime_forever': 521, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 92, 'last_played': 1580201972}
review:
My momma always said... "Space is like a box of chocolates. You never know what you're gonna get..."

This game is challenging and unforgiving.
Choices have to be made. And sometimes, you're gambling on the unknown.

In my games so far, I made friends with several races, learned new words and technologies, found humans in cryogenic sleep that I had to leave behind, had to abandon a good working ship for a more damaged one because I needed the fuel.

The game doesn't hold your hand and it doesn't guarantee a victory.
Just the way a game should be.

author: {'steamid': '76561198014443366', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 3780, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 524, 'last_played': 1711098797}
review:
This game hates me is what anyone playing it for a sufficiently long amount of time will think at one point.

However, it is not the case.


Roguelikes are a distinct category of games that are usually unfolding in a fantasy setting. Not over the past year, though. FTL was one of the first ones to become popular and albeit it's usually akin to self torture, the victory is all the sweeter.

I have played Out There on mobile first and when it came out on Steam I was keen on playing it again, this time luxuriously relaxing on my sofa with a Steam controller (or the wireless peripherals of your choice) instead of being hunched over a tablet or a phone.

It has retained the same principles - you're a dude, stranded in space. You need to make do with what you have and then what you harvest from the different planets you encounter. The resources are three - Fuel, Oxygen and Hull, each being replenishable. One of them hits zero. you still have a chance, but that's always a dice roll and I got lucky only once. Says a lot tbh. You can upgrade your ship and you can find and board (or plunder) other ships on your way. You discover technology, but you can also forget how to build stuff. You will meet alien races which have their own language and it's mesmerizing to actually get to discover almost a full language only to end up asphixiated at one point. Or adrift. Or blown up due to sailing too close to the solar winds (literally).

You can mine planets, gas giants, even suns. You can interact with black holes or even create one. You can bring life to planets by terraforming them, only to just chug along nicely to another part of the galaxy.

It is - in the end - a journey. A journey that can end several different ways, however what you feel when you see the credits rolling is that it isn't the end that matters. It's the journey itself.

11/10.

author: {'steamid': '76561197971451270', 'num_games_owned': 349, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 283, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 40, 'last_played': 1627935401}
review:
Llevaba tiempo sigui√©ndolo ya que me apetec√≠a vivir mi propia odisea espacial en mi viaje de regreso a la tierra. A nivel art√≠stico el juego destaca de manera especial. Gr√°ficos estilo c√≥mic muy mimados y con efectos resultones para representar la galaxia y los saltos estelares. Otro punto a destacar es la cuidada narrativa que te ayuda a meterte un poco en el universo.

A nivel jugable es donde m√°s me ha decepcionado. Me esperaba vivir una aventura, pero b√°sicamente es un juego de gesti√≥n de inventario: qu√© recurso extraer, cu√°ndo gastarlo y c√≥mo optimizar el espacio de carga de la nave. 

Valoraci√≥n: bonito pero vac√≠o. En ning√∫n momento me ha dado la sensaci√≥n de estar viviendo una aventura. Salvando las distancias, me ha aburrido tanto como Reigns; o el c√≥mo hacer el cuento de la abuela para mantener los recursos.

author: {'steamid': '76561197987018898', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 377, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 352, 'last_played': 1664646180}
