author: {'steamid': '76561198004368051', 'num_games_owned': 534, 'num_reviews': 141, 'playtime_forever': 824, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 516, 'last_played': 1681614452}
review:
Out There is a rather interesting Space Journey & Survival Rogue-like that would likely remind one of FTL: Faster Than Light; though without all the combat elements that one would find in FTL and more of a focus on acquiring ship technologies and resource management. It also has a sort of diary occurring between space jumps which helps you understand a bit about your journey.

Unfortunately it is also a game that seems nonsensical at times, and has its fair share of game mechanics that could likely be fleshed out better then what they were. There is also a lack of explanation as to what is going on - both in terms of the Tutorial not covering interaction of ship components, or just and overall lack of understanding of what is happening in the universe. Additionally, the diary elements between jumps begin to get irritating as they repeat.

It is also worth mentioning that some of your runs are just going to fail regardless of what you do - while Rogue-likes can sometimes have bad runs that go nowhere, this one seems revolve around Luck way more then it should. Personally I blame perhaps that amount of fuel that gets guzzled as you travel around for being a major source of trouble.

Anyhow, to delve into some of the cons for this game - why is it you can't talk to aliens once you begin drilling a planet - or why do aliens show up on a planet you just terraformed a moment ago? Why can't you choose to discard a less useful element when you inventory is full and Omega is being offered to you? Why can't I choose to only use some of a stack of an element when my inventory is full?

Perhaps a chief complaint I could levy though would be how the resource gathering mechanic is done - where subsequent attempts will yield reduced returns, but in regards to gathering fuel you tend to always get that 1 Hydrogen (or Carbon as my last ship was sometimes fueled); leading to an annoying situation where you are probing for that 1 Fuel Resource over and over until you get everything.

There is probably something to note about Game Design as well. The developer could have likely done away with orbiting planets that the player could land on - instead opting to have the player just land on planets if they could instead of having to click once to orbit and then once to land. There was an option to skip the jump sequence cutscene between star systems so may as well eliminate the need for having to orbit planets if they can be landed on.

I'm sure more can be said, but it is worth noting that his isn't to say one won't find a little enjoyment from playing this game though. For the first few hours I certainly enjoyed it, and before the flaws of the game annoyed me to the point that I didn't want to play it anymore, I could see myself replaying this game quite a bit. Now though, I don't think it has enough replay value for what is currently being offered - especially if the game is at full price.

author: {'steamid': '76561198041679702', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 136, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 136, 'last_played': 1437578156}
review: This is an unforgiving resource management game that really gives you very little for your effort. If your looking for something like "FTL", stear clear.

author: {'steamid': '76561198040649499', 'num_games_owned': 740, 'num_reviews': 86, 'playtime_forever': 332, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 332, 'last_played': 1473634458}
review:
It's alright. The core concept is fine, the writing is decent, and there are enough mechanics to learn about that for a few hours it was very satisfying. It feels appropriately engaging, in the beginning, to make progress and refine strategy and try to get farther and achieve more.

But once you're far enough it gets very repetitive, and the game's unsatisfying conclusions come abruptly at what feels like it 'should' be only the midgame, with no sense that there would be more to be gained by playing further. It is a well-polished experience for what it is, but it feels like half of a game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198001241298', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 94, 'playtime_forever': 158, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 158, 'last_played': 1472786661}
review:
I had read, that Out There is what No Man's Sky should have been. And I was so silly as to believe it.

There are many aspects with a strong resemblance found in No Man's Sky, and maybe there's a little bit of FTL: Faster Than Light. The thing is, Out There has everything that makes NMS a bad game, and nothing of what makes FTL a good game.

Essentially, imagine Out There as NMS with a huge amount of RNG. You mine/probe every place you go because you have to, deal with tedious UI/inventory management, and die a lot. Like, a lot. RNG. A lot. Die.

author: {'steamid': '76561198045823506', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 479, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 434, 'last_played': 1483622355}
review:
Out There propose une belle aventure spatiale sur les traces des humains. L'univers, l'atmosphere et le scenario sont vraiment rafraichissants et plein de rebondissements. 

J'ai aim√© : la d√©couverte de nouvelles technologies, la rencontre de nouvelles esp√®ces aliens, l'apprentissage du language ainsi que l'optimisation du vaisseau, la gestion des ressouces. Ces aspects rendent le jeu fun, rejouable et renforce l'immersion.

Selon moi le principal point n√©gatif du jeu r√©side dans le c√¥t√© trop al√©atoire des √©v√©nements, de la collecte des ressources qui ne valorise pas l'exp√©rience acquise et notre courbe d'apprentissage du jeu et qui peut cr√©er de la frustration.

author: {'steamid': '76561197973229984', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 1786, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 429, 'last_played': 1676763855}

author: {'steamid': '76561198086263525', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 167, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 167, 'last_played': 1471405549}
review:
Some great concepts are involved in this game, but ultimately it falls flat. From things such as the tedious resource management and scavanging, to the brutal difficulty and unforgiving amount of RNG (even on Easy I can barely make it through 15 destinations), and the lack of gameplay variety really drags the experience down.

I like the design of the aliens, the language mechanics, the art style, and the music. It plays smoothly. Its polished. But its dull and repetitive. Only get this if you enjoy the grind and don't mind unforgiving difficulty at the hand of RNJesus. It can be a nice game to chill to, but nothing that amounts to an active, engaging experience.

author: {'steamid': '76561198077964942', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 445, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 420, 'last_played': 1525881830}
review: 7.5/10 - It's like No Man's Sky but cheap, functional, and not overhyped.

author: {'steamid': '76561198177195226', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 520, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 520, 'last_played': 1448010027}
review:
I was very optimistic about this game.

On the plus side, the encounters with aliens are interesting and the fact they all have different languages is pretty fun. But I got bored by the situation the game puts you in. You get fuel on planets and you use it to travel to other planets to get oxygen to survive and metals to fix your ship. You will use the oxygen again to find another planet with fuel and your equipment will get damaged when you get it and so on... Basically you get stuck in a loop of getting fuel, oxygen and metals; all which turns to be pretty boring after a couple minutes. 

You only get a little action when you find another ship or when you are asked to make a choice. 

It still does not make up for the boredom that settles quite quickly.

This game would have been more interesting had the ressources not vanished/been used so quickly, restricting your moves.

author: {'steamid': '76561198014722620', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 222, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 149, 'last_played': 1471320072}

author: {'steamid': '76561198169103171', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 1064, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 648, 'last_played': 1480103578}
review:
Just played 4 runs today. Great game! I really like the simplicity and the sheer explorative spirit. 

The things I think need fixing - when you visit a station that replentishes Oxigen and your ship is Oxygen fueled it should also refuel! Similarly with other such occasions. Just makes more sense.

author: {'steamid': '76561197976038448', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 1942, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1870, 'last_played': 1562530271}
review:
Lost in the dark, dissociating abyss of space you must find your way back to humanity. In this excellent indie space exploration rouge-like you will travel red dwarfs and blue giants fighting for survival, exploring planets, discovering new technologies and ships, mining for elements, learning alien languages, all randomly generated each play through. With an awesome comic-book styled 2D artstyle and a surreal, alienating sense of being lost this game certainly makes a great game for sci-fi and space exploration fans!

I feel like I'm relearning the periodic table collecting all these elements and this game is definitely top-notch if you like to trip out! A great tide over till No Man's Sky comes out!

author: {'steamid': '76561198032490694', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 460, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 460, 'last_played': 1470435696}
review: As much as I wanted to like Out There, a combat-free sci-fi Roguelike-like, it is an exercise in tedium. Occasionally you get to discover something interesting about this universe. Occasionally you get to interact with aliens. Occasionally you get to decide how to respond to a random event. Occasionally you can get a new ship. The majority of the game, however, involves collecting fuel, oxygen, and iron to make sure you can continue you journey. And this resource management isn't even interesting: maxing out drilling and fuel scooping is almost always the best choice, since repairing damaged equipment involves spending a small amount of iron that you can replenish by drilling. The promise of multiple endings isn't enough to justify hours of boredom. Both FTL and Infinite Space III are more interesting games to me.

author: {'steamid': '76561198042779077', 'num_games_owned': 378, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 699, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 457, 'last_played': 1492799061}

author: {'steamid': '76561197970109049', 'num_games_owned': 125, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 7818, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5841, 'last_played': 1613573425}
review:
[h1] Lost in Space[/h1]

Dispite a great premise, it's difficult to recommend this game. It's very much designed for a touch-screen tablet - there is very little keyboard support. A little more effort adapting it for PC could go a long way.

author: {'steamid': '76561198018948430', 'num_games_owned': 409, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 438, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 408, 'last_played': 1470625698}
review:
It's like other randomly generated "Go from point A to point B" space games.  Most similar to FTL.

The big difference between this and FTL is that the game is not based around combat, but instead resource management.  As other reviews have said, the gathering of fuel and supplies is its own form of tedium, and the game could use some extra type of subsystem/minigame to really make it shine, but since this seems to already be a special edition, I doubt it will happen.

It's still fun.  If you're into these kinds of games, ten bucks is a reasonable amount to pay, and for those people who this game is NOT for, you'll probably recognize it within two hours and be eligible for a refund.

As for complaints about the game being too RNG-dependent, I'm going to actually say it isn't.  Yes, luck plays a big part in things.  But knowing how to make resources stretch, and knowing when to let go of cargo is a key part of playing the game, and can protect you from a lot of the RNG stuff.

author: {'steamid': '76561198027997444', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 249, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 249, 'last_played': 1467593206}
review: The random encounter texts and learning the different alien languages are kinda neat, but the main gameplay loop (drilling&probing for ressources) is extremely tedious. Combined with being killed by random dice rolls (sadly the non-fun variant of this, e.g. you choosing a path that turns out to be a dead end or just rolling a damage dice and killing you), this game doesn't live up to the promise of an exciting space exploration.

author: {'steamid': '76561197964250494', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 101, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 101, 'last_played': 1469147154}
review:
I expected a less combat oriented FTL.  Instead I got "probe for fuel simulator 2015".

I really wanted to, and tried to like this game. It starts out promising. You warp around a semi-linear path of stars, exploring planets looking for resources to upgrade your ship and fuel to keep going. It's got text-base events like FTL, limited slots to make you pick and choose what upgrades and cargo you take, a nice soundtrack, and great hand-drawn art style that I really liked.

Unfortunately. The gameplay mostly consists of clicking "probe" on gas giants to scoop up fuel until your ship is too damaged (orbiting a gas giant damages you), then wasting all the fuel you just mined landing on a rocky planet and pressing "drill" to scoop up almost, but not quite, enough iron repair the damage you took from the gas giants. Then you fly to the next system to repeat the process in an endless loop of tedium that eventually ends with you running out of fuel with no gas giant in sight, or crashing into a gas giant in a desperate gamble to mine one more load of fuel so you can mine one more load of iron to repair your hull that was damaged the last time you mined fuel.

Meanwhile, the "game" (such as it is) is also almost 100% pure RNG - significantly worse than FTL. The majority of maps feel like they are completely unwinnable no matter what you do due to bad random layouts, and spending 20 minutes grinding fuel and iron just to die because of something utterly out of your control such 2 bad random events in a row just feels so bad and offputting.

I can't recommend this game, unless you absolutely love tedious grinding and pure RNG combined in one.

author: {'steamid': '76561198056488960', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 56, 'playtime_forever': 117, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 117, 'last_played': 1467552940}
review: Tedious and unrewarding

author: {'steamid': '76561198031086170', 'num_games_owned': 1117, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 73, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 73, 'last_played': 1468775431}
review:
THIS CONTAINS SPOILERS:

Played using hacks to test the limits of this game.

Basically this game is this:

Move from star to star until you reach the "ending" star

between that and the end, all you do is maintain the upkeep of your 3 life lines - Oxygen, Fuel, and Hull - by visiting planets within the current star system. Once any of the 3 lifelines hit 0, you die.

It adds some flare by allowing you to "discover" and construct technologies which boost your functions of surviving/travelling, but other than that I don't really know..

I was expecting more...

After meeting the All knowing Alien being, it explains how you got lost, and what happened to humanity. After a few lines of dialogue, you return to the home screen with no option to continue exploring - or at the very least, expanding the game mechanics so you can interact with the universe in more ways than what it gives you now.

It's an okay game at best.

Buy it when its on discount.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970656406', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 1673, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1486, 'last_played': 1619122499}
review:
It's a lovely game, simple but very atmospheric.
I thumb it down only because of the last patch which made all the soundtrack monophonic. Devs were supposed to fix that, but it's months now and they didn't, and they begun to completely ignore the requests.
Make no mistake, this game is 99% atmosphere, and 50% of it is soundtrack which in mono sounds so much worse. They could as well make the game black & white.
I'll happily flip the thumb up as soon as they fix it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198007064131', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 711, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 711, 'last_played': 1468531297}
review: Too many recent reviews say "It relies too much on chance" Well tis a rogue like. If your buying a rogue like and dont like your games to rely on chance then theres something frankly with your expectations. Its a great rogue like. I loved it lot more than FLT due to its more compelling story of survival out there in the uncaring depths of space plus sub-plots and branching story choice endings.  Theres also a nice little feature in the menu options to allow you to encounter ships where you previously died in. Leading to some interesting situations in using the resources/tech from the previous game helping with the critics "relies too much on luck" theme going on.

author: {'steamid': '76561197999960958', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 1181, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 850, 'last_played': 1584139061}
review: Fantastic game! Really evokes the atmosphere of outer space and makes you feel like you are journeying through the stars. The art and story are thought-provoking and the music is serene. Highly recommended.

author: {'steamid': '76561197976829248', 'num_games_owned': 479, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 2491, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1542, 'last_played': 1527650946}

author: {'steamid': '76561197997404688', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 73, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 73, 'last_played': 1468075039}
review: The problem with this game is that it is random.  There is very little strategy and skill involved.  You go out there with your game set to Easy nd you last about 15 stars give or take.  There is so little you can do to mitigate failure that the game is just frustrating and seldom fun.  The graphics are great and the overall mechanics are pretty awesome but the game is just too random.  You can do almost nothing to win.  This is sad because the game is great.  I wish there was a story mode where you could go through the story and worry little about survival.  Exploring the stars is pretty appealing, but the constant frustration of random problems that WILL end your game early just sucks.  Deleting this and probably never looking back.

author: {'steamid': '76561198083257415', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 1398, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1137, 'last_played': 1615598113}

author: {'steamid': '76561198031433857', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 88, 'playtime_forever': 548, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 526, 'last_played': 1538890261}

author: {'steamid': '76561197993917008', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 107, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 107, 'last_played': 1467373909}
review:
I love roguelikes - they comprise a large portion of my library.  I love science fiction, have a degree in microbio and genetics, and work in IP.

While this game started off with an interesting premise and mechanics, it quickly became apparent that there are deep flaws systemic to the gameplay.  Most of what the other reviews say are right on: namely, that there is no real way to determine if what you do is right or wrong, or how to learn from the experience.  In which case, everything you do ends up feeling wrong.

Beyond this, there are other flaws that show the dev team/writer is out of their league in tackling this genre.  Diminishing returns when harvesting gas or minerals from a gas giant or rocky planet (respectively)?  Are you out of your mind?  IT IS A DAMN PLANET.  You are ONE PERSON.

All the aliens, however different or implausible, apparently speak the same language.  That's not even true of the one species on OUR PLANET.

Many of the "science techno jargon" employed is entirely wrong.  That is not science fiction.  Science Fiction proceeds from known, actual science and posits unattained or impossible results (but in a logical manner).  Using terms incorrectly, contrary to known science, and largely at random is not science fiction.  It shows that the dev team did not do much, if any, research into what should be (but are not) frankly core aspects to a space exploration game.  Star types are tossed about at random (and with no consistency or accuracy), planets are largely arranged in nonsensical order (yes, that gas giant with the rings is right next to the star, precisely where it ought to be).

The end result is something which is not enjoyable to RL players (because of the mechanics) nor to SciFi lovers (because of the experience itself).

author: {'steamid': '76561198223164124', 'num_games_owned': 946, 'num_reviews': 126, 'playtime_forever': 820, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 212, 'last_played': 1564253691}
review:
I'll start by saying that the game is pretty awesome: the story, the graphics, the soundtrack, the interface, everything is well polished and carefully crafted.

"Why don't you recommend it, then?", you may ask. To put it simply: one still relies way too much on luck. No matter how much strategy you employ, a couple of unlucky jumps is all it takes for you to lose - and when you lose, you lose absolutely everything, and you have to start all over again.

If you like this sort of game (FTL, Battestation:Harbinger), you'll love Out There. If you prefer strategy over luck, i humbly advise you to avoid this game.

Update: The Android version doesn't seem to suck as bad. So much so i was able to reach 3 of 4 endings in less than 12 hours. However, the PC version remains the same, though now it seems to have more bugs:
- Achievements fail to unlock.
- Resolution, quality, and full-screen options sometimes malfunction.

review: Another concept game. Lots of immersion and frustration. The game feels like a metaphor. If you are looking for fun I would not recomend this. It is what I like to call and experience game. The FTL comparison is unfair to the game. This is something very different. You spend most of your time despairing at your upcoming demise then start again to wallow some more.

author: {'steamid': '76561197971016201', 'num_games_owned': 934, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 81, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 81, 'last_played': 1466936388}
review: Relies way way too much on RNG for "difficulty". You never know when it might just arbitrarily decide to end your game through no real fault of your own. Even when you think you're doing really well you could be two random "events" or one bad planet line up from death. Since you always begin with the same ship and tech there's no way to try different strategies or approachs. You're just relying on the RNG to be kind enough to let you live.

author: {'steamid': '76561198050020408', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 528, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 397, 'last_played': 1507365666}
review:
Pure RNG if you do not like may not be your thing. The option to bump into your earlier failed runs ships helps along a bit. Playing the game for a few hours is the best advice on how to understand the game. The runs can be quick due to not understanding priorities and the limitations of your ships.

So bought it for half the price and was reading reviews of it being worse than ftl. Sure no combat to speak of but all other things and managing your cargo are important factors. Choosing the right options, getting better ships and finding technology sure make the game rely on luck. At least each playthrough so far has been totally different. To make things interesting you can find old ships you have crashed as well. 

For the price the game seems to have a decent amount of replayability and so far i understand only a small part of it so I enjoy it as much as FTL. Getting to the end was easier with FTL =)

author: {'steamid': '76561198233456184', 'num_games_owned': 457, 'num_reviews': 112, 'playtime_forever': 50, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 50, 'last_played': 1464993348}
review: Out There Omega espande la gi√† squisita iterazione di questo rogue-like arduo e senza piet√† con una quantit√† di extra come incontri alieni, eventi, tecnologie disponibili, opzioni (tra cui il cimitero dove incontremo le nostre navi abbandonate in altre partite e livello di difficolt√†, come se servisse eheheh), un restyle grafico, ora animato e pi√π bello. La linea guida sostanzialmente √® succhiare carburante in ogni occasione, occhio allo scafo e all'ossigeno, sperando di non incappare in qualche brutale incontro random che con buona probabilit√† vi spezzer√† la nave a cui si dovr√† aggiungere la disperata ricerca di ampliare l'estensione del motore o si finir√† alla deriva. Azzardare e cavalcare gli eventi, di fortuna ce ne vorr√† un p√≤, magari in un sistema troverete una supernave che vi tirer√† via di impiccio, almeno per un p√≤. L'atmosfera opprimente dello spazio dove morte e solitudine sono sempre dietro l'angolo, Out There Omega nel suo piccolo √® una esperienza oltre che avventura. Deve piacere la natura rogue-like come stile di gioco, qui assorbiti i meccanismi basilari, si andr√† per tentativi e la bravura non c'entra, ma regala lo stesso tante soddisfazioni se si entra nell'ottica giusta. Dopo svariate ore sull'originale per mobile, ancora oggi non l'ho finito, chiss√† se ci riuscir√≤. E non √® finita, tra non molto verr√† pubblicato Multiverse II per allargarlo ulteriormente. A 10‚Ç¨ √® davvero un indie completo e ampiamente rigiocabile. Ostico, sappiatelo.

author: {'steamid': '76561198036565047', 'num_games_owned': 855, 'num_reviews': 30, 'playtime_forever': 1027, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 426, 'last_played': 1608628492}
review:
Its hard, you'll love it....

well, you'll hate it, then hate it, get pissed off, hate it some more, then eventually you'll finish the easiest ending on easy... And then you'll love it! 

Don't expect a whole lot of lore, the game does have a story, and several plots. But it is an ironman/roguelike in which you gotta find your way back home after falling into a wormhole delta quadrant style, except without the universal translators, or weapons, or any technology. You start with what you have on your ship, which is nothing, and go from system to system trying to survive your way back home. Your going to need fuel, air, and a plethora of periodic elements along with a mostly unattainable amount of luck. You'll encounter aliens both good and bad, decypher the common language of the galaxy, and discover and obtain advanced technologies. You'll encounter derilict ships and weigh your options, keep what you've managed to piece together, or gamble on a larger more damaged ship in hopes of finding the components and materials to put it back together? 

With the number of advanced technologies and the handfull of different obtainable ships, in conjunction with options like ship graveyard where your ships you leave behind from finding a derilict or when you run out of fuel/oxygen remain in the system you left them in and can be reclaimed during the next playthrough. Combined with an average playthrough length of anywhere between 2 minutes to 30 minutes, you can be assured no two games will be alike. 7

I purchased ths steam version of this title after first purchasing it from google playstore, and having had it installed on my tablet and my phone, So keep that in mind before you let the fact that its a mobile port influence your final decision to pick this title up or not.

Its an awesome means of killing time, whether your in the waiting room at the dentists/doctors or your between classes in the commons with a half hour to kill. I highly recommend the mobile version, for anyone interested in what they see/read about OutThere simply because it'll serve you better next time your standing in line at the DPS or Waiting for your turn in the financial aid department at school. Not to mention the mobile port is cheaper, Only a buck or two. If it appeals to you like it did to me, you'll most likely purchase the steam title with little consideration. The amount of achievments and ridiculus sale price are what sold me. It was a welcome addition to my steam library

review:
I am sorry that I can't recommend this game. It feels unfinished; what I thought would be starting points for quests, were actually goal posts that end the game (without asking for a confirmation). But the worst part is the bugs. GAME-BREAKING BUGS. My first finished game had a ruined ending because I couldn't read the plot text when I got to the end, and in my current game (which was going really well), ALL of my known technologies have mysteriously been deleted.

I won't spend any more of my time on this game, when it could all be utterly wasted by bugs of this magnitude.

En definitiva si quieres pasar un buen rato en un √°mbiente c√≥smico c√≥mpralo, si quieres pasar un buen rato en el metro c√≥mpralo tambi√©n (ya que esta disponible en ios y Android).

author: {'steamid': '76561197978782798', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 72, 'playtime_forever': 1947, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1947, 'last_played': 1460390046}
review:
OUT THERE is a classic space adventure mixed with resource management.  While it is a port of a mobile game, only the comic sans esque text betrays it.  There is no actual combat in this game;  it's a bit more like a choose your own adventure book mixed with a random number generator and resource management.

The object of the game is to reach one of four points on a fixed star map and meet the conditions required at that point.  The points vary by distance,  which is an indicator as to the quality of ending you get.  Along the way, you have to manage your oxygen, fuel, and hull integrity.   Travel and random events that occur when entering a new system,  many with choices for the player, can help or hinder.  The starting ship is moderately sized but very inefficient; finding derelict ships to swap to is an early game goal. 

The language of aliens is one unified language.  You only talk to aliens by triggering an event on any life giving world.  As you interact, the words transform into readable text.  Unfortunately,  these equivalence are random,  so  one play through will not have the same translations as the next.   These aliens are important as they give you the technologies needed to progress.

Running out of fuel or dying means starting over from scratch,  but you will find ships from your failed attempts as derelict vessels that you can loot or swap to.  

The biggest issue here is that behind the curtain,  this game is a cross of inventory tetris and random generator results.   This changes a little as you learn the star map,  but not the inventory problem.  Each ship has a fixed number of aquares.  These squares can be a stack of resources mined from planets or they can be a module built from a technology you acquired.  Building one means losing cargo space,  except for one module.  As the game progresses a lot of time is spent recycling parts so you can fit fuel,  then filling your tank from that fuel and putting a drill in its place to get more iron so you can build more fuelling probes and drills and so on. A bad click while doing this can leave you stranded with no engines and no way to make more.

The music is incredible and the game is very relaxing if you can get past the comic sans and the inventory tetris.  I recommend this on sale,  but not for retail price.

review:
Out There is a cool idea, it's even a reasonably fun game at first. 

But after the initial play-through or two, the struggle for resources to keep yourself afloat becomes routine and once you figure out some reasonable strategy for keeping yourself topped off with fuel, iron, and oxygen, the game doesn't have a lot more to offer besides a few rare random encounters.

review: I've played this game both on IOS and on the PC. On both platforms the game creates an excellent atmosphere in which you as a player has to survive all extremes space has to offer. The excellent storyline and nicely drawn graphics help to immerse you in this bleak future and keep you from leaving the game. For this price it offers more than enough replay value.

If you don't have luck in games and you are not very masochistic I wouldn't recommend you to buy it. Otherwise... good luck!

author: {'steamid': '76561198084203609', 'num_games_owned': 222, 'num_reviews': 146, 'playtime_forever': 738, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 738, 'last_played': 1461366641}
review:
SUMMARY: An atmospheric space exploration roguelike with multiple endings, involving exo=ploration, finding resources, building technologies, and making choices..  Simple controls make it easy to play, the resource management and many decisions make it a challenge.  Must-buy for space exploration roguelike fans.

Out There: Omega Edition puts you in the position of an astronaut whose normal shuttle flight and cryo-sleep doesn't go as planned, and a simple trip finds him in an unknown part of the galaxy, with a mysterious faster-than-light drive, and a signal calling him to a far star system.  You're in the unknown with limited cargo, and a vague idea of what's going on.

Simple point-and-click navigation lets you travel to various star systems and explore the planets therein.  However every choice costs valuable resources - fuel, oxygen, and hull integrety.  You've got to balance what you choose to do carefully to keep yourself alive.

As you explore, you'll encounter various worlds.  Some will have oxygen and life, letting you restock supplies and perhaps gain some insight or resources from the inhabitants (which also requires you to learn an alien language).  Others may be rich in minerals, providing elements you need to craft new gear.  Yet others are gas giants, providingr fuel for the journey.  Exploring may lead you to mysterious artifacts, ancient ruins, abandoned ships, black holes, random events, and more.  You're never quite sure what's around the corner - though the right equipment may help you avoid (or find) surprises.

Crafting and repairing equipment is a large part of the game.  One broken piece of technology -or one new device - may make the difference between life and death.  Some technologies radically change your ship's capabilities, and some can be paired to enhance their functions.  You might find yourself mining - or scavenging - just to try out something new.

You'll also find different spacecraft if you're fortunate, providing you even more options for exploration.  Some of them are wildly different and highly imaginative - and may or may not be what you're looking for in your travels.

On top of all of this there's an interesting plot with multiple possible endings for you to try and reach depending on your inclinations.  The entire package combines into a fascinating, engaging adventure - each move, each decision, requires some thought and planning.

The game also has excellent art design, though some of the planetary art is recycled or palette-swapped, so it can seem a bit "samey."  Alien design is exceptionally imaginative, and until you're used to all the species, you'll probably go "wow" at some of the creatures you encounter.

The music is quite good, setting the mood without being invasive.

There's few flaws in the game.  Some of the game flow and control options seem odd (can't we just ignore the space-travel filler?).  I've encountered occasional bugs.  Complaints aside, it's an extremely solid game - and quite replayable (you'll probably spend quite some time to get all endings).

This is one of the games I can definitely list as a must-buy for fans of space exploration and roguelikes.  It has the right mix of easy-to-play, compelling and challenging.  It can be enjoyed in short bursts or long sessions..  It's got everything you'd really want in such a game, so give it a try.

author: {'steamid': '76561198002524680', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 109, 'playtime_forever': 22, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 22, 'last_played': 1459203194}
review:
I was low on fuel, so I stopped at a gas giant made of hydrogen that was thousands of times the mass of the earth.

When I tried to mine it for hydrogen, it was out. That's like visiting the ocean to find out that it ran out water.

author: {'steamid': '76561198070460036', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 498, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 489, 'last_played': 1459311169}
review:
Out There makes for an interesting bunch of hours of play.  The games is sometimes described as FTL without combat, which is an apt comparison, however Out There lacks FTL's replayability. I appreciated the game's artistic style and especially the feeling of being alone in the vastness of space. You slowly discover new technologies and learn the language of the aliens you meet.  However, the mechanic of resource management as you travel from planet to planet quickly. This is offset  somewhat by your character's journal entry's in which he describes how he feels being trapped in space and what he will do once he comes back to earth. 
After five hours of play I'm mostly bored with the game although I would like to see the other endings. (I think the game has four endings.) I feel like this game doesn't quite live up to it's potential. However, I'd certainly be interested in a sequel.

author: {'steamid': '76561198009535042', 'num_games_owned': 852, 'num_reviews': 51, 'playtime_forever': 1486, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 460, 'last_played': 1626142172}
review:
I love the aesthetic and relaxing atmosphere. While it's by no means perfect, it is very enjoyable in its own way. 

I wish the ships were more varied, so that it was possible to upgrade ships a few times during one playthrough. As it stands right now the chances are if you come across a derelict worth boarding; then you're probably not going to come across anything bigger during that playthrough. In all my playthroughs I've only had a couple of playthroughs in which I got to up ship more than once.

I hate random number generators and random events. So it's a testament to how good this game is that I still enjoy it despite it being randomly unforgiving at times.

Part of its charm is the randomised alien language that helps keep the joy and wonder of exploration fresh over successive playthroughs. It really gives the feeling of being lost and adrift deep in spacel

author: {'steamid': '76561198001066632', 'num_games_owned': 1895, 'num_reviews': 49, 'playtime_forever': 323, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 307, 'last_played': 1465095866}
review:
Totally a 'choose your adventure' style game, but presented like a developer's fell in love with Jodorowsky's Dune while wanting to make 2001. FTL is a loose, too easy comparison. This is a different beast, more like the Steve Jackon game books, but in a trippy, lonely, alien universe.

Ridiculously punishingly difficult, but still with that 'must try once more' edge because next time you'll get the fuel drops you need to make one more star jump away from oblivion towards some new weird-ass alien homeworld with fuel. 
 
Love it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198006719006', 'num_games_owned': 823, 'num_reviews': 95, 'playtime_forever': 485, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 485, 'last_played': 1457986398}
review:
Out There goes beyond being very difficult; it's just very poorly balanced. After dying and restarting 10 times, you will have figured out how the game works. After 30 restarts, you will have found a moderately effective strategy. At around 50 restarts, you will begin to realize that game progress is based entirely on luck, and not skill.

At that point, if you're one of those macho-ego gamers that has to beat games to prove your own self-worth, you might stick with it for another couple hours. Everyone else will uninstall, acknowledging that the first third of the game is pretty cool, but knowing the rest of the story isn't really worth the frustration and repetition.

author: {'steamid': '76561198015444627', 'num_games_owned': 722, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 393, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 303, 'last_played': 1658786784}
review:
So I was playing this game for a while and loving it. The concept is cool. It's a bit basic, but you do get a sense of being alone in the galaxy and have to make very difficult choices to survive. 

Then I was watching some videos of No Mans Sky and thought to myself, "Does anyone else realize how similar these games are? Are they made my the same company?" As far as I can tell, they aren't made by the same people but take a look at them. 

They both have:
‚Ä¢ weird relics in them that help you out in some way... like learning a language. 
‚Ä¢ a very similar periodic table of elements.
‚Ä¢ obviously space travel to/from planets and solar systems with occasional stops for materials.
and many more similarities I found incredibly odd.

You don't need to upvote or even like this review, but at least let me know what you think about this. I can't be the only one who see's the resemblance can I?

review:
Gutes Survival Game f√ºr Zwischendurch. Man wird im All ausgesetzt und muss wieder nach Hause finden. Dabei springt man von einem Stern zum anderen und muss aufpassen, dass der Sprit f√ºr das Raumschiff nicht ausgeht. Das ist mir jetzt schon mehrmals passiert. Da habe ich wohl vergessen den Tankdeckel zu schliessen. :)
Die Zufallsereignisse sind ausgewogen, k√∂nnen es aber dem Spieler auch nicht leicht machen. Findet man einen bewohnten Planeten und unterh√§lt sich gechillt (ja es gibt auch Eisplaneten :)) mit den Aliens, lernt man neue W√∂rter aus deren Wortschatz kennen und versteht beim n√§chsten Mal etwas mehr als nur Weltraumbahnhof. :)
Der Laderaum im Raumschiff ist leider etwas zu klein geraten, so muss ist man immer gezwungen stragetisch zu entscheiden und im Ernstfall Ressourcen wieder von Bord zu werfen (mit den Worten von TheMartian: "lets science the sh*t out of it"). Mit Gl√ºck findet man aber ein gestrandetes und gr√∂√üeres Raumschiff und kann umziehen. :)
Ich w√ºnsche allen eine gute Reise und viel Spass! :) Klare Empfehlung f√ºr kleine Marsianer und alle die es noch werden wollen. :)

author: {'steamid': '76561197987872190', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 41, 'playtime_forever': 394, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 394, 'last_played': 1453530226}
review:
Pretty fun for a little while.  Gets pretty repetitive after three or four hours.  Revolve around hopping from star to star collecting any available fuel, oxygen, or iron.  Eventually you will run out and die.  For variety, you get "events" at most stars.  these events might be a choice, or maybe something that gives or takes resources, or often just a scrap of prose to read.  I'm already seeing a lot of these events repeat themselves and they aren't all that interesting in the first place.

You occasionally meet alien life, but not much happens there either.  There is a sort of neat thing where, as the game progresses you learn words from the alien language, but in the end, nothing ever comes of it--you never learn enough words to understand the aliens speech or writting, and even if you ever did, from what I can tell, the only thing the aliens ever really have to say is that they would like an item and they will give you technology if you give it to them.

In short--Fun and relaxing for a couple of hours, but repetitive and dull beyond that.  Would maybe recommend for two bucks as a relaxing ap you play here and there while taking a dump or during commercials. 

And the "mood" of the game is nowhere near as evocative as some of the reviews on here would lead you to believe.  The artwork, however, is pleasant.

author: {'steamid': '76561197985655462', 'num_games_owned': 3977, 'num_reviews': 113, 'playtime_forever': 73, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 73, 'last_played': 1453642089}
review:
Out there Omega Edition ist ein Ressourcenmanagment Spiel.
Die Hintergrundgeschichte erkl√§rt sich ziemlich schnell.Als Raumfahrer wacht man weit ab unseres Planeten aus dem Kryonikschlaf auf.Irgendeine ausserirdische Macht hat einen weit vom Kurs abkommen lassen,die einem aber nicht unbedingt Feindlich gesonnen ist.Nun heisst es per Sternenkarte den Weg nach Hause anzutreten.
Das klingt einfacher als es ist,denn jede neu angefangene Runde spielt sich anders.Zwar bleibt die Sternenkarte gleich,aber jedes System beinhaltet unterschiedliche Planeten,die sich von Runde zu Runde √§ndern,so ist der Ablauf nie derselbe.Kommt man in einem System an,gilt es gen√ºgend Treibstoff,metallische Erze und Sauerstoff zu bekommen um die Weiterreise zu gew√§hrleisten. Dabei wird nebenbei die Geschichte eures Raumfahrers erz√§hlt in Form von Logbucheintr√§gen.Die durchaus sehr Spannend erz√§hlt wird.Unterdessen triff man auf andere Lebensformen,deren Sprache wir nach und nach erlernen um so auf Handelsangebote eingehen zu k√∂nnen.Man findet auf Planeten verlassen Kolonien fremder Rassen und kann deren r√§tselhafte Technologie erlernen um sein Raumschiff besser auszur√ºsten.

Die Grafik ist komplett Handgezeichnet und sieht sehr sch√∂n aus.Jede Art von Planetenoberfl√§che auf der man landet wird mit einem tollen Bild dargestellt.Das ganze wird von einem atmosph√§rischem Ambientsoundtrack begleitet deren Kl√§nge man gerne lauscht und auch das geheimnisvolle Universum thematisch unterstreicht.

Der Einstieg in das Spiel ist sehr einfach und es braucht keine 5 Minuten bis man alles erlernt hat."Out there"nimmt einen sofort beim Start mit einem kurzen Tutorial an die Hand und es kann sofort losgehen.Wenn man alles verinnerlicht hat kann man das Tutorial im Optionsmen√º abstellen,damit man bei einer neuen Runde nicht alles nochmal mitmachen muss.
Von mir eine klare Kaufempfehlung.Das Spiel l√§dt immer wieder zu einer neuen Runde ein und wird somit auch nicht langweilig.

author: {'steamid': '76561197972503203', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 477, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 204, 'last_played': 1528944219}

author: {'steamid': '76561197994387037', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 33, 'playtime_forever': 345, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 229, 'last_played': 1594565333}
review:
Fun FTL-esque game. games are typically short lasting between 20 minutes to 1 hour. high replay value
No combat is an interesting twist on the Oregon trail in Spaaaace. instead you focus on exploration, learning alien languages, acquiring new tech and trying not to run out of resources. 

Fuel is a BIG thing in this game. you harvest resources including new fuel by using your ship's finite power supply (fuel). 
Oxygen is fairly easily replenished
and Hull score decreased as you enter orbit of planets or take damage from random space events.

the ability to find ships you used on previous playthroughs is quite helpful, and can sometimes extend the length of the game another 30 minutes or so depending on how the RNG events treat you.

the only drawback, as side from using fuel to do anything, 
is Ship capacity. ship cargo space is fairly limited and forces you to make some hard choices about what resources are necessary and which ones would be nice for that new tech you want to craft.

there is the possibility to find random derelict ships that were not ones you used previously, i encounted an alien vessel once with a more advanced Cryo chamber and more cargo space.

author: {'steamid': '76561197988404499', 'num_games_owned': 753, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 3525, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3188, 'last_played': 1579899979}
review: A great resource-management rogue-like with many different elements and endings that keep the story fresh for many, many play-throughs. An easy mode has recently been added with the caution that it's not the way the game is meant to be played, but it does allow greater forgiveness for those who have already explored the game and want to experiment without having to start over. However, I very strongly recommend playing through at the normal, recommended difficulty level to completion first, as the challenge is part of the appeal.

author: {'steamid': '76561198049520081', 'num_games_owned': 1378, 'num_reviews': 34, 'playtime_forever': 911, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 826, 'last_played': 1460886389}
review:
Extraordinaire jeu de strat√©gie, Out There est un jeu d'exploration spatiale pacifiste m√©langeant roguelike, gestion de ressources et fiction interactive. Oui, je trouve que le r√©sum√© propos√© par les d√©veloppeurs est juste parfait.

Out There est chrophage, passionnant, et... sans piti√©.

author: {'steamid': '76561197984505368', 'num_games_owned': 1529, 'num_reviews': 226, 'playtime_forever': 427, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 427, 'last_played': 1452260915}
review:
I enjoy this more on mobile because it works best when played in short bursts (and is fine on small screens too!) - it's a BIT less successful played on a and over longer sessions because that highlights the randomness...

The atmosphere, music etc. is all great but I almost always die through lack of fuel and I've not really found a way of avoiding that OTHER than good fortune in what I find in a given run.

So it's a recommended >IF< you can cope with a game which, whilst enjoyable, is maybe more luck than skill....

author: {'steamid': '76561198018508362', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 40, 'playtime_forever': 1367, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 620, 'last_played': 1452509457}
review:
I Have been playing for a few days now and it has been entertaining, but the game does feel unbalanced with regards to your ship's fuel consumption and the resultant rapid conclusion to the game when you run out.

With great frequency I have felt that I had been doing well only to run into a punitive random event and bad luck with planets encountered (read as resources made available), and just like that, game over.

At the moment my curiosity is outweighing my frustration and so I have kept playing, but as much as I love the rogue genre this one feels like there is way too much random determination of whether one will be able to progress past the 30 minute mark.

If nothing else I would recommend the devs make a few changes to just edge a few percentage points of the chance of survival in the player's favor and make survival feel less like a random process.

For instance it would be welcome to be able to have access to the fuel/oxygen/hull maintenance UI during resource harvesting so one could use resources in the temporary probe storage boxes to immediately refill the UI instead of potentially having to throw away useable resources just because one doesn't have room in storage prior to switching to display of the maintenance UI.

I imagine with further player feedback this game will be able to achieve the proper balance between fun and frustration.

review:

"En el juego" est√°s perdido en la galaxia y debes volver a casa. Tienes que administar bien tus recursos para llegar sano y salvo. Hay Elementos y tecnolog√≠as que te ayudan en el viaje. author: {'steamid': '76561197985006944', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 188, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 114, 'last_played': 1529240011}
review: I love this game !!! A very fun and addicting sci fi space game with random play everytime you start a game. author: {'steamid': '76561198039086516', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 161, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 161, 'last_played': 1451728611}
review:
THIS GAME IS A CHALLENGE. So if you are afraid of that then don't buy this game. However if you love a good challenge then you should give this one a go. It will take you a few games to get used to how it works, but its pretty rewarding.

Out There is like FTL but instead of fighting an oncoming fleet of enemies you are faced with your own survival. You have to make tough decisions, you are rewarded for making the right ones and punished for the wrong ones (so it takes some finesse to work out whats right and whats wrong). Most of the time you will get angry with the challenging nature of this game, but it has lots of depth, pleasant atmosphere, and intresting alien/planetary encounters. It makes me feel like im lost in space and that every decision matters (and it does). 

It could definately use some more imagery in the mini-encounters while you travel between systems, Otherwise its a great game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198077434372', 'num_games_owned': 2055, 'num_reviews': 34, 'playtime_forever': 312, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 312, 'last_played': 1451191098}
review:
Should be named the "Ways To Randomly Die Horribly In Space Simulator". 

With procedural generation, and little story elements interspersed between, it's possible to provide the illusion of story, simply due to the human ability to construct a narrative out of any series of roughly connected events, and many games have hung their hat upon this post. But this does not make it a story game. 

Just as it provides the illusion of story, it also provides the illusion of resource management. The semblence of a resource management game is there, with the need to balance limited cargo space with the three essentials (fuel, oxygen and hull repair material) and improved tech (and the necessary parts to build it). However, since it's impossible to  predict the availability of any of these resources or technology there is no possibility of informed play. Learning more about the mechanics of how things work in the universe provides absolutely no advantage, as the available systems to travel to may be lacking in oxygen that you can harvest, or you may run out of fuel because there's nowhere to refuel (despite an earlier playthrough having gas giants on every corner waiting to be sipped from).

If anything, playing this seems to be indistinguishable from randomly choosing from the available possibilities. You might as well have it make the choice for you and then simply progress through by hitting space bar, reading the 'story', until your inevitable horrible death. It's art - but is it a game?

author: {'steamid': '76561198063494292', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 61, 'playtime_forever': 128, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 95, 'last_played': 1520804246}

author: {'steamid': '76561198052369621', 'num_games_owned': 83, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 144, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 91, 'last_played': 1647723908}
review:
I first encountered this game on the App Store for my iPhone a few years back, before Omega Edition was announced. I instantly fell in love with its unique art style, hypnotic music, and the fun, relaxing atmosphere (no pun intended) that the game created. While the gameplay itself was brutal, I found myself kicking back and enjoying the music and the story that I managed to follow as the game slowly progressed.

Omega Edition has maintained all of the spirit of the original game, and managed to make it even better. While I thoroughly enjoyed the 2D art of the original game, Omega Edition has created aesthetically 3D planets and systems in the planetary view while maintaining much of the spirit of the original 2D art. There's more possible endings, more ways to use resources, more kinds of ships, and more music. All of which have combined to create the amazing package that is Out There.

I love this game so very much, and I hope you do as well.

author: {'steamid': '76561197981655644', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 334, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 334, 'last_played': 1441480390}
review:
Full review  [url=https://davidyat.es/2015/09/06/review-out-there-omega/]here[/url].

Briefly: An atmospheric, punishing resource-management space simulator with more narrative than you'd expect. Beautiful art; addictive at first. It does get tedious once you figure out how not to die all the time, and some elements of the plot are ultimately disappointing, but it's worth it if you're looking for a few hours of atmospheric story and light resource management.

author: {'steamid': '76561198125826059', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 85, 'playtime_forever': 1342, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 618, 'last_played': 1492929704}
review: A cool little peaceful roguelike, a bit like FTL without the combat. The focus is on careful management of resources and on learning how to play a bad hand. There's not quite as much to see here as there is in most roguelikes (maybe 15-20 hours of content if you're after all the achivements?), but it's still very much worth the price.

author: {'steamid': '76561198148296370', 'num_games_owned': 86, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 10579, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1200, 'last_played': 1682307221}

author: {'steamid': '76561197990188583', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 221, 'playtime_forever': 2445, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1487, 'last_played': 1581185669}
review:
Very nice and relaxing rogue-like. Its not absurdly hard and it's enough to play it for a short time to get idea of what can lead to a "Game Over". Then it's just a beauteful space filled of unknown which is left for you to discover! Resource management is necessary, but compared to FTL game, it's not punishing. You can go back/forth between star system before you are ready to progress (e.g. stacking fuel to jump some fuel-hungry areas). There is a nice story of lone astonaut thoughts. It's touching. Music and visuals are just great.

I definitely recommend this game. And I would play games of such genre in the future for sure myself.

author: {'steamid': '76561197979029123', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 280, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 264, 'last_played': 1481237653}
review: The game has some things going for it: original gameplay, has you making tough choices about what to take and what to leave behind, and the comic book style is used to good effect. I really like the art as well. Where it falls down is the text, and since there's a lot of it, this ultimately breaks the game for me. There is a lot of broken english, and some extremely juvenile content ("the problem with aliens is that none of them are sexy girls". Really?) I'm not asking for a refund on this one because I enjoyed it, and hope maybe if the developer makes a little money they can afford to hire an editor.

review:
I usualy don't like space games but this one kept me hooked !
Every run is different, you have to learn some things and face a lot of random events while managing your resources in order to survive.

The only thing that i regret is the fact that you always start from scratch at every run, getting no benefits from the previous ones you made. But this is still a great game and it's worth its price !

author: {'steamid': '76561198025195084', 'num_games_owned': 2012, 'num_reviews': 101, 'playtime_forever': 949, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 786, 'last_played': 1586132000}
review:
tl;dr It's interesting for a couple hours while you're still getting a hang of the game, then it just becomes tedious when you're doing the same thing over and over again (fuel + repair).  6/10

I was really psyched to play this game.  Loved FTL and the description of FTL without the combat sounded great.  Unfortunately, it just doesn't come through with any of the depth that FTL had.  It's got atmosphere, absolutely, but that atmosphere is thin and evaporates quickly.  The only way it's a roguelike is in permadeath.  There's not enough variety for me to really consider it a roguelike.

The biggest downfall is the ships.  You start out with a bucket of crap, which is fine and to be expected.  If you're lucky, you might wander across one other ship before the game gives you the second-best ship for free as an auto-reveal plot point.  There's maybe seven or so other ships in the game, but only two of them are actually better than the bucket of crap you started with...which is completely underwhelming.  The firefly, even though it has zero free space, is fun to tool around and explore in simply because everything is so easy -- it's such a relief after the slow-going of the other ships that it can make the game quite fun for a little while.  Otherwise the only major difference is the amount of cargo space.  Even with the biggest ship (21 spaces), you're still going to be very short on space.  If the ships had been at least minimally interesting, I would've enjoyed the game a lot more.

Synergy - while not explained at all - is very important.  If a tech 'requires' another tech, placing it next to the 'required' tech improves the efficiency (giving a blue outline).  Which means less fuel/o2/mining!

The writing is sometimes interesting, but very much amateur hour sci-fi schlock.  Tons of spelling mistakes and awkward transitions.  Every time you warp to a new star, you get a random blurb/encounter.  After going through almost all the stars, I was still seeing new ones, which is something.  If the writing was a bit better, it would be a reason to keep going.  Unfortunately, it's not.  They don't ever really add to the very minimal story.

Drilling/probing should always be done at 10/10.  Ignore the super mining/super probing tech, they're not worth the space or effort.  Get your tech from the alien encounters as soon as you can.  Certain species will always ask "approve" others will always ask "disapprove."  If you choose correctly you can get tech and new words.

Overall, I really enjoyed the first couple of hours of learning the game.  But it gets old very quickly.  There's not much diversity in things to do.  The tech is shallow, ships are beyond shallow, and the map is far, far too large for how little there is to do.  Get it on sale/bundled.  Do not rush to get it.  Still fun for a bit if you really like the genre.  If you do get it, do yourself a favor and copy your save file before you do one ending so you reload it and complete the others.

author: {'steamid': '76561198048092359', 'num_games_owned': 1702, 'num_reviews': 235, 'playtime_forever': 255, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 255, 'last_played': 1449158891}
review:
Out there is a space exploration game and one of the most boring games i have played in a long time. It is almost as if the devs forgot to add gameplay.

You fly from star to star and all you do is refilling your fuel and oxygen and you gather some metal that is the entire gameplay. The user interface for that aspect of the game isn't even done well, it takes way too many clicks to do basic stuff like drilling a planet and taking the ressources. Once in a blue moon you find an abandoned ship that you can take over, but since they are all very similiar and only really differ in size even that part of the game is boring.
Sometimes you get a special encounter and you get a quest beacon added to your map. I managed to go to one of the quest beacons but once i was there it said on all 3 planets that the planet is hostile towards me and i can't land there. So all i could do was leave and continue the boring routine.

I haven't been able to complete a main quest because after literally an hour of doing nothing to get closer to the main quest my ship couldn't reach the quest beacon and i had to reroute and go at least 20 minutes backwards. At that point i decided that this game is not for me.

author: {'steamid': '76561198020125851', 'num_games_owned': 15680, 'num_reviews': 840, 'playtime_forever': 317, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 317, 'last_played': 1449050660}
review:
[h1]A nice resource-management rogue-like space survival game[/h1]
https://youtu.be/IWq6ojgfqxk
+ Interesting story
+ Nice atmospheric emersive graphics and sounds
+ Challenging
+ Limited inventory management causing you to make a lot of critical choices
+ High replayability elements (events that make you want to continue playing to find out more)

- Too difficult, I often found myself running out of fuel very often and constantly needed more
- High learning curve, you basically learn new things as you go 
- Heavily reliant on "random events" which can sometimes save you, but often causes you to fail
- Relies too much on text to narrate events (lacks visuals / animations)

author: {'steamid': '76561198038793183', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 7842, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1888, 'last_played': 1653761021}
review: The learning curve was fairly steep, but the game itself is very simple. It's difficulty helps make up for the small number of different endings (that I have seen so far, there may be more I don't know about). There is no combat, just occasional enemies to avoid. The mechanic for encounters with alien lifeforms is easy to use, and you get better results as you learn the languages.

author: {'steamid': '76561197993930568', 'num_games_owned': 5393, 'num_reviews': 480, 'playtime_forever': 162, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 162, 'last_played': 1448969164}
review:
It's an interesting game: FTL without combat; managing your resources as you explore the galaxy, but the interface is really annoying. For example when you use your drill or probe it's like looting and you get random loot popping up, say 3 or 4 things. To take them you have to drag them with left click from loot box to your inventory or right click each one and select to take it from the context menu. There is no -loot all- button. When you want to add a resource to your oxygen, fuel or hull you have to drag it across too. There should have been a one click button to fill your fuel, oxygen and hull, each one separately or all at once.

There are also issues with being forced to do something -right now- or lose the chance. An example is using a probe and not having room to loot everything from it, but the game won't let you take the resources in your hold and transfer them to your fuel, oxygen or hull: you have to dump stuff overboard or else you'll lose everything you looted in the probe. There are quite a few situations similar to this and it's very frustrating.

author: {'steamid': '76561198045022348', 'num_games_owned': 3229, 'num_reviews': 85, 'playtime_forever': 41, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 41, 'last_played': 1448843379}
review:
In one word: ATMOSPHERIC.

Nice relaxing moody Oregon Trail with loneliness lost-in-space. No combat. Scary in its atmosphere. Exploration and story only, no fighting. Mouse-clickfest. Lots of reading and learning about this or that. Some encounters with aliens but mostly it's just moody reading and traveling the stars. 

FTL minus the combat.

author: {'steamid': '76561198011116413', 'num_games_owned': 107, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 87, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 87, 'last_played': 1448587239}
review:
Among the best space survival roguelikes out there.

If you liked FTL, you'll be happy to hear 'Out There' is a very similar kind of experience. While FTL is more of a ship management sim, 'Out There' offers more of an exploratory angle.

I've left my planet for what reason, to find what, am I alone?

These are some of the questions you'll be asing yourself when you run out of Oxygen and you're left to die, gazing into infinite darkness.

author: {'steamid': '76561197993400405', 'num_games_owned': 3365, 'num_reviews': 167, 'playtime_forever': 853, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 546, 'last_played': 1636347232}
review: Lost in space, you must craft and utilize alien technology to inch your way millions of light years back to earth. The hook is that your ship has limited space to store resources and technologies. The game has surprisingly few moving parts and a heavy luck element, kind of like a "lost in space solitaire". A comfy yet nerve-racking game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198027044097', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 317, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 305, 'last_played': 1691049093}
review: There are too few ways to survive in this game. After a while, it gets formulaic and boring. This problem is compounded by the fact that you see art and concepts reused repeatedly.

author: {'steamid': '76561198015760546', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 1051, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 931, 'last_played': 1459306922}
review: 3.5/5. game is complete luck, if u dont plan shit out from the get go, your going to have a bad time. also dont play around with deciding how much fuel to use to mine fuel and metals. do 10. you'll get the max amount of resources possible from that planet. your shit might break, but just carry around some iron and viola, resources. even with the extra resources, if you get crap luck, like no gas planets within 4 jumps, your going to lose. play some classical or some other bob ross music to soothe yourself when shit hits the fan every few jumps( trust me, it will). I would recommend this game to people who are extremely chill or high. If you like rogue games, but hate pure luck aspects, dont get this game. there are better games out there that will still shit on you, but can be managed.

author: {'steamid': '76561197995943301', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 8, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 8, 'last_played': 1443914436}
review:
The Good:
You feel like an explorer. Your next move could bring about success..or your doom.
The Bad:
Yeah, it's gonna be your doom. 
Because everything happens to mess with you, and either kill you through asphyxiation, deteriorating hull, or just..stranding you in the void.

Still, one tries again and again.

author: {'steamid': '76561198065958899', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 655, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 502, 'last_played': 1518694077}
review:
well it really took me a while thinking about shall i recommend this game.

i have to say this game is an unfinished science-fiction art piece.

possitive side: the nice art work is the first reason i bought it and recommend it. it combined with the 4 story lines, 4 different endings, which gives me a sense of space opera in the deep, dark, solitary space. like i am sitting in front of the pc  with loneliness. YEAH you bloody losers wank all the time like me, face it.
the story is good i think, and the sound of "using iron fixing the hull", always reminds me"yeah NOW WE ARE EATING UP THE RESOURCE AND MAY THE FAINT FUTURE"

if you are just a simple gamer, who look for nice smooth gaming experience i dont suggest you to buy it.but if you fancy roughlike game, it may works.

this game is mostly based on RESOURCE CONTROL and well, gambling. you could say "the space is the most mysterious place, every move is gambling" seems i could not deny it. the resource collecting is really routine job, collect the fuel elements all time, if not enough fuel as you expect you die. and to fix the hull or deploy new tool go to rocky star, blahblah.
and the worse part is meeting the intelligent alien species. and the routine triggers of the other 3 story lines. can you developers just set some simple trigger conditions?

it is an unfinished game to me. but it is a really nice game. can't ask too much.

author: {'steamid': '76561197982663510', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 243, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 243, 'last_played': 1445207130}
review:
As someone who enjoys rogue-likes and FTL I thought this game would be quite fun.  I love story driven games, and I love super difficult games.  This game though is horribly flawed.  The most infuriating thing about this game is running out of a resource, finding a planet that has it, and then getting less from it then it took to even reach the planet.  If I go to a gas giant, I expect fucking gas, not levels of hydrogen so low that I was actually better off never going in the first place.  Sure rogue-likes are supposted to be random and luck based, but when this happens 2 or even 3 times in a row and end your play through, its no longer about difficulty as much as it is straight up stupid.  

The fact that everything also requires its own special element and you will almost never find said element when you need it nor ever have the cargo space to carry 1/5th of them for future use makes the game incredibly grindy while also being too luck based to grind in the first place.  This is also my experience on Easy mode, f$%k if id ever try the harder modes if easy alone is not enjoyable to me.

The second problem I have with this game is the story.  The aliens you meet are boring and their dialog is always the same, with very slight differences.  The hundreds of events you run into when jumping to a new sun could have easily been incorporated into the alien life meetings, but they wern't which was a huge mistake.  After you get whatever technology you need for your "mission ending" there is no longer a point to talk to aliens, which devaluates what should be a very important aspect of a game that pits you as being very alone.  I should be alone because everything is foreign to me, not because the backwater hillbillies on every planet speak gibberish and toss me useless Omega or space wasting technologies I give two shits about.

Lastly this game has very few endings for a rogue-like that needs to boast replayability, and most of the endings are poorly designed and give you a very poor taste and bad memories of the game afterwards.  A game like this should have endings that are memorable, and few of them are with the others feeling like they robbed you of your playthrough.  With 0 bonuses for completing a playthrough and a lack of diversity in the game making multiple playthroughs feel more like a chore then an enjoyable experience you feel like you are better off just youtubing the rest of the endings instead of forcing yourself to grind them out (which I did for the endings I didnt recieve yet).

This game saddly feels like something that would play great on a phone, but is ill suited for the PC in its current stage.  It has a lot of promiss, but it feels horribly unfinished.  I get this bad feeling that this game needs to be put right back onto early access, not have a "new edition" title added to it.  Go play FTL or Darkest Dungeon if you want a fun rogue-like experience, this game has a lot of growth left to it.

author: {'steamid': '76561197996896441', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 59, 'playtime_forever': 294, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 126, 'last_played': 1475414472}

author: {'steamid': '76561198018764855', 'num_games_owned': 1182, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 476, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 152, 'last_played': 1503265738}
review:
Out there is one of my favorite games, one that I can always go to and get lost in, find a deep story and never see the same thing twice, it does get somewhat repetative and ends up taking the fun out of it, I almost wish there were an automation mode, maybe some way to skip or set what your things go to.

going forward with that, the seclusion and desire to get further in the game has eluded me like no other, I've spent many hours exploring the world of Out There and I have yet to lose the intense wonder and need to keep going and push my ship and psyche to the limit trying to see everything in the universe. learning the alien language trying to figure out the paths and the mystery of the universe draws this compelling story and narrative experience out of the fluid and easy to learn gameplay.

author: {'steamid': '76561198001048776', 'num_games_owned': 611, 'num_reviews': 65, 'playtime_forever': 1373, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 687, 'last_played': 1580372436}
review:
"FTL without combat" while technically somewhat true is a bit unfair. I don't think it qualifies as a roguelike, for starters.  This is more like.....a point and click exploration game perhaps.

The steam page accurately refers to it as "interactive fiction" with some heavy resource juggling. Instead of any sort of combat (none of the ships you can use have weapons of any sort) you'll be presented with a dialog box with two, maybe three or rarely more choices, usually each choice affecting your resources in some way. That's where the similarities to FTL start and end really, if you mess up and run out of any one of your resources, you're screwed, and this being screwed can happen at random even if you're careful in some cases.

Interestingly there are multiple ways to end the game, with wildly different outcomes; its very much a choose-your-own-adventure type game with lots of text and some nice comicbook-esque visuals. It was originally conceived as a mobile game and it shows, but (much like another mobile game I liked a lot, Plague Inc) its kept patched with the occasional new feature, he's actually adding an "easy mode" apparently, since death or failure in this game really can be sort of arbitrary.

For the people on my friendlist who played and liked stuff such as Sunless Sea or Long Live The Queen, this is the sort of thing you'd likely enjoy.
