author: {'steamid': '76561198023899327', 'num_games_owned': 332, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 71, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 71, 'last_played': 1443118633}
review:
[h1]Another roguelike artificially inflating gameplay[/h1]

The game sets you up to fail.  I've played about seventy-one minutes and I've given up.  The small cargo hold in combination with the constant self-defeating need to refuel and repair drag me down every playthrough.  To be clear, you need to repair everytime you go to a gas giant, where you go to refuel.  And getting the components for repair requires you to land on a planet, and both taking off and landing require fuel.  Why can't I get hydrogen and helium anywhere but gas giants?  Isn't hydrogen the single most common element in the universe?  To top it off, installing technology and upgrades onto your ship to make the game easier requires cargo space: but you have very little of that.  Each unit of space can hold either one upgrade, or up to twenty units of a single element.  You need a variety of elements in order to get different upgrades, you need a steady supply of iron and helium/hydrogen for the refuel/repair grind (or should I say...  timesink), and you need certain techs in your hold just to stay afloat.  Some will say that you're supposed to recycle upgrades you don't immediately need, but that just means you need to retain a wider variety of elemental components in order to constantly manufacture the different upgrades necessary for each situation.  A variety of components which are unlikely to all fit in your hold if you mean to keep a decent supply of fuel.
It's clear that the game is designed to kill you so that you have to keep starting over before making any progress.  Which means you play more.  But why would I play something that's just frustrating?  No thanks.

review: Within two hours of playing this game for the first time it became one of my favorite titles in my Steam library. It's like FTL without all the stressful ship battles; and don't get me wrong, I do love every aspect of FTL, but this is a more soothing experience on that front though there is still plenty of resource management stress built into the gameplay. Another comparison would be if you took from the Mass Effect series the portion of play where you travel from star system to star system, scavenging for resources, and made an entire game of just that... this would be that game, of course with its own added story and additional fluff. It's really more of a cosmically beautiful experience than a game. And I love it. 10/10 for the ultimate Star Trek-ish, nerd experience.

author: {'steamid': '76561198030904505', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 37, 'playtime_forever': 1496, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1275, 'last_played': 1660705569}
review:
This Rogue-Like game is not about fighting, it is about resource management, planning and priorities. This makes it unique and great in this sea of Rogue-Likes. There are weapons in the game, but not to fight directly, even though you can use it for a genocide in an inhabited system or create life with its opposite.
Together with a ton of events - rarely the same for several playthroughs - and a nice survivalist atmosphere, I enjoyed it very much so far and will most likely complete it soon. Even though there is no completionist bonus, if you get that one perfect run, going all the way to New Earth, undaunted by resource shortages, you know you have done it. 

I would say if you like strategy games - or puzzles - and Rogue-Likes, this game is for you. See it through to all four ends and complete it!

That being said, the one achievement that I miss, is the one based on luck "Junkfood". This is my main critic here, a luck achievement should never be so rare, that it forces you to play a game without a goal until it sours. That is bad design.

author: {'steamid': '76561198003213131', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 592, 'playtime_forever': 614, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 423, 'last_played': 1579989468}
review:
Que dire de Out There, Omega Edition ... 

j'ai d√©couvert ce jeu sur iphone dans un premier temps et je peux dire qu'il m'a frustr√© xD

Le jeu √©tait sympa mais tellement sujet √† la chance que s'en devenait rageant.
Puis j'ai vu qu'il √©tait sorti sur steam en version Omega Edition, je ne connaissais alors pas la diff√©rence, mais maintenant je sais, il semblerait donc ajouter une fin vis √† vis du jeu de base.

Le but du jeu, √† part jouer avec la chance, est de mener son petit vaisseau sur l'une des quatres fin possibles du jeu, je n'en ai fait que deux mais c'est d√©j√† un v√©ritable challenge en soit xD

Pour un jeu tel que celui-ci, les graphisme sont soign√©s, ils ne sont pas d√©mentiels mais tout simplement bien fait, juste ce qu'il faut pour un petit jeu.
La gestion des ressources vous donnera des migraines, j'en ai moi-m√™me une √† l'heure o√π j'√©cris ces lignes ayant termin√© la quatri√®me nouvelle fin au jour 2300 et des brouettes de mon p√©riple soit plus de 6 ans apr√®s le point de d√©part lol.
Pour donner une id√©e je n'ai fait que la fin simple "verte" et la difficile "jaune", j'ai donc zapp√© la bleu et la rouge et c'est l√† que le d√©faut du jeu, qui en fait, soit dit en passant, tout le sel de celui-ci, est rageant ; Il n'y a pas possibilit√© de sauvegarder √† plusieurs point de l'histoire, ni m√™me de "new game+", pour faire les 4 fin faut 4 parties diff√©rentes et quand on sait tout ce qui peut merder dans une partie de out there alors c'est tr√®s difficile d'en venir √† bout !

C'est dommage ce point surtout qu'en fait, la fin verte pourrait nous laisser continuer √† jouer car elle ne "bloque" pas la ligne scenaristique, on pourrait ensuite passer par la fin bleu ET l√† nous serais donn√© un choix moral de faire la fin jaune ou la rouge. Ce qui ferai deux fins v√©ritables, une gentille et une m√©chante xD

Sinon le jeu en lui-m√™me, vous ne subirez jamais de combats spatiaux, vous les observerez de loin √† la rigueur mais jamais on ne vous demandera de cr√©er des armes et de les utiliser sur le voisin. La gestion de l'espace dans la soute de votre cargo est primordial, mais le placement des item l'est lui aussi tout autant, petit conseil : r√©servez deux cases √† l'horizontale ou la verticale et qui soit li√©es au reacteur, trois cases pour le plieur cosmique et trois cases pour le bouclier, √ßa vous √©vitera des mauvaises surprises et de devoir d√©monter un appareil existant et gal√©rer √† retrouver les mat√©riaux pour le remonter sur un autre emplacement par la suite. De m√™me, monter l'am√©lioration d'un bouclier, par exemple, dans une autre case qu'une coll√©e au bouclier ne servira √† rien.
Le plus grand vaisseau que vous pourrez avoir est celui de stargate atlantis xD 21 cases et m√™me comme √ßa, on manque cruellement de place dessus, on peut pas tout construire !! Ah et le plus petit des vaisseaux fait trois cases xD
Si jamais vous avez loup√© un des √©v√®nement spatiaux qui se d√©roulent √† chaque arriv√©e sur un syst√®me sachez que ceux-ci sont r√©p√©table et al√©atoire, le r√©ussir ou le foirer une fois ne vous le supprime pas de la liste des rencontres al√©atoires. Certaines am√©liorations vous permettent de r√©ussir sans dommages ces √©v√®nements, mais parfois ce n'est pas rentable car vous n'y gagnez rien, √† m√©diter ;)
L'item semence de mort ne sert que pour une seule des fin, pour l'avoir SUR-utilis√© tout au long de ma derni√®re partie, dans des syst√®mes ennemis, √ßa ne change strictement rien au gameplay, vous n'avez personne aux fesses qui souhaite vous d√©zinguer. Par contre l'item semence de vie est preque capital, il permet de transformer une plan√®te st√©rile, apr√®s l'avoir min√© conscienceusement, de la terraformer en une plan√®te respirable qui remet automatiquement votre stock d'oxyg√®ne au max, qui plus est vous y rencontrer dans 95% des cas une race alien (je dis pas 100% des cas car j'en ai terraform√© un sacr√© paquet, et une seule fois la plan√®te √©tait vide, aucun alien xD). Ensuite pour les interraction avec les aliens ne vous formalisez pas si vous merdez vos premiers dialogues, c'est pas grave, tant que vous apprenez les mots c'est le principal, une fois tout le dictionnaire dans la t√™te et que vous avez int√©gr√© le concept de lecture du traducteur (lol) vous aurez toujours le discour de trade, et si jamais vous n'avez pas l'item demand√© alors annuler l'√©change, puis relancez la discussion, g√©n√©ralement ils peuvent demander trois item diff√©rents au max, moi je privil√©giait le fer, le plus simple √† trouver dans la galaxie, et s'ils en voulait pas je me barrait pour aller sur la prochaine plan√®te, voil√† une bonne utilisation des omega r√©colt√© √† gauche √† droite ^^


Enfin bon, le jeu est bien sympa et si vous souhaitez vous √©nerver et vous arracher les cheveux pour d√©couvrir le fin mot de ce tr√®s bon jeu alors foncez dessus je vous le recommande.

author: {'steamid': '76561198123054255', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 135, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 90, 'last_played': 1456412327}
review:
If I wanted to play space adventure games, I'd play FTL.
Not that Out There has anything to do with it. But I really hope I'd purchased FTL first.
Out There has an interesting concept, but will ultimately be cause for stress, anger and depression.

It's not a graphics issue, those are fine. Nothing too special and definitely not ugly. Some visuals (that of the black hole, for example) are actually quite beautiful.
It's not an idea issue, that -aside from the fact that it might even be TOO developed, for the depth then delivered by the game-, is fine. The story...makes sense, there is some interesting variety and you do, in the end, want to figure out the hidden secrets of the game.

It's the GAME. I'm not the best player in the world, and not one to ragequit on a game that's too hard. Seriously: most of my games are unfinished because I tend to suck at most. But this is just frustrating. Pretty much everything you do causes damage, and because of the little cargo space of the ship, you either suffocate, explode or get stuck in the middle of deep space. OR YOU DON'T experiment. That's an option, of course. You can survive long enough, if you just ignore every material you find, every technology you discover, every planet you'd like to land on. The moment you pick up something new, bang, you're dead.

And guess what, it's all back to the start, baby. Took me half a dozen time before I told this little game to fuck right off. I wonder how many times it'll take you.

author: {'steamid': '76561198007154600', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 58, 'playtime_forever': 888, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 671, 'last_played': 1580534608}
review:
One of the finest examples of rougelike mixed with sci-fi and resource management.  What can I say?  The description was accurate so I pointed it out lol.  There's lots to do in this game if you have the wits and the supplies like oxygen and fuel to keep hurtling through space.  You'll run into strange aliens and even stranger stellar events!  It sort of becomes a choose your own adventure type of game without it being a visual novel type of game thankfully.  I highly recommend this game to sci-fi nuts like myself.  I also recommend the game to anyone who thinks they can span the cosmos with what they are given and what they scrounge up from their limited travels to keep on moving forward!  Have fun and buy this game to have even more fun!

Overall rating: 8.5/10

author: {'steamid': '76561197993781879', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 64, 'playtime_forever': 768, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 768, 'last_played': 1439382055}
review: Dice rolling: the game. This game is ALMOST pure RNG, with some inventory management that might skew the odds torwards your favour. And that would actually be pretty bearable since it kinda has an interesting premise but there is SO much clicking in this game, and no shotcuts that I found to make it less tedious. Click to land on a planet. Click to mine it. Click to collect stuff. Click done. Click take off from planet. Click to fly to another planet. Click to go to a another solar system. Repeat a thousand times.

author: {'steamid': '76561198030933161', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 499, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 499, 'last_played': 1440468471}

author: {'steamid': '76561198006648302', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 1313, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1239, 'last_played': 1550821807}
review:
This is the first roguelike I have played for myself (having previously seen others on Twitch), and I love it. I knew going in it would be frustrating, but that's the charm.

It's addicting and will have you silently cursing every time you make a boneheaded mistake, forget your hull is so damaged, or the RNG gods have decided "That's far enough. NEXT." And yet despite the agony and rage, you click 'retry'.

The writing is top-notch (outside of some grammatical mistakes) and funny when it counts and the visuals are stellar (pun intended).

I highly recommend this game

author: {'steamid': '76561198000607162', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 30, 'playtime_forever': 382, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 190, 'last_played': 1581208694}
review: This is a very well written game, it really feels like a classic science fiction story about exploring uncharted stars. Short texts describe the pilot's thoughts, unexpected encounters with alien forms, weird phenomena, all the elements of a good star exploration. It feels excesively random at first, and very hard on the managing resources side. You start to link certain stars with certain resources and you feel like a true explorer, but I still have problems finding fuel and without fuel you can not continue your travel and lose the game. I hope it's just my lack of experience with the game, it would be sad that the random availability of the resources were the true factor that decides how hard your playthrough is.

author: {'steamid': '76561197971809180', 'num_games_owned': 270, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 157, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 124, 'last_played': 1438827905}
review:
I really want to recommend this game. It's unique and charming. I love that it's simultaneously simple and engaging. You can jump from star system to star system in search of resources, alien life, new technologies, etc. Along the way there are pieces of back story and new encounters to reveal. Unfortunately, it just ends up being repetitive and ultimately shallow. I think some very simple adjustments to resource balance could help fix some of the "grind". As it stands you spend much less time looking forward to revealing story snippets and just worry about finding the next barely sufficient supply of fuel or iron for your hull....time and time again.

I really, really want to spout how great this game is. But so often the devil is in the details, and Out There is just missing some of the defining detail that might push it to cult-y status.

author: {'steamid': '76561198087131948', 'num_games_owned': 3521, 'num_reviews': 51, 'playtime_forever': 406, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 221, 'last_played': 1652210112}
review:
Titolo meritevole con alcuni richiami ad un gioco ben pi√π famoso: FTL - Faster Than Light, i quali condividono un sistema di spostamento della propria astronave attraverso interi sistemi solari e galassie.

Tutto si ripete finch√© non si riesce ad arrivare alla fine del gioco. Non per questo risulta ripetitivo per√≤, in quanto infatti saranno presenti eventi random che difficilmente sembrano ripetersi, oltre a ci√≤ la generazione dei vari sistemi solari, pianeti e quant'altro √® anch'essa casuale.

Ottenere un buon score o arrivare alla fine? Si pu√≤, grazie ad una buona gestione delle risorse, ad un minimo di capacit√† strategica e ad un po' di fortuna.

Rimane comunque molto frustante morire e perdere i propri progressi effettuati, anche se si riesce ad ottenere un buon risultato.

9/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198025913007', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 132, 'playtime_forever': 335, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 335, 'last_played': 1437716309}
review:
Out There is a game I was really excited about when I stumbled on it a few days ago.  I was expecting a game like FTL, but with its own unique style.  It [i]does[/i] have a unique style, but the gameplay is severely lacking.  Resource management is much more complicated than it needs to be.  You constantly run out of everything.  Running out of any one of the games three resources--fuel, hull, and oxygen--leads to an immediate game over.  Space on your starting ship is very limited, and you will constantly find yourself destroying and rebuilding modules to make more space for resources.  Game overs are frequent because you can run out of resources at any time if you hit several systems that lack planets to resupply at.  Game overs are far too frequent.

The game itself is unrewarding.  Unlike FTL, there are no unlockable ships.  You can find ships randomly during your adventure, but there is no way to start the game with a different ship.  Different ships require different materials to repair and maintain, which means you can stumble upon great ships that need materials you don't have because you never have enough space to carry them.  Not being able to unlock different starting ships makes the game stale as it limits your options.

Technology gains are also completely random, and whole sections of the map later become inaccessible later in the game if you haven't stumbled upon certain required technologies.  Even after you acquire the design for a technology (which can be lost in random events), you still must build it, often out of resources you can't keep on hand because of space limitations.  And for every technology you add to your ship, you have less space to gather materials.

The map of stars is fixed, but the planets and events are randomized.  This may sound like enough variation to keep the game fresh, but the lack of choice made the game stale for me after a few dozen attempts.  There are four different endings, but nothing that any of them offer could compel me to play further.  There is too little strategy, too little choice, and too much chance.

There are makings of a good game here.  The art and music are both excellent, and the production values are high, and it does have some interesting ideas.  It's just poorly balanced and unrewarding.  Making ships unlockable (so that you could choose to focus on different materials and have more freedom) would be a welcome change.  If a sequel is made that addresses my complaints, I will be the first in line to buy it.  But I cannot in any way recommend this game in its current state.

author: {'steamid': '76561197971264400', 'num_games_owned': 1112, 'num_reviews': 142, 'playtime_forever': 22, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 22, 'last_played': 1437190069}

author: {'steamid': '76561198036943999', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 170, 'playtime_forever': 636, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 553, 'last_played': 1552956451}
review:
I'm giving this game a negative review, although it's mostly about the content to price ratio. It's got alot of good points, but it's too simple to be worth $10. It was made to run on a phone, and it shows. Very little content. Excellent writing, but very little story. The artwork is great, but the game is just not what you'd expect at this price point. 

This is a Roguelike set in space, so of course it gets compared to FTL. So imagine FTL without combat, crew management, shops, system upgrades (although you can keep the augments), alien races (you can keep the occasional space-monster), and the rebel fleet. What's left? Jump, read event text, harvest system, jump again, and try not to run out of fuel.

The biggest complaint I have is that the game claims to be more than it is. The game is 90% resource/inventory management (which was pretty simple/uninteresting), 9% flavor text (which I thought was very good), and 1% "meeting intelligent species that won‚Äôt care about you, but also dealing with ancient powers linked to your destiny and the fate of mankind itself." In my humble opinion, a 100 word dialog in the end scene about earth does not make the game about the fate of mankind. Also, the game purports to be story driven, but the story is just a series of unrelated microevents that occur when you warp into a system.

Also, I'm not saying this as a negative point, but this game is unforgiving. All roguelikes will kill and frustrate you at first, but I thought this one had more to do with luck than skill. The games are quick enough that it's not like you've got a huge amount of time invested, but there will be games that simply cannot be won. 

Honestly, the game is kinda dull and repetative, but the artwork and writing really are great. I just was expecting a little more.

author: {'steamid': '76561197996780598', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 40, 'playtime_forever': 1243, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1123, 'last_played': 1437890678}
review:
Bought this game yesterday. The graphics are crisp. It's a tad too difficult for me and I wish there was one or two more initial slots. I like the variety of events.

One thing that's a big negative for me is that no one at Mi-Clos Studio took the time to actually spell-check and grammar check the story text. There are a lot of typos, including missing words and "it's" confused for "its". I hate that.

author: {'steamid': '76561198031689202', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 199, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 188, 'last_played': 1603192083}
review: I loved the art and atmosphere Out There provides.  However, it is essentially a luck driven game.  The penalties you receive by random chance are devastating; the cost to travel, drill, probe, etc is too high or the ability to stockpile resources is too low.  Ultimately, it just becomes a dice roll.  Sometimes you'll survive through 30 star systems, sometime as low as 3.  Play enough times and you'll get somewhere, but very little will do with skill (although some base knowledge of resource management is needed).  This game is not for explorers, this game is for masochists who don't mind starting over after no real fault of their own.  A save option might fix this so you can "reroll" those fickle dice of fate.  I would also probably enjoy an option to bump up the cargo storage (like double or triple).

author: {'steamid': '76561197971723812', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 66, 'playtime_forever': 564, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 563, 'last_played': 1437945012}
review: I purchased this game on a whim (steam sale 50% off) and it was one ofthe better decisions I have made as far as purchases go recently. I would gladly pay full price for this game knowing what I know now: this game is fantastic. It is very simple, yet extremely complex. You have a ship which needs fuel, air, and metal to survive. (Fuel to move, air to breath, metal to repair the ship). You collect these resources from different planets you encounter. Planets are in various solar systems you travel to. Gas planets have fuel; oxygenated planets have air and life and metals and one form of fuel (carbon); rocky planets have metals and carbon. You discover technologies as you jump from solar system to solar system through random events. (You can also lose tech through random events: ex. space bugs chewing through part of you computer causes it to lose the info on how to build a certain tech. If that tech is destroyed you won't be able to rebuild it if you don't re-discover the tech). This is what makes the game so addicting. The randomness of the gift of tech and space ships and life forms that all have their own advantages and disadvantages. Life forms give you gifts randomly or by saying and giving them all the right things. They have a randomly generated language (every time the game is restarted). Learned words are always the same every time you restart. So, whatever languages you learned with this current space explorer's life, you will have for his duration. Once you die, everything beins anew. I just beat the game- finally- and I plan on replaying it much more. Why? Because I only got one of the endings! There is so much more I have left out, but I think this is adequate enough to pique some of your interests. Note: the game is very tough due to the randomness. If you can have things fall your way until you find a bigger ship and gather some useful tech then you will increase your chance of survival exponentially. (I went from lasting maybe 20 or so solar systems explored to over 100 in my last playthrough).

author: {'steamid': '76561198111263701', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 28, 'playtime_forever': 2140, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1879, 'last_played': 1449966115}
review:
Voil√†, √ßa fait 5h que je m'acharne √† essayer de terminer Out There, et apr√®s moult efforts (et de la chance, bon sang, cette chance qui est indispensable !), j'ai enfin r√©ussi. R√©ussi oui, mais √† obtenir une *des* fins. Il y en a d'autres...

Bref, le gameplay de Out There fait vaguement penser √† celui de FTL : on se d√©place de syst√®mes en syst√®mes, dans le but de parvenir √†... quelque chose (no spoil inside) tout en g√©rant 3 ressources (carburant, oxyg√®ne, la coque du vaisseau). Dit comme √ßa, √ßa ne donne pas forc√©ment envie. Surtout qu'√† la diff√©rence d'ETL, ne cherchez pas de combats, il n'y en a aucun. On pourrait donc r√©sumer le gameplay par une sorte d'algorithme : avancer au prochain syst√®me consomme du carburant et de l'O2, checher du carburant consomme de l'O2 et de la coque, chercher des m√©taux pour que le vaisseau ne tombe pas en ruine consomme du carburant et de l'O2. Et comme bien s√ªr on ne sait pas ce qu'on va trouver dans le syst√®me suivant pour se ravitailler... Tout √ßa √©tant ponctu√© par quelques rencontres avec des civilisation extraterrestres et... d'autres choses (no spoil inside).

Bon, dit comme √ßa, je ne suis pas certain que √ßa donne tr√®s envie. Sauf que Out There dispose de quelque chose tellement d'autres jeux n'ont pas : une ambiance. Ici, avec pas grand chose pourtant, l'ambiance est terrible. Cette impression d'√™tre perdu, seul, sans aucune chance. Je ne sais pas si c'est seulement d√ª √† la touche graphique, ou bien aux musiques - exceptionnelles d'ailleurs, si j'avais su, j'aurais pris l'OST avec - mais en tout cas, c'est particuli√®rement r√©ussi. Presque autant que quand on se retrouvait √† voyager dans la galaxie dans l'Arche du Capitaine Blood, pour ceux qui ont pu y jouer pendant l'√®re Amiga/Atari. Ou, dans un style diff√©rent, on retrouve un peu le d√©sespoir du personnage du livre de James Smythe, Le Voyageur.

Conclusion, je ne peux que conseiller ce jeu !
D'ailleurs, je vais y retourner de ce pas pour tenter de parvenir √† une autre fin.

review: As others have said, it is like FTL without combat or time pressure. The writing and scenarios are quite good. But I agree with the main complaint, which is that the gameplay relies a little too heavily on randomness and doesn't seem to have enough of a skill component. Despite that I still enjoy playing.

author: {'steamid': '76561197971508249', 'num_games_owned': 638, 'num_reviews': 94, 'playtime_forever': 99, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 99, 'last_played': 1437285308}
review:
Out There is a game that sounds decent. Music's fitting, SFX are nice and in time, if a bit scarce. Tad generic, but everything works pretty well.

Out There is a game that looks decent. The occasional stunning view or the very nice intro are counterbalanced by the general hand-drawnness of the game (nothing against that style, I just think it doesn't work very well in this particular game). The text boxes and the fonts also look wrong, maybe overly clean, maybe too much spacing to the sides, maybe it's the artificial feel of the fonts. At any rate the game is kinda irregular throughout but when it works it works, I just think it falls short of the style they were obviously aiming for.

Out There is a game that reads pretty nicely, the random tidbits on arriving to a new system tend to be pretty entertaining to read. Although it doesn't get too boring you'd think they would have way less walls of text [i]in a game that tries to look like a comic[/i], buut I guess if that's gonna allow for more variety I guess that's fine. Most times those text messages are just elaborate ways to tell you you've lost something, so pretty soon you'll be skipping over them and get the non-verbose "here's what you lost this time" message. Other times you won't understand whoever you're talking with, and through trial and error you'll finally be able to understand what they're telling you. I think it's a neat mechanic on paper but that alienates the newer players and gives an advantage to veterans. I tend to have problems with mechanics that work like this.

Out There is a game that [i]in paper[/i] sounds great: you start on a ship with hull, oxygen and fuel. Traveling costs fuel and oxygen. Approaching certain bodies will cost you hull. Different ships take different elements for each of those, and you can get the elements strewn across the 3 main kinds of planet: rocky (metals), gas giant (fuel) and breathable, where you can also interact with other races. You can build modules with those elements as well, and there's also a variety of random events, including derelict ships you can take for yourself, peppered across most of the systems you'll go to.

Out There is a game that manages to kill all of the previous due to what I think are really sloppy late-cycle decisions that constantly remind you how much more fun you'd be having with the game if the main source of difficulty weren't incredibly obvious arbitrary restrictions aimed squarely to kill you faster. Now, when I say "arbitrary restrictions" I don't mean the ones that come along with the systems the game chooses to base itself off, such as the tile based inventory. If anything, a tile based inventory feels more at home with this game than many others: after all, you can tell me you have 16 universal, fixed compartments on your ship that can only be occupied by one resource and I'd be cool with it without even asking why there doesn't seem to be barrels in space. I can sorta roll with it. If the game played fair.

You see, through the game you'll constantly catch yourself thinking "wait, I can't do this now?": have you just looted a lot of fuel but your cargo hold is full? Tough luck, buddy! No, you can't transfer the fuel directly to your reservoir. You can't transfer the fuel that's in your cargo hold either, despite being totally fine anywhere else outside of the loot screen. No, you can't just exit the loot screen and go back to it after arranging your cargo. Do you have the one single unit of silicon to craft a module? You need to free up another entire compartment to build it first, despite the fact that there'll be one or more empty compartments after you craft it. Want to mine a breathable planet before talking to the natives? No siree! The option to talk to the natives will be gone by the time you come back from the loot screen. Do you want to transfer this module between ships? Christ, no! Even though just a while ago your dude went out on EVA to get into a transparent station to shoot a negative energy ray to a sun. You can only dismantle them, AND THEN get the elements back to your ship.

Now, here's what I think happened with Out There: They planned the game, they prototyped it, they coded it, and when it came time to testing it they realized that some testers were beating the game too easily, or that the existing system was too prone to exploits. But either because of an exceedingly rigid development plan, because of deadlines or because the game was  way too far developed to redesign it into something that solved the issue they were having, they instead made a list of the strategies the testers were using to beat the game and just simply took the common elements in these strategies out of the game. It is the equivalent of having a game where you have control over your stuff but with the developer sitting next to you and slamming on the keyboard every now and then screaming "NO YOU CAN'T DO THIS IT'S NOT FAIR." Not only will that feeling come to you when you'd need those things (and, again, you'll constantly think about these things since they're commonplace), but you'll also be constantly penalized by an entropy that honestly seems wildly exagerated and out of whack: flying to a gas giant will take you 10 fuel, and mining it between 5-10, and the probe that's designed to scoop fuel from a gas giant and return it to your ship will come back with barely enough to cover ITS fuel cost, let alone your ship or the jump to the next system. While wasting oxygen and hull at the same time for good measure. This can happen up to three times in a row (and I couldn't keep counting because my hull disintegrated trying to get to the fourth), showing that the game wants to kill you way more than have you presented by a series of decisions in an environment where you are in control. I tend to bash on tower defense games calling them "antigames" because there's only one ideal solution and maybe a couple sub-optimal ones to each level, but in Out There there isn't even that. In most cases you will find youself dying without any chance of control over it and no satisfaction for that playthrough. And yes, space is merciless and life sucks. That doesn't mean my experience with a game has to suck just because those two things are true.

So in closing, Out There is a game that although majorly pleasing to the senses and a solid concept comes apart because of a series of very obvious, very arbitrary design decisions that will constantly remind you that this is not a game made to be challenging and fun, it is designed to make you fail unless you are very lucky a lot of times. The entropy is stupid and the arbitrary restriction of player control is inexcusable for a game that calls itself "a genre bending roguelike". Roguelikes should be hard, but fair. And this game doesn't play fair.

I honestly can't bring myself to give it a bad score because of the solid core, but I can't honestly recommend this game because of the very big and very evident flaws on its execution.

5/10.

author: {'steamid': '76561198060340067', 'num_games_owned': 573, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 1549, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1528, 'last_played': 1445135600}
review:
I wish steam had scales between thumbs up and down as I want to like this game, this game has the DNA of everything I love, so even giving it the benefit of the doubt, in the end, I cannot give this game a completely good review. 

Even without living in the shadow of FTL, after several playthroughs, what hurts this game is that it touts resource management -which literally suggests that if you "manage" your resources wisely that you'll have a chance to survive. 

This is hardly the case as you are constantly up against no win scenarios. I know this game is suppose to have an element of chance to simulate the harshness of space; but when 9 times out of 10, you either run out of fuel or hull material, or just wind up stuck someway because you encountered a chance scenario that breaks your space folder and drill and you have no material to fix it and you can't drill for any (this happens surprisingly often). There is a problem with the game that doesn't allow your choices to ultimate determine how far you get. 

There is no strategy because in order to even survive, you must drill or probe very conservatively, meaning you must only use as little fuel as possible while mining for as much resource, fuel and hull repair specifically. I've gotten farther on some attempts vs others but when 5 out of 6 sides of your dice ends the same way, it becomes tedious and I no longer want to  play. In other words, when your game isn't allowing me to have fun, when every turn ends the same way despite the choices I make, there is a problem. I have encountered so many no win / stuck scenarios - and this happens the further you progress. Everything depends on chance in a way that is unfair and unfun rather than being unexpected and challenging. 

I've beaten FTL several times, don't get me wrong, I've died 10 times more than I've survived, but NEVER did I feel like my choices didn't impact my result - sure chance situations occur, but my cumulative choices in those situations still allowed or disallowed progression. 

I still think this game can be fixed with an update where they allow changes in difficulty and altering gameplay mechanics in the options menu. Also allow for the ability to create fuel and hull material using other materials (this may be currently allowable but after 10 playthroughts I still haven't experienced it). OH and please add a Move all resources to cargo button when probing or drilling. and/or keyboard hotkeys for pc. Thanks

But until then, your game might as well be telling me to simulate space by putting a plastic bag over my head.

author: {'steamid': '76561198026835681', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 1576, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1576, 'last_played': 1446742428}
review:
The perfect ambiance for a spatial exploration game. [b]I did enjoyed it[/b], just couldn't recommend because of the PC version, wich is only the copy/past of the phone version, without UI improvements.

The game itself is way too difficult to manage to end it with fun only. And it's not just difficult, it's frustrating.
The game is NOT balanced, unless events couldn't kill you randomly without hope of surviving at the very start of the adventure, but the very late game is fairly easy.
You have hundreds of stars to explore to end the game. One jump by five can kill you in many way than I can't enumerate it. You'll never have some help, tips, nothing. Die and learn about it, it's a pure die and retry.
So, it should be named "Beautiful space dying simulator 2015@".

But there's plenty of gameplay elements that make you just click again and again for nothing, redundantly, because the UI ergonomics isn't finished. It's so bad, it's almost killing the game.

As I said, all the content of this game is unbelievable, unique, great. So, just play for it, the ambiance, the amazingness of the storyboard, and watch you character die again and again, making you feel like a dumb empty nuts drifting into nicely colored space. Until you finally beat the game in the same glory as ending Dark Souls 1 in thief mode, with daggers only.
At least, it's realy, realy, immersive.

TIPS : By the way, to end it, you have to do every little possible improvement to your ressources management and pray a bit to find the right technology. You need to optimize random event and just forget about here. (like just keep 0-1% fuel after a jump, just in the case of you have to escape a big crazy monster and consume 30% of your fuel to do so. You will just use the 0-1% left, and still escape the evil guy. But don't joke with the hull or the oxygen, you're warned)

author: {'steamid': '76561198004570747', 'num_games_owned': 98, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 160, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 146, 'last_played': 1502505979}
review: Out There is a fantastic mix of game and story. Though the mechanics and resource management are challenging and fun, what really ties the game together is the tidbits of information, either directly linked to the real game or simply imaginative and beautiful in itself. It's a lovely game that I wholly recommend.

author: {'steamid': '76561197986003679', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 83, 'playtime_forever': 103, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 103, 'last_played': 1437207747}
review:
TL;DR Great theme and art spoiled by monotony and a heavy reliance on RNG. Always drill and probe 10/10. Focus is more on resource management than space exploration -- what could be a whismical journey is instead just looking for the next fill up station.

This game... this game would be awesome, if you weren't constantly concerned about finding the next gas giant to fill your tank or hoping you find a garden planet for oxygen. When you do, prepare for some inventory managment so you can stock up!

In the screenshots, the game seems like your main focus would be exploring strange new worlds, encountering life. And at some point in the game, maybe this does happen. But in my 2 hours of playtime, I couldn't manage to get past the first 10 or so galaxy hops. All this game was, in my experience, is drilling planets for materials, probing gas planets for fuel and hoping to the Random Number God that the game would bestow a planet with oxygen at some point so I didn't asphyxiate. Too many of my playthroughs ended simply because the game didn't randomly give me a planet with fuel, or a planet with oxygen. Reading the forums and guides, I do not see how I could have played differently; the game just didn't spawn what I needed, so it was a lost game no matter my choices. DYING TO RNG IS NOT FUN.

The game also has another false choice -- in the beginning, when drilling or probing for materials, the game presents a prompt for how deep you want to go, out of a scale of 10, where the higher number gives more of a chance of your tools breaking. Unless you knew ahead of time, you will waste you time until you find out that you ALWAYS, no matter what, go 10 out of 10. Repairing the tools is less than trivial, so 10/10 is always optimal. If you don't, you simply just waste more fuel and get less materials. 

Once you find this truth, the beginning game is monotonous -- you simply hop galaxy to galaxy, consuming planets like Galactus, waiting until the game starts to throw some random event so you can actually start making any sort of decisions. By this point, I was too bored. You still have to hope that the game spawns what you need and doesn't just not give you oxygen until you die. I'd rather have more agency determining the outcome of my run.

author: {'steamid': '76561197977451962', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 287, 'playtime_forever': 41, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 41, 'last_played': 1437183113}

author: {'steamid': '76561198004701225', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 130, 'playtime_forever': 670, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 670, 'last_played': 1437346991}
review:
Wow this is beautiful.
Wow it's too hard to enjoy it.

Hey all, let's have a quarter flipping contest. Whoever can flip heads the most times out of a thousand wins. After that we can have a dice rolling contest.
Oh oh I have an idea, let's make a board game where you advance a token down a path, each turn rolling three dice, and if any of them is a 1, you go back to the beginning. It'll be a great game.

No really. This is a beautiful game but I'm only going to enjoy looking at the beginning of it so many times, even if it's a randomly generated beginning.
If they wanted it to seem like it was closer to the reality of space travel by making it harsh and unforgiving, then I don't understand why they included fantasy things like warp drives. They could've just made a game where you start flying to another star in a conventional spacecraft and die of old age 0.000001% of the way there.  Or why did they even include starting again when you die. That's not real. If it were realistic you'd game over once and then the game would delete itself. None of this endlessly repeating early stages of a journey, you'd just see the early stages once and that'd be it.

What's the point of this design mentality really? What does it achieve? A game I can't actually play, is all I see here. A game where a player unexpectedly loses all progress due to circumstance beyond their control - you can frame it as "game over" but it's an effect identical to a game with bugs that cause it to crash randomly.

[b]edit 1:[/b] Okay switching it to a positive review(this review was initially negative). I'm not going to just wipe the original review because it serves as a good example of what a first impression of this game looks like. It's up to the readers of this review, maybe I'm an extremely wishy-washy person, or maybe this game's mechanics are really off-putting. I was reluctant to check negative to begin with because it's a really beautiful game.
So anyway I got far enough to get one ending out of four, seven hours logged but who knows how many runs. Ask for/read advice in the forums as to how to do the game, play it enough times, discover the RNG can be managed.....sort of. Maybe I just had a really lucky run. The game tutorial could offer some hints on the game's strategy at least to soften the blow of that first 3 hours. I'm no stranger to games with lots of RNG, I play Hearthstone of all things, so I'm used to the idea of considering things like order of operations to minimize risk, but the strategies here weren't readily apparent and I doubt I'd have found some key points on my own(there's a trick thats pretty counter-intuitive but makes all the difference: [spoiler]always drill/probe on 10, it only takes iron to repair the equipment breaks, iron is common, if the equipment is destroyed and requires a different resource to rebuild it will drop right then, and positive events are also possible in addition to the breaks[/spoiler]).

author: {'steamid': '76561198032537451', 'num_games_owned': 1276, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 66, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 66, 'last_played': 1437159721}
review:
I bought this game because it looks eerily similar to FTL. Be aware, it is far from a similar experience. 

Although I did enjoy the fact that there was a storyline incorporated into the game, this is for me the only positive aspect of the game. The game is designed around resource management and strategy; however, I found myself desperate to keep my ship moving. Every action you take requires fuel... even OBTAINING MORE FUEL! To a degree, this works but the amount of fuel consumed felt excessive. Combined with the constant bad-luck events and the inability to carry resources from one game to the next, it leaves you with a game session that ended in failure within minutes (ie. not enough time for strategy to even play a part).

There are many other rouguelike, resource management games out there. This one doesn't have the balance to be playable. After attempting for an hour to enjoy the game, I have requested a refund--something I've never done for any other game before.

author: {'steamid': '76561198007579261', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 63, 'playtime_forever': 939, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 899, 'last_played': 1598884086}
review:
I generally do enjoy the game, but the inventory system is a problem, as it's a problem in every game that tries to bodge a clumsily restrictive tile inventory together. Music's perfect, atmosphere's evocative, art is simple while suiting the game well, but the design isn't [i]quite[/i] there for me to recommend this game without reservation. Still largely worth a buy, I'd say. And if you don't like it, get a refund - easy.

Edit: I'm going to change this to a no simply because there are too many design shortcomings that negatively impact the experience. The inventory is a major factor in the way it paints you into a corner or creates arbitrary crises simply through bad design. I don't mind losing in a difficult but fair game, but the game wasting my time because it's poorly designed is inexcusable. 

I'll give an example: in the course of the game you need to gather and stock various rare elements (like gold, thorium, platinum, etc.) in order to build and repair some of the more exotic ship modules. Good so far. The problem is that the ships you're flying will generally tend to be between 14-16 tiles, with a good 2/3 of those taken up by essential ship hardware, leaving maybe 6-7 to store cargo in. You want to be stocking full 20-stacks of essentials like iron, hydrogen, oxygen, or helium if you can get your hands on it, but rare elements you only use for repairs, or the omega element that's essentially a wild card, all MUST take up an entire cargo hold even if you only have 1. So if you have 1 omega, 3 hafnium, 3 gold, 8 thorium, and 5 platinum, that's FIVE of your 6 cargo holds used for storing crumbs of rare elements that you need to mitigate RNG with. In a sane world these crumbs (that incidentally total up to 20) would only take up one tile of space. Where's the iron, helium, hydrogen, and oxygen going to fit? Nowhere. Something needs to go overboard, and sure enough, as soon as you dump it, you'll get a random event that requires the element you threw away. It's like the developers, or all the people giving this game awards, never bothered to play it.

This is 3/4 of a good game, with the last quarter being lazily programmed and amateurishly designed garbage, as is distressingly common with a lot of these games that rely on their music, writing, or art direction to draw people in, like Don't Starve, Sunless Sea, and several other overrated culprits. It's like going to a restaurant with attractive ambiance, a great band, and being served a perfectly arranged meal that tastes like cat vomit. 

Developers, fix your fuckin' game; it isn't too late. This game is already highly modular and begging to be expanded on (orbiting derelicts, trade posts, maybe a little space combat hazard to use the Resistance stat, stealth - emission sinks, etc.). An inventory fix, and fixes for a few other imperfections, would be just the thing to throw in there.

author: {'steamid': '76561198098320371', 'num_games_owned': 987, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 577, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 219, 'last_played': 1606958079}
review:
YES !  I bought it and the second i started the game, i knew it was worth it.
     It kinda is in the style of the game ''FTL'', but ''Out there'' is more on the resource management/survival aspect compared to ''FTL''s combat driven storyline.
      I will stop comparing the two xD, Out there is awesome , has a lot of replayability (which is something i love in a game), It's randomness is another thing i love <3 ( the RNG can be both forgiving or merciless, depends on how it feels at the moment -3- ).

All in all, a great game, totally recommend it ! <3

Happy gaming people !

author: {'steamid': '76561198103620840', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 129, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 129, 'last_played': 1437209923}
review:
The concept is cool but its repetitive and frustrating always doing the same things. Its ok to survive but most gaz holding planets are doomed and destroy your ship. So you end up always getting irons for repairs and it cost gaz to drill it. 
You have to find planet wit gaz but again its breaking up your ship. In between you have to invest gaz for finding oxygen and inhabitants. Its a vicious cycle who gonna make you kill yourself of boredom and frustration.

author: {'steamid': '76561198026368052', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 174, 'playtime_forever': 644, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 249, 'last_played': 1579935735}

author: {'steamid': '76561198021172451', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 47, 'playtime_forever': 473, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 400, 'last_played': 1471157656}
review:
I can't stop playing this game. At first it seemed really simple, but then as I delved deeper, I realized just how deep this game really can be. The story of your solitary life, alone. out there.

I've gone insane and destroyed my own ships equipment, launched clear across the universe to a star far far away from where I just was, I've had aliens speak strange words to me, only to scream in terror and run away, leaving some valuable resources.

It is impossible to sum up this game adequately. Suffice to say, well worth what they are asking for, for it.

author: {'steamid': '76561197980526251', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 267, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 267, 'last_played': 1437603319}
review: More of a choose your own adventure style game as opposed to a tactical game.  Music is atmospheric and i found it rather soothing.  Don't go into this game thinking its FTL, its not.  It's a story told by the protaginist as he desperatly tries to make his way to back home.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025316942', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 2793, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 812, 'last_played': 1540098987}
review:
A contemplative, atmospheric Roguelike, "Out There" has gorgeous art and interesting challenges. Sure, eventually you'll solve most of the encounters and events - making the game's replay value limited to a few tens of hours, I suppose - but it's well worth the cost.

This is not the game for everyone - it requires patience and reading to fully enjoy, and the desire to learn and remember the "right" outcome of various events - but it's a game I can appreciate, a game that stirs the imagination the way most games these days just can't do. A game that has a story which you can get invested in, paradoxically because you know just how likely it is that the story will end with the phrase "This is the end of my journey."

One word of advice: If you have a large tablet or touchscreen laptop, I'd get this game for the tablet instead. The mouse is not the ideal control scheme for this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198151222054', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 32, 'playtime_forever': 402, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 212, 'last_played': 1527186972}
review:
What can i say. Great Game. The exploring and have to manage all the resources, plus all the unexpected thing that happen to you, making it a great game. It is not easy at all, but i like that. You will die a lot out there in the depth of space, but you will find your way home, i still have to haha. This Game is a gem for people who like those kind of games, so dont just read there, buy it. I notice that a lot of heart went into this game and can only say well done.

9,5/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198028390380', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 134, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 103, 'last_played': 1523074912}
review:
Ever wonder what a crippling sense of hopelessness in the middle of nowhere, where any decison you make could potentially be as much of a boon as it could a crushing blow to your already dwindling chances of survival? Or maybe truely feeling alone; the last of your kind, stranded out in an unforgiving and uncaring universe? Ever wonder what it's like to be... Out There?

This game is best played in a dark, quiet, secluded space. The art in phenominal, and though it still does kind of feel like a mobile game, the changes they made to "Out There: Œ© Edition" are enough to give it an entirely different experience... as if every time you start a new game it isn't already entirely different.

author: {'steamid': '76561197963441362', 'num_games_owned': 330, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 141, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 141, 'last_played': 1436119383}
review:
I wanted to like this "game" I really did. 

In my first few moments the story was interesting, the setting compelling, and the artwork beautiful. 

The gameplay is however very deeply flawed and heavily reliant on luck (each game you play the universe and it's inhabitants are randomly generated) and acts as a barrier to enjoyment rather than a source.

If this game could either improve the frustrating and flawed gameplay or just remove it so I could enjoy the story it would be an instant recomend.

As it stands, I can not recomend this game and have refunded it (thank you steam for finally implimenting a refund system)

For people who just want to know what the gameplay is like, i'll give you a run-down of my various failed playthroughs.

You start the game in one corner of the galaxy map and your objective is to reach the opposite corner, you jump short distances from star-to-star just like in FTL, but unlike FTL there is no combat.

Instead the "challenge" comes in the fact that each jump consumes rediculous portions of your fuel and you can only obtain very small ammounts of it by "probing" gas giant planets.

How do you find a gas giant planets? you jump to a star system and hope one of the 0-3 planets it will randomly generate is a gas giant.

In the 4 seperate attempts I made to play through the game less than 30% of the star systems I encountered had any gas giants at all. 

Once you DO find a gas giant, you probe it for gas resources, you are only allowed to extract a small ammount before you are told "there is nothing else here" as though your very tiny vessel had absorbed the entierty of a jupiter-sized planet. 

If, and I stress IF, you are lucky enough to find one of the 2 gasses that count as fuel instead of one of the many that don't you find just barely more fuel than you spent obtaining it. 

Unfortunately you also damaged your ship orbiting the planet (this happens on every planet no matter what, aparently your ship is made out of balsa wood) so you will need metal to repair the damage, which means spending tons of fuel finding, landing on, and drilling a planet with metalic resources. 

Doing THAT, consumes more fuel than you could replace by visiting a dozen gas giants, oh and landing on this planet ALSO damages your hull, and when you drill into the planet to get the also dumbfoundingly-limited metalic resources you flip a coin and either damage or destroy the drill you used to do so. 

There's a less risky way to drill but it consumes much more fuel.

So I tried, I really really REALLY tried to like this game, the alien encounters seemed neat, the music and art was interesting, but you end up spending each game sucking d**k for gass, and STILL end up dying around your 5th planet no matter WHAT because you either run out of gas or metal.

Even THIS could be solved by carefully designing the planets you will reach and the order in which you will reach them, to ensure that a crafty player will always be able to squeak by if he manages his resources correctly and takes the right risks at the right time.

But designing a galaxy map takes time and effort, and writing a script to randomly generate the galaxy adds "replayability" and "challenge" to the game via rendering 9 out of 10 generated maps impossible to complete, and like corporations and stuff and like man it's an like an experience man, and you're entitled and stuff.

review: This game is without a doubt fun, entrancing, and above all else, frustrating as all hell. A good strategy will only get you so far before RNG fucks you hard. I got very far with a spherical ship that ran on Carbon (making it much easier to collect fuel and therefore keep going) But then my tao stasis broke and i had no way of repairing it, leaving me stranded around a blue dwarf star not able to reach any other star system. Buy this game if you want good challanging fun and lots of frustration. It's a love/hate relationship I have with this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198030752592', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 1091, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1003, 'last_played': 1435017349}
review:
Running out of fuel: The game.
This is a mixed review.

The game is solid at what it focuses on: environment and isolation. The scenery and soundtrack are both enjoyable and engrossing, while the challenge of surviving alone in an indifferent universe will engage you for many hours.

Where the game fails however is in the execution of the resource management and randomized systems. Limited cargo space makes stockpiling difficult, while the sparsity of gas giants for fuel makes it all but impossible to actually net fuel in the long run. I've had games where I had 3 stacks of stockpiled fuel and a full tank and I lose anyway because the next series of systems I visited had no sources of fuel. Games. Plural. 

In 30+ games I've yet to get more than halfway to the target systems at the far end of the map and that was only because an event teleported me much closer (only to leave me stranded because I didn't have the jump distance systems to get out of the cluster). I can understand some difficulty, but the journal entries, encounters, and events start feeling stale and repetitive after seeing them the second or third time in a playthrough because you've not gotten that golden game where everything goes right.

This is compounded by some UI oddities that stem from the game's mobile origin. Lack of many simple shortcuts makes for tedious management of things. To get more fuel you send out the Hydrogen Probe and it returns with whatever it found. Rather than being able to put it directly into your tank from this screen, you have to switch over to the ship view and drop it into the fuel tank there before switching back over to the planet screen to probe for more fuel. Rather than a button to empty everything from a probe or drill or double clicking to transfer to cargo, everything is drag and drop or rightclick to select transfer to cargo (then watch the game drag and drop it for you, meanwhile you can do nothing but wait for it). Normally these wouldn't be an issue in a game, but when you're doing this a dozen times at every gas giant you go exploring for fuel, it gets massively tedious.

Abandoned ships you encounter are often side-grades from the shuttle you start in. The few ships that are larger have oddties or are in need of serious repairs before you can use the extra space they afford; the few ships that are smaller only amplify the resource storage problem.

The technologies you find are interesting to find but don't help much and are an uncommon find if you don't get lucky with finding the right tech and the resources for it. The new modules save a small portion of your resources by taking up space where you could have stored them in the first place. I imagine finding three or four would actually make for a much more efficient ship, but again the problem is luck in finding them.

I will likely continue to play to try to find some closure for the plot, but as it stands for me I don't hold much hope of ever finding it. Such is the drawback of random generation and encounters: Some players don't get lucky.

Despite these flaws it is a solid game of exploration and resource management. I encountered no bugs or glaring issues while playing. If you enjoy exploration and atmospheric games, grab a touchscreen and this will be an enjoyable experience for many hours.

author: {'steamid': '76561197988451613', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 75, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 75, 'last_played': 1431233984}
review: My job puts me on the road a lot. That has created a new hole in my gaming experience, and it was filled by games like Out There.  While flying or sitting at the airport, I didn't have time to get into a large time consuming gaming experience. I still wanted something fun and intriguing.  Enter, Out There!  The story and commentary is sometimes funny and always deep. Take a few minutes to explore or a 5 hour flight to DC. It's up to you and the time wont be wasted.

author: {'steamid': '76561198131530092', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 360, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 291, 'last_played': 1433860062}
review:
Out There √©tait un bon jeu, son √©dition Omega l'est √©galement. Enrichi de tr√®s beaux environnements par rapport √† sa version de base ainsi que d'une fin suppl√©mentaire, ce jeu ne vous laissera pas indiff√©rent. M√©lange de livre-jeu et de jeu de gestion, Out There regorge de tr√®s bonnes id√©es, d'une qualit√© d'√©criture ind√©niable et d'une bande-son fabuleuse.

N√©anmoins, une fois la bonne strat√©gie de survie adopt√©e, la difficult√© du jeu est bien moindre, et voir toutes les fins du jeu ne demandera pas √©norm√©ment de temps. La rejouabilit√© du titre est faible, et ne vous attendez pas √† y jouer plus de 6  ou 7 heures (ce qui n'est pas ridicule non plus, comprenons-nous).

Je recommande ce jeu pour les amateurs de science-fiction, qui seront ravi de d√©couvrir un espace tr√®s riche, inspir√© notamment pas les ≈ìuvres de M≈ìbius. Pour les autres, pourquoi ne pas laisser sa chance √† cette petite p√©pite spatiale ? Elle pourrait bien vous s√©duire.

author: {'steamid': '76561198057581347', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 180, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 180, 'last_played': 1434336177}
review:
Pros:
Beautiful graphics/illustrations. It's like FTL, but prettier. 
Lots of interesting story elements. 

Cons:
The game gets repetitive too quickly. While the story has constanly new and different elements, even that loses its flavor after awhile, because unlike FTL, which had more immediacy to it... there is very little driving force to push you forward. Your focus is to keep your ship going... but you are severely limited in how you can do that, 

The new technologies you can discover seem neat at first, until you realize they don't tend to do all that much differently or improve the gameplay all that much. Your ship is extremely limited. You can actually discover new ships, apparently, which does improve things, but there is no garuntee of this and the existing ship has very little space in it. It seems like poor design decisions led to combining your cargo with the slots to install your new tech in. I don't recall you ever being limited in cargo in FTL and that is one of my big gripes here. Plus, in FTL, you could easily expand various capabilities of your ship beyond just new tech you can install. The tech seems more varied in Out There, but also far more limited. 

Having to micromanage your cargo space is annoying, because while all the elements you can find have info on them, most of these elements are pretty much useless unless you stumble across the right technology that requires these elements to build. 

Also, if you go to a breathable atmosphere planet and immediately fill up your O levels, why can you not also fill up as much inventory of O as possible? I would have to drill for it, and still too often get too little. The balance of elements to drill or probe for seems out of whack. Also, more often than not, it seemed like a waste to drill or probe a second time, as it produced little to nothing in addition. I would think drilling 2-3 times could still yield some good resources, at least more often than not. Otherwise, why is there an option to drill or probe a second time other than to waste your resources? Just make it only doable once and be done with it. 

I played through three times, and got better each time, but mainly, I stuck very strictly to doing very specific things, because otherwise, it is way too easy to run out of resources in this game. 

FINAL SUM UP:
I think if I didn't have such limited cargo space and the elements were not quite so out of whack when drilling... the game would play better for me. It is in many ways a more laid back kind of game compared to FTL, which has combat and the risk of being attacked if you explore too much... and I want to like this game for the graphics and story, but it seems like there isn't enough of a game to really make it worth more than a few playthroughs. Maybe if there was more story that a player can actively get involved with, but it is all so passive, almost like a visual novel you can die in and have to do a little bit of work in, but mostly, just... yeah. 

So I cannot really recommend it... very lightly, very mixed. .

review: Every now and then, culture is made that instantly connects with me.  I've always found myself lost in daydreams of deep space exploration, in which the beauty of the void surrounds me, but the danger and loneliness are strangely close.  Out There: Omega Edition perfectly combines the unending novelty of wandering through space with a constant sense of uneasy solitude and imminent death.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970922684', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 690, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 168, 'last_played': 1471899152}
