author: {'steamid': '76561197993661434', 'num_games_owned': 7148, 'num_reviews': 144, 'playtime_forever': 365, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 294, 'last_played': 1704525547}
review:
[H1]Space is a lonely, distant place, especially when you're... out there...[/H1]

FTL did raw panic, and the sheer urgency of a space based roguelite. Mi-Clos's approach to the genre, and indeed the space based roguelite is to go quite literally in the opposite direction. You do not have time constraints as such, as long as you can keep yourself fuelled, repaired and stocked with oxygen you can bumble around the galaxy as much as you like. Instead, what it provides is a sense of overwhelming scale, and of loneliness. This game is crafted around an uncaring universe, a mind-boggling huge, and often lonely place.

[H1]Start at FTL, turn left at the first jump...[/H1]

The similarities between this and FTL are entirely superficial, you have jump points that you work between, like a spiders web, and jumping between them will burn resources. Like in FTL there's a slew of different spaceships, all with their own idiosyncrasies. That's where the similarities end though, there is no crew in this game, there's only you. There are no weapons to speak of, there are some terraforming tools and a planet killing device which can radically alter the story, but those are special case items. There's no combat, instead you're evading the enemy as you work towards whatever destination you head to, there are no merchants to buy supplies from, instead you're mining and scooping resources and fuel as you go.

You construct your own devices which are then installed into your ship, each device eats up precious cargo space that could be given over to fuel (which you will go through rapidly), repair metals (which you will also go through fairly rapidly) and oxygen (which you will go through less rapidly but you'll come across less often). The game is finely balanced and often you'll find yourself a few jumps away from disaster, where a few bad judgment calls in a row will see your game ended.

[H1]And it's not just your ship that is out to kill you...[/H1]

Even more critically, you start each game with zero knowledge of the alien language, which is randomised each time, so you will learn the words of importance with each encounter, gradually building up your auto-translator and being able to answer their queries and make trades with them as you go further into the galaxy. The very first encounters where you're stumbling over a few words and having to take almost blind guesses based on the positions of the words "Love" "Hate" "Death" or "Life" can often lead to unintentional hilarity.

[H1]I'm flying through the golden age of comics...[/H1]

The presentation in this game warrants special mention. Both the graphical design and sound presentation are literally off the scale. The graphics are presented in this retro sci-fi comic book approach, with everything done out in this comic book presentation of how space would look as if it were presented in a late 60's / early 70's era comic book The ships, planets, alien races, are all lavished with attention and the environments are spared no expense when it comes to the love and care that's gone into them. 

These are places you -want- to visit, time and again. Furthermore the soundtrack that layers on top of this is easily up there with FTL as one of the most suitable and listenable in the genre, it really conveys the loneliness of being in deep space, of being alone in an alien galaxy and trying to find your way with precious few resources and fewer allies. This eerie, sweeping soundscape is of such a high standard I [b]actively recommend buying the OST alongside the game[/b].

[H1]A place you'll lose yourself in time and again...[/H1]

Deeply replayable, tough to the point of occasionally being unforgiving, but always rewarding with new, gorgeous planets, and amazing encounters, along with starships designed with as much love and care as the comic book spaceships of old. This is a game that if you loved FTL, you simply cannot afford to pass up. It deserves your attention if you have any love of the roguelite genre at all, and it's a great place to start even if you're fairly new to these types of games.

Verdict : [b]Essential, especially for the soundtrack, and especially for fans of FTL[/b]

author: {'steamid': '76561198071423487', 'num_games_owned': 252, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 103, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 72, 'last_played': 1524206528}
review: I honestly didn't think that I would like this game.  It's a bit like the Oregon Trail in Space... Except, you're going to die, and quite often.  But the fun of the game lies in the fact that no two playthroughs are ever quite the same.  I've played on mobile, and now the Omega Edition here on Steam (at least 10 or so hours now between the two).  Even though I'm restarting because I keep running out of fuel, or my hull cracks, each star brings a different journal entry or some new encounter that is different from the last time.  Masterfully crafted in my opinion, deceptively simple and punishing, but keeps you coming back for more.

author: {'steamid': '76561198018381921', 'num_games_owned': 352, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 391, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 211, 'last_played': 1444767533}
review:
There are no space battles, instead this game excels at what it does: pushing your decision making skills to the edge for survival. In FTL you might be deciding now and then whether to buy more hull hitpoints, fuel or another crewmember, and that will keep you alive for another sector or so (hopefully). In Out There you'll have to decide whether another jump to a planet with metals instead (costing fuel) won't kill you because the next jump's random event suddenly drains your fuel so much and the planets there (and possibly that of the next two jumps) are completely impossible to recover from. 

This may sound unnecessarily punishing, but at some point you can get the hang of it (it's just a tough pill to swallow if you thought you could build up some kind of comfort zone). After some failures I could see how there's really that need for optimizing every decision towards maximum survival possibilities, and for example forcing me to have to deal with my habit of loot hoarding. It took me a while to figure out that demolishing ship parts to rebuild them later can grant extra logistical options, and how to take the expense of such actions into account through those tough decisions you have to make. I still fail miserably at it, but that's just testament to how well this game is designed around the deep drive for survival.

I'd say, abstract thinkers and problem solvers alike may like this game very much, it's more of a puzzle from some points of view, but the theme is still there, very well integrated into the gameplay. If you are more into the action that FTL's space battles granted, I'm afraid you won't find it here. This game pushes you to the limits just as much, but to the sense of a more strategic view on things, rather than tactically. And you need it, to survive in space, you need to do everything to extend your potential lifespan because space is scary like that, and this game conveys that just perfect.

author: {'steamid': '76561198010211998', 'num_games_owned': 535, 'num_reviews': 30, 'playtime_forever': 1405, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1037, 'last_played': 1644476547}
review: This is a contemplative game. It's part optimization problem, part choose-your-own-adventure. There's a lot to discover, and the atmosphere is very intriguing, but the biggest challenge is managing the very small amount of storage space on your ship. I think I'd be more immersed in the adventure part if I weren't constantly worried about finding resources to survive and making trade-offs with cargo space, but it's still very worthwhile. Plus, I love analyzing the randomized alien languages across playthroughs; it's sort of a meta-game puzzle that I'm not sure if the developer intended or not.

author: {'steamid': '76561198023477015', 'num_games_owned': 185, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 241, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 207, 'last_played': 1432684342}
review:
A very pretty but profoundly repetitive and underdeveloped game.

The basic gameplay revolves around a route procedure you will repeat throughout the game, and won't really be fundamentally changed much by any tech upgrades you acquire (more on that later). These are as follows:
[list]
[*] Travel to the nearest solar system to the bottom-right, and pray that you can reach a yellow system before your oxygen runs out.
[*] Wait for five-second travel cutscene to play out, every single time. (And disable it in the menu after the third jump.)
[*] Handle whatever random event the game throws at you by selecting one of two-four options, most of which will either drain or supply a varying amount of your three resources, or warp you to the other buggering side of the galaxy.
[*] Depending on which of your 0-100 resource counters is lowest, warp to either the gas planet in the system (if your fuel is low) or the rock planet (if your hull strength is low). If your oxygen is low, and you're not in or adjacent to a yellow system, you're dead; hit the convenient 'give up' button and return to step 1. If you still have enough resources to make each little hop, and your equipment isn't fried from the random event you get warping into the system, then congratulations; extract your resource of choice and hope that the RNG gives you more than the resources you spent to get there.
[*] Jump out of the system with whatever generic resources you managed to eke out, or the vain hope that you'll be able to scrounge some in the next system. Repeat.
[/list]
You will perform these actions, most of which take about 5-6 clicks; "are you [i]sure[/i] you want to spend the 6 fuel/3 oxygen to take off from the planet, even though you have no other means to proceed in the game, and if you can't afford that you're dead anyway?", for the rest of the game. Ultimately, you're hoping that when the starmap finally lets you reach a yellow system and land on the garden planet, that you can somehow guess correctly from the gibberish the alien there will spout at you and get a technology/vocabulary unlock and some of that [strike]cheaty-filler-'we-made-this-game-too-miserly'-element[/strike] sweet sweet "[b]omega[/b]" element. These three things are the only way you can make the game any easier; though you're still going to be relying ultimately on the beneficence of the RNG. I'll cover these in particular, as (aside from the plot which you will never get lucky enough to progress in) they're the only bit of gameplay you're going to get.

[h1]1. Vocabulary[/h1]
Every time you try and contact life on a garden planet (the most reliable way to progress), and in some of the random events entering a system, some of the words will be gibberish until you randomly unlock translations; all of them with alien contact, some of them during the random events. Until you've survived long enough to be randomly awarded enough linguistic acumen to be able to guess-the-blanks, you won't know if the alien you're talking to is asking for a pinch of hydrogen or is accusing of being the spawn of satan. Don't worry though, he won't have a gun or pose any real threat to you; unlike the random event where you come across a giant space-box with nothing but "Gizzelthorpe" written on it and you'll have to guess whether it'll repair your hull or feed you to the giant space-kraken.

[h1]2. Technology[/h1]
You ever wanted a shield generator, so you didn't take so much damage trying to scoop up a little fuel, and could maybe save up enough iron to repair your telescope? Here, have three schematics for upgrades that you already need to have the shield generator for, and oh by the way the same random event also erased your schematic for the fuel probe. [i]Why/how did that tooth-worm alien thing give me a schematic for blowing up systems into black holes?[/i] you may ask; [i]Why would I ever want to do that, when I can't get anything from black holes and they still need fuel to travel to?[/i], [i]Why does it only cost two iron and a gold nugget to build?[/i] I don't know. But you will get this as your first piece of technology, five games in a row, while you exhaust your last bit of fuel warping into a neutron star.

[h1]3. Omega[/h1]
This is apparently the coolest little element in the game, which half of the aliens you talk to will chuck at your feet faster than you can say [i]donde es el bano[/i]. Congratulations, you can now spend the next ten jumps gripping it with white knuckles and trying not to spend its juicy 25-fuel-oxygen-or-hull bonus while wondering why you can't just get a single damn mote of cobalt to build that engine upgrade you need. Eventually, you will be out of options, and you will use it. An alien will give you another, and you'll do the math and realize that it doesn't even cover the cost of warping into the system, landing on the planet, and taking off again. But hey, if your drill needs repairs and you can't find any iron, at least you can spend the most valuable resource in the game to fix it.


Why am I here? Are we alone in space? Is there a god? Did this really have to be a 3-click operation? [b][u]Out There[/u][/b] will make you ask all these questions and many more; like "why does getting attacked by a blob of anti-matter hurt less than orbiting a gas giant" and "is this game in early access or something?". And in truth; there's a lot of neat stuff in this game. It's mostly a shame that you don't get to sit back and appreciate it because the gameplay is so blandly frustrating.  I think the best way to approach this game is as a shiny graphic novel, interrupted intermittently by by route gameplay.

This game is kind-of disappointing, but I'll probably spend a few more hours cursing at the Ansible upgrade, [i]What alien space fleets?! I haven't [b]SEEN[/b] any godamn spacefleets![/i], before I give up entirely.

author: {'steamid': '76561198042608365', 'num_games_owned': 364, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 270, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 263, 'last_played': 1540929925}
review: Out There is a game for a type of person, i admit. but i am that type of person. It is a difficult game until you understand what you should be doing. so if you're not looking for a challenge or..reading then this isnt the game for you. Very similar to FTL: Faster Than Light but you Vs. encounters instead of enemy ships. Very much a recommended game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198006626799', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 465, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 360, 'last_played': 1432661506}
review: Are you looking for game in cosmic style with crafting and want to use brain but not too much? You have free time but you don't have to play all night long? It's the best game for you. Simple game but probably you won't pass it in a few hours. If you plan to play like 6 or more hour a day you gonna get bored.

author: {'steamid': '76561198057225018', 'num_games_owned': 1524, 'num_reviews': 61, 'playtime_forever': 341, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 341, 'last_played': 1431879211}
review: I just love the little stories.

author: {'steamid': '76561197967424242', 'num_games_owned': 866, 'num_reviews': 64, 'playtime_forever': 50, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 50, 'last_played': 1431712390}
review: I've loved this game since it was on Android. This is the PC version and has some updates, but the core game is still the same. It's a "survive as long as you can" game, similar to FTL. The randomness of FTL does not seem to be a problem with Out There, but there is also less action. After a while, it does seem to drag because of the lack of options, but that is a long and frustrating while (frustrating in a good way)

author: {'steamid': '76561197992358612', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 104, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 103, 'last_played': 1435090670}
review:
If you loved FTL like I do be cautious about your hopes for this game. This game is not for me and it might not be for some of you either.
There are two main reasons i dislike this game already;

Firstly it bugs out to the point of game breaking. 
My first run found me having just collected the resources I needed to make one of the new systems I had found. The UI then suddenly failied on me, getting stuck on the cargo bay screen. There was little i could do but return to the main menu and continue the game, finding that it had actually saved me in the last solar system. Annoying no? 
That it happened on my third run twice more is a pretty big flaw for a supposedly finished product.

Secondly, and this is a matter of opinion, it's very monotonous and grindy.
Most of what you will do is visit solar systems and its planets to find resources so you can make it to the next couple of solar systems. You may meet an alien life form or find tech for ship systems, and they seem to mostly be enhancing your current systems). Like. Yaaay.
I did find a couple of interesting scenarios, but after getting 20/30 solar systems in I really didn't feel engrossed.

This might be your thing but it aint mine, its a roguelike im not doing 5 runs of, this let alone 50, its got no hook for me to want to play it.
tl:dr games dull & buggy, buy this if you like dull & buggy

author: {'steamid': '76561198031438789', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 74, 'playtime_forever': 263, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 241, 'last_played': 1589870571}
review:
Nice easy game to get into and whilst simple in concept - gets very hard very quickly.

As others have said the game is completely random so each choice is your own to make and the exact consequences are unknown.

At its heart this is about being alone and having to discover stuff.  But it is also inventory management.  Do you keep the 9 gold you found in the hope that you might use this rare material, or do you give it up, not knowing when (if ever) you will find more.

The game plays very quickly so even perma death doesn't feel like you have wasted hours needlessly.

Overall, this is an FTL type variant (no combat, but rich story based exploration).

author: {'steamid': '76561198018405489', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 855, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 423, 'last_played': 1443664219}

author: {'steamid': '76561197960342736', 'num_games_owned': 1601, 'num_reviews': 280, 'playtime_forever': 128, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 26, 'last_played': 1434011927}
review:
Version PC d'un jeu mobile qui mise avant tout sur son √©criture plus que par son gameplay qui tourne plus autour de la chance qu'une quelconque strat√©gie. M√™me si des choix sont propos√©s au joueur lors de certains √©v√®nements, le caract√®re impr√©visible du r√©sultat obtenu fait qu'on ne peut pas prendre de "bonne" d√©cision √† moins de conna√Æutre le jeu par coeur. Cela est rendu encore plus difficile gr√¢ce √† la multitude d'√©v√®nements pr√©sents dans le jeu.

On a ici un jeu tr√®s bon sur le papier, qui p√™che un peu par son c√¥t√© al√©atoire mais qui ravira les amateurs de SF et de "livres dont vous √™tes le h√©ros". Je pense n√©anmoins que le jeu a plus sa place sur mobile gr√¢ce √† ses parties relativement courtes.

author: {'steamid': '76561198095531273', 'num_games_owned': 352, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 308, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 228, 'last_played': 1511478846}
review:
Magnifique jeu,

Ce jeu est un tr√®s bon roguelike, la gestion y est vraiment importante et bien d√©finit par les besoins vitaux en premier( O¬≤, H-He et Fer) puis par la suite des autres mat√©riaux pour am√©liorer sont vaisseau afin d'augmenter ses capacit√©s et de diminuer les consommations globales des ressources lors des diff√©rents voyages entre les syst√®mes et les plan√™tes.

L'apprentissage des langues extra-terrestre y est importante et un jolie petit plus nous permettant d'√™tre plus immerg√© dans l'univer du jeu. On peut √©changer avec eu afin de d√©bloquer des t√©chnologies et r√©cup√©rer l'omega qui peut servire autant √† r√©parer un √©quipement cass√©, remplir les jauges de besoin du vaisseau ,actionner un terraformeur ou bien d√©clancher une arme capable de d√©truire un syst√®me par l'explosion de son soleil. 

La narration aussi y est un point important tant√¥t elle nous permet de gagner des bonus, tant√¥t de nous mettre des b√¢tons dans les roues ou nous donner des choix qui vont influencer pour l'un ou l'autre. Cette narration nous permet de nous sentir plus proche de notre personnage de ce qu'il ressent. 

Le vaisseau de base est l√† pour nous apprendre √† g√®rer avec le peu d'espace disponible et les √©quipements vitaux mais nous pouvons d√©couvrir des vaisseaux abandonn√©s soit pour l'aborder et le r√©cup√©rer soit pour r√©cup√©rer les ressources de celui-ci en d√©truisant l'√©quipement qui est dessus. Il y'a aussi des zones abim√©s qu'il faudra r√©parer avec du Cobalt afin d'avoir l'espace maximal pour les ressources et √©quipements.
( Petit √©v√©nement qui m'est arriv√© j'ai rencontr√©e un vaisseau plan√©te encore remplit de personne cryog√©nis√© que je pouvais r√©cup√©rer pour sauver et j'ai trouv√© cette aspect vraiment fort)

Graphiquement on en prend pleins les yeux les couleurs sont magnifique et les animations aussi pour un jeu venant d'un d√©veloppeur ind√©pendant. Le style BD rend parfaitement honneur √† ce jeu.

Pour moi un des meilleurs roguelike-gestion que j'ai pu jouer.

author: {'steamid': '76561197974002194', 'num_games_owned': 1646, 'num_reviews': 237, 'playtime_forever': 279, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 248, 'last_played': 1445011339}
review:
[table][tr][th][h1][b]FR[/b][/h1][/th][th][h1][u]Col√®re noire (Maj "Om√©ga", juillet 15)[/u] : [/h1][/th][th]v. 0 -[/th][/tr][/table]
Reponse au d√©v. : C'est toujours tragique d'avoir √† reprendre ses excuses et pourtant...
Tout d'abord, voici un lien vers la critique originale qui permis √† cet √©nergum√®ne de d√©noncer ma pr√©tendue haine et ainsi donner toute latitude √† la sienne (mais il est moins marrant que moi !) http://www.senscritique.com/jeuvideo/Out_There_Edition/critique/53110155

Alors comme √ßa, il se fait que les m√©diocres veulent l'argent, le succ√®s et 0 pens√©e n√©gative sur ce qu'ils font ? 
Et √† d√©faut on doit se cogner la psychologie du caf√© de la gare de dugenoux les 2 guirlandes ? Braves gens, je vous avais donn√© de bonnes raisons de ne pas toucher √† Out There, mais c'est son propre d√©veloppeur qui est venu s'humilier devant nous. Nous abreuvant de la b√©ance de sa prose, toute proche de celle de son titre. Et ses mots sauront vous dissuader mieux que moi de lui faire confiance.

Mauvais cr√©ateur, mauvais r√©dacteur et mauvais psychologue de surcro√Æt. Et c'est √ßa qui vient me jeter √† la figure ses 300K ventes, ou la publication Steam. Comme si publier un jeu ind√© √©tait le summum de triomphe de la volont√© humaine. Comme si c'√©tait un exploit, qui a lui seul justifierait que l'on s'aplatisse devant le fond de ce qui est publi√©. Des jeux sur Steam il en sort 50 par semaines et je ne vous apprendrais rien en vous disant que la majorit√© d'entres est passable ou inutile. 

J'intitule ma critique col√®re noire, j'emploie explicitement le terme "rage" et machin vient me mettre sous le nez comme une trouvaille grandiose que j'aurais de la haine ? √áa s'appelle de la passion, simplement. 
Voil√† qu'il questionne mes motivations, moi je les lui demande quand il porte son truc d'Android vers Steam ? Si je roule pour la gloire, tu roules pour quoi toi ? La cupidit√©, c'est √ßa qu'il faut comprendre ?! 
Pourquoi j'√©cris, je citerais bien L√©o Ferr√© tien. Il disait que les putes mettent leur cul dans la rue et en font de l'argent, tandis que lui, c'est ses id√©es qu'il envoie dans la rue pour faire de l'argent et jamais il n'en eut honte. 
Mais rassurez-vous, je n'√©cris ni pour la gloire ni pour l'argent, mais si on vous le demande dites-leur quand m√™me que Smithfield √©crit dans l'espoir d'aller un jour nager avec des dauphins. 

Alors voici une critique 100% sans haine (garanti)
N'achetez pas Out There. Ce jeu ne contient rien de neuf, n'apporte rien √† son genre, ni √† l'art, ni au joueur. Il ne vous donnera rien, vous serez le m√™me avant et apr√®s. Par ailleurs, remercions la providence qui nous permet maintenant de voir le triste sire derri√®re ce titre, gardez-vous de l'encourager ou il recommencera !

Je ne vous salue pas et ne veux pas de votre cl√© ou quoi que ce soit d'autre de vous.
developer_response:
Bonjour Smithfield.

Ici l'√©quipe de d√©veloppement de Out There. 

A titre exceptionnel, nous allons r√©pondre √† ta critique, chose que nous ne faisons jamais car nous consid√©rons qu'elle et elle seule parmi toutes les autres n'est pas informative sur ses d√©fauts mais pr√©judiciable et d'autant plus insultante √† titre personnel.

Les d√©veloppeurs du jeu "sans talent ni id√©es" que tu d√©nonces te lisent. Nous sommes 2. Nous avons fait ce jeu effectivement tr√®s modeste au final avec le minimum de ressources que nous avions. 

Nous sommes conscients de ses limites. Nous n'avons oblig√© personne √† l'achat. Nous avons √©t√© √† l'√©coute constante de toutes les remarques, techniques notamment, et avons d√©j√† d√©ploy√© en continu une vingtaine de patchs, bien que le jeu ait √©t√© parfaitement jouable d√®s sa sortie.

Out There est plus que la somme de ses composants, mais Out There, c'est le travail d'un graphiste reconnu (Gwen Vibancos), d'un musicien ultra reconnu sur la sc√®ne JV (ayant compos√© la musique d'Antichamber et de The Stanley Parable),
d'aventures diverses repr√©sentant l'√©quivalent de 40 000 mots, soit un petit roman de SF. 
Out There a √©t√© nomin√© (regarde sur la droite) √† des dizaines de distinctions et dans des pays (comme la Serbie ou la Russie) o√π le "buzz" fantasm√© que tu d√©nonces n'a pas prise.

Out There ne b√©n√©ficie pas d'un buzz. Nous n'avons aucune √©quipe marketing. Nous avons 0 budget pub.
Nous avons fait 300 000 ventes √† ce jour et nous avons tous supports confondus 20 000 critiques argument√©es positives, √©crites toutes par des joueurs ayant appr√©ci√© le jeu. Nous avons des centaines de letsplays sur Youtube.
Aucun n'a √©t√© pay√© car nous n'avons pas le budget.

Tu as le droit de hair un jeu, de te sentir flou√©. Tu as le droit de d√©verser ta haine et de nous faire du mal.

Mais ce que tu as fait est diff√©rent.

Tu as pris le travail de deux personnes qui n'avaient rien, qui se sont battus en d√©pit de toutes les difficult√©s (je t'invite √† lire notre carnet de d√©veloppement √† ce sujet : http://www.ulyces.co/fibretigre/carnet-de-bord-de-out-there/ ), difficult√©s dont tu fais partie d√©sormais, et qui ont quand m√™me sorti un jeu sur un mod√®le sain (le premium, sans subventions ni crowdfunding) et dans l'optique de proposer quelque chose de nouveau.

Tu as donc pris ce travail et tu as trait√© ces deux personnes de gens sans id√©es ni talent souhaitant exploiter les joueurs.
Tu nous calomnies en affirmant des choses fausses comme le fait que nous ayons des m√©caniques pour prolonger le jeu pour soumettre le joueur √† des publicit√©s alors que notre jeu mobile ne comporte aucune publicit√© car nous nous opposons √† ce principe.

Tu insultes aussi les joueurs (et des publications comme The Verge, le New Yorker, Forbes) en disant qu'ils sont aveugl√©s par des syst√®mes que seul toi semble comprendre.

Et cela tu le fais pour quoi ? Pour ta gloire. 

Tu mets un lien vers tes critiques et ton profil √† la fin. 

Personne n'est dupe de tes m√©thodes et surtout de tes objectifs.

Et bien malgr√© ta haine on va faire d'autres jeux. On sera toujours 2. On sera toujours l√† √† te r√©pondre.
Les gens aimeront nos jeux ou pas, mais tout comme pour Out There on fournira des jeux que nous aurons construit avec une vraie sinc√©rit√© de coeur et la volont√© de plaire aux joueurs, car nous ne sommes pas des financiers, mais des joueurs passionn√©s.

Et pour notre prochain jeu, d√©j√† tr√®s attendu par la critique, nous t'enverrons une copie gratuite comme cela tu pourras nous donner en exclusivit√© et avant tout le monde toute ta haine. 

Tu pourras aussi venir nous voir sur nos stands aux conventions pour nous dire √† quel point tu nous hais.

J'esp√®re que cela te fera du bien. J'esp√®re que tu pourras t'en vanter et montrer √† ceux qui te lisent combien tu es devenu un type important par ton commerce de la haine.

Mais nous ne changerons rien √† notre fa√ßon de fabriquer nos jeux - et √† ce qui nous motive √† en produire, c'est √† dire, en ce qui nous concerne, par amour des joueurs et du jeu.

author: {'steamid': '76561197996726659', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 928, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 716, 'last_played': 1581896350}
review:
Great game. People who are saying its a coin flip are playing sub-optimally, i can now probably win most of my runs now that I thought and optimized every aspect of this game.

Of course it was the same with FTL, after a couple days of play I was able to optimize the game very well and was able to finish it, once you feel like you are doing everything close to optimum there is not much desire left to play but its still great while you learn.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970538911', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 57, 'playtime_forever': 123, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 15, 'last_played': 1446668245}
review:
C'est le genre de jeu auquel le choix du joueur a tr√®s peu de r√©percussion (voir pas du tout). J'entend par l√† que quoique vous fassiez, vous pouvez perdre lamentablement et ce ne sera pas de votre faute puisque vous ne pouviez pas faire grand chose d'autre. Vous n'avez aucun contr√¥le ni aucune information. Ce n'est absolument pas √©quilibr√© et √† mon avis les d√©veloppeurs s'en fichent pas mal et de toute fa√ßon ne savent pas du tout comment faire. Il n'y a aucune tentative dans ce sens. En conclusion vous ne jouez pas vraiment mais subissez constamment. Au final ce n'est pas tr√©s amusant ni gratifiant.
Seulement pour du casual gaming, pour ceux qui veulent vraiment jouer, passez votre chemin.

author: {'steamid': '76561198066154957', 'num_games_owned': 595, 'num_reviews': 355, 'playtime_forever': 173, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 173, 'last_played': 1429625889}
review:
It's a whole lot better than FTL. 

Like FTL, you can upgrade your ship, and choose different options and see the outcomes, however, something this has, that FTL doesn't, is that in Out There, you can just explore forever and ever. There's so many different places to go. And solar systems. Such as blue giants, red dwarfs and supernovas. 

The music is calming and the art style is simple and sweet. The resources that you collect via finding, mining or catching from probes are used to research, build and repair equipment. Said equipment takes up slots, which, if needed, you are able to dismantle the equipment and get it's core components. 

You can also help other races, and ships. Aswell as board abandoned one and use them yourself. 

I cannot stress how good this is. I got it for 50% of the price (crafting coupon) but bloody hell, it's worth full price. Every single penny.

author: {'steamid': '76561198052236689', 'num_games_owned': 843, 'num_reviews': 110, 'playtime_forever': 949, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 947, 'last_played': 1429642943}
review:
I have fallen in love with this game. Yes, it seems pretty random until you get your tactics and priorities laid out, but once you got that in place, you do have a realistic chance of succeeding til the end.

The atmosphere, the soundtrack, the artwork and the perfectionist simplicity are just beautiful.

author: {'steamid': '76561198042147212', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 741, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 312, 'last_played': 1584818881}

Mon seul regret : vraiment trop al√©atoire, on aurait aim√© un peu plus de prises de d√©cisions, mais √ßa aurait √©t√© plus proche de FTL en ce cas... bref, je ne regrette pas d'avoir achet√© ce jeu et y joue avec plaisir.

author: {'steamid': '76561198030828143', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 72, 'playtime_forever': 1213, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1213, 'last_played': 1429467138}
review:
You can Play that game with only one Bug (a Bug that let your Ship Stuck in the Jumpanimation and you cant skip it you must leave and restart to play further annoing if you found something cool like a Tech bevore). BUT after you come near the first Mission marker the Game becomes more and more Buggy.

Textbars outside the Screen, you found a unique Missions ship again. Problem with that is that if you go there and check Cargo or go onboard the ship the game Breaks and you must Quit and restart your last save.

A nice Game with some Pice of art (Planetscreens, Stars etc..) but have still some Bugs.


My conclusion after I've managed to solve the game despite annoying bugs:

Contra:

- monotony since the variation of the planets and stars (the Pictures you see after you land or Orbit) repeats itself very quickly after some time. For a HUGE universe that is ridiculous.

- Constantly repeating tasks, rocky planet landing and drilling, gas planet /sun flying fuel collecting.

- Random elements to extreme. The whole game is a single dice.

- Random elements are good but you can also exaggerate.

- This is boring. A universe in which one has seen anything so fast? Too bad.

Pro:

- Some Nice Pictures

- Story Elements are good

- You must learn the Alien Language

- Different Ships and Technology Combinations

- Good Music

This Game is ok, but not a must have...

Try to get lucky by not getting hit with the wrong random event (e.g. losing half of your fuel.)  Try to avoid getting a string of randomly useless systems.

author: {'steamid': '76561197994666064', 'num_games_owned': 3746, 'num_reviews': 611, 'playtime_forever': 271, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 271, 'last_played': 1428111737}
review:

Voc√™ controla um astronauta que tinha J√∫piter como destino, mas acabou despertando da c√¢mara criog√™nica em um lugar aleat√≥rio do universo, ao encontrar uma esta√ß√£o espacial alien√≠gena vazia, voc√™ descobre uma estrela que envia um sinal e a √∫nica coisa que pode fazer √© tentar chegar l√°, mas para isso ter√° que viajar entre v√°rias estrelas e nisso pode encontrar de tudo.

Voc√™ faz o seu caminho e decide a rota que quer pegar, mas isso pode te fazer cair em lugares aleat√≥rios, como algo que te teletransporte pra uma outra √°rea do universo, e assim voc√™ vai tentando chegar, mas quando estiver do lado, √© poss√≠vel que algo aconte√ßa e voc√™ seja atrasado. No caminho tamb√©m √© preciso entrar em planetas, extrair recursos e usar como suprimento da nave, as vezes √© necess√°rio fazer manuten√ß√£o de emerg√™ncia e destruir uma pe√ßa para pegar elementos que ser√£o usados em outras, √© preciso se virar e isso √© uma verdadeira maravilha, sem contar com os elementos de RPG, √© fant√°stico de repente receber mensagens como "Voc√™ v√™ tr√™s naves em combate, a batalha √© fervorosa, uma nave solit√°ria est√° sendo atacada, voc√™..." e ent√£o op√ß√µes do que fazer, e essas podem trazer consequ√™ncias boas ou ruins. author: {'steamid': '76561198005662292', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 227, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 227, 'last_played': 1429378252}
review:
Pretty fun, wish it wasn't so entirely luck based, or maybe language or some type of progress is saved between deaths? I've played over a dozen games and barely made it 15 turns. It's not due to poor decisions as I will die to lack of fuel due to a string of stars with no fuel around it. So yeah, too completely random. 
Twice now I've died to fuel loss right as I find a new ship. This shouldn't be a death, this should be an exstatic experience as I am saved by such a rare occurange. I made it too the ship, so why can't I just hop out and board it?

author: {'steamid': '76561197963660521', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 243, 'playtime_forever': 830, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 790, 'last_played': 1429560978}
review:
It's fun. The music is great, the art style is great, the writing is enjoyable (though, reminding me of anime, it pretends to be too smart, or pretends to tackle complex themes when it is not). there is enough variety to keep you coming back, im seeing new content on every play through


 a couple huge problems though.


Problem 1 is the UI....its directly ported from the touch screen mobile interface, and with a mouse and a huge screen, it SUCKS. Moving the mouse from one side of the screen to the other to click buttons is as about as tedious as it can get...zero keyboard short cuts....I feel like im playing on an iOS emulator, and thats not a good thing.  Everything on the screen is gigantic for clumsy fingers....this was a lazy ass port on the developers part.


Problem 2 (as many others have stated) is the difficulty. I LOVE LOVE LOVE hard games, but I don't like losing to chance....over and over again. While taking risks that might not pan out is acceptable, way to much (dare I say the majority) of this game is left soley up to chance. Even with the most careful planning you will often lose just from an unlucky streak of game events.

 I'd buy this game on sale, not worth the 9.99 asking price, but would be good at the mobile game price (3.99-4.99)

author: {'steamid': '76561197987828646', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 65, 'playtime_forever': 338, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 181, 'last_played': 1443478044}
review:
There's some of the exploration sense of FTL in this game - jumping from system to system - so making that comparison would be a fair assessment. (As so many others have done.) With that, instead of combat, you have to deal with survival resource management. It's a roll of the dice whether or not a certain star system will help you out or be a waste of fuel and oxygen; but it's more of a cost-benefit analysis mechanic. (Will landing on this planet to gather resources be worth the fuel, or will I end up with a bunch of stuff already in my cargo bay?)

Like FTL, I found this game particularly frustrating when I first started playing. It grew on me though. Getting used to the game's mechanics will likely take a number of play-throughs. The strategy involved comes once you start learning how to best utilize the various technologies available to you as the game progresses.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025057920', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 35, 'playtime_forever': 1001, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 987, 'last_played': 1574294965}

author: {'steamid': '76561197965071382', 'num_games_owned': 499, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 697, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 602, 'last_played': 1428934279}
review: I can get behind the luck based gameplay. This game has a lot of story in it, it's super interesting. I can get behind the difficutly. Even when you're super lucky it's INCREDIBLY likely you'll fail. I cannot get behind the shear amount of BUGS in this game. Crashes opon continuing an existing game. Crashes if you travel too far in one jump. Crashes ANYTIME YOU GET NEAR THE END. I like this game but it is fucking BROKE.

author: {'steamid': '76561197982095882', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 143, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 59, 'last_played': 1667367908}
review: I've dumped countless hours into the mobile version after discovering this gem in a humble mobile bundle and decided to pick up omega because it's just THAT GOOD. I've seen a fair number of people complain about the "luck" factor in this game, and while it can be frustrating, I see it as a core mechanic to the experience. Not only does it add near infinite replay value, it turns what would otherwise be a simple game into something much deeper. Every decision has consequences and I think part of this game's charm is that it's actually a struggle to reach the end of the game. It's part of what keeps me hitting "Restart" over and over. Even after all that I think I've only reached two of the three or four endings (I can't remember how many were in the mobile version). If you're having a hard time there are tips/tricks you can find with a little Google-Fu that make the early game a little easier, and after playing for a while you start to become familiar with the random events that pop up when you hit a new system which can keep you from making an unwise choice. All in all I'd say this game is like many of the Rouge-like games in that familiarity breeds survival. If you're looking for a game that's going to hold your hand and/or not punish you for not paying attention look elsewhere. Learn from your mistakes!

author: {'steamid': '76561198066799702', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 29, 'playtime_forever': 432, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 432, 'last_played': 1428902911}
review:
Waking up from cryostasis and finding yourself lost in space, you try to edge forward through the void in search of answers while struggling to keep you and your ship alive.

"Out there" is basically an FTL-clone which does stand on it's own merits though. While there is no combat, the challenge comes from keeping safe amounts of Fuel, Oxygen and Hull Integrity on your way through space which can be obtained by harvesting elements from the planets you visit. It's quite compelling to improve your ship's stats by collecting blueprints and building new technology. The overall presentation is very good, music and artstyle ranging from adequate to convincing, the game is definetly polished! 

Despite all of this, I cannot recommend this game because of this SINGULAR reason: Survival is just too random. There is not a lot of room for skill or potential for strategic thinking, that would improve your chances drastically. Whenever you lose a run, you never feel like you deserved it. You would expect this to be resolved by some form of persistent unlocks but there is literally no progress carried over when starting a new game. Going through the first 30-60 minutes of every new run is a real chore, boiling down to being lucky or unlucky when finding new technologies and dice-rolling on conversations with aliens you don't understand because your Lexicon is reset every game as well.

It's unfortunate that all the pros get outweighed by one con, but as the game is now I couldn't recommend it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198054438418', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 281, 'playtime_forever': 601, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 595, 'last_played': 1579997827}
review:
tl;dr This game is amazing. Get it!

Gameplay-wise it's like FTL, but with focus on resource management and ship loadout. There is no active combat, only exploration and random events with choices. There is no rebel fleet or big boss battle; Only the universe to explore as you survive and work toward one of 4 endings (each achieved in a specific way).


The feel of exploration (and space loneliness) is very strong. No other space game had made me feel this way (apart from X-Tension and original Mass Effect). 

I would recommend this game to all fans of space games and exotic worlds.

// human love star love life //

author: {'steamid': '76561198026697822', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 757, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 601, 'last_played': 1428875231}
review:
This game was immensely fun, if a little buggy, until the end. Then it takes one of the sharpest nose dives of any game I've ever played. All of the possible alternate endings are terrible. They're poorly written and gut wrenchingly anti-climatic. 

The cliches are so bad as to be physically painful to read. After hours of gameplay and stuggling to the end, instead of being rewarded with an intersting or though provoking wrap up, you get to enjoy an immense let down that seems to retroactivly suck all of the fun out of the game. Such wonderful wrap ups as: "No, now you are the alien!" or "Sometimes, mass genocide might not be a good thing."

author: {'steamid': '76561198005061118', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 98, 'playtime_forever': 769, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 431, 'last_played': 1484112613}
review:
Similar to FTL, except instead of combat, you have resource management. Music is fitting, aesthetics are colorful and generally interesting, overall the atmosphere of this game is outstanding, gives a good sense of being alone and stranded in the galaxy, thrust into the role of adventurer desperate for survival.

This game is also very punishing which can lead to high frustration. Often I have found a seemingly succesful run end because I couldnt find a single planet with oxygen in the last 5 star systems, or I couldnt find the technology to allow me to jump to farther stars once that technology was mandatory in the latter half of the galaxy. It feels like even with knolwedge of the game's mechanics, you still have to rely a good deal on luck to make it to the goal, which I have yet to do after ~10 hours of gameplay.

Overall, I do love this game, I just wish there was a sort of difficulty choice to have, or at least it wasnt so punishing for seemingly unforseeable choices.

author: {'steamid': '76561197973015267', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 51, 'playtime_forever': 499, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 408, 'last_played': 1428698183}
review: Look, domestic abuse is a real issue and one that Out There: Omega Edition from Mi-Clos Studio doesn't address at all. But, if, like me, FTL is a former lover of yours, then Out There is the abusive rebound you probably convinced yourself was the best you could do after the break up. Both contain a lot of the same qualities: there's the space-themed roguelike, the 2D spaceship cut-aways, the modular narrative structure, but where Out There sets itself apart the most is its brutality. For more, check out the [url=https://youtu.be/kCmA-KRhgTc] VIDEO REVIEW.	 [/url]

author: {'steamid': '76561198052333663', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 97, 'playtime_forever': 294, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 274, 'last_played': 1430346906}
review:
Out There is a very atmospheric rouge-like game. It's suprisingly interesting and definitely worth a look.

Video Review:

https://youtu.be/wAlsEgo3wq8

What is it?

Out There is a science fiction rouge-like game. You play as an astronaut who has mysteriously arrived deep in space after waking from cryo sleep. You're goal is to travel to one of multiple objective points on the star map. In order to survive the journey you need to harvest fuel, metals, and oxygen along the way. 

The gameplay is very reminiscent of FTL in cetrain areas. The main map consists of star systems that you can jump between. Once you're at a system you can travel to the planets to mine them for rescources and potentially find technology. Between each new star system you get a random event where you have make choices, often with limited knowledge that can hurt or benefit you.

The game focuses on the feelings of lonliness and exploration that your character feels while he is traveling. You have to try to communicate with aliens and in the process begin to learn their language. The atmosphere is built as a beautiful combination of lonliness and exploration. Everything is new and alien, but that adventure doesn't take away from the fact that there is no one to share the stories with.

Unlike other rouge-likes, there is no way to change what you start with. You always begin with the same ship and you can only get others by happening upon them in your travels. Each ship has its own benefits and drawbacks (although your first ship is really a hunk of junk).

Pros:

-Every game will be very different. You're coices will be storngly driven by whatever ship or technologies you find first.

-Immersive atmosphere. The soundtrack, the text, and the visuals all work together to build on that atmosphere.

-The game focuses heavily on its rescource managment side and does it well. It doesn't burden itself with a combat system (which could be a con for some, but a I think this game did it well). You will often dread dropping that tungsten, but you have to to make room for fuel.

-Multiple endings. I've only one once so far, but I've seen at least four different objectives that one could go to.

-Games can be quick. I think that my average game was about thirty minutes going to as long as an hour. 

Cons:

-Grindy. The gameplay can end up feeling a bit grindy as you fly between rocky planets and gas giants just probing them all day. Despite this, I didn't hate the grind as much as I might in other games.

-Potenitally simple endings. [spoiler] The one ending that I have achieved was the first objective you are given. When I got to the star I spoke to the Architects, an old race of aliens that keep the universe working. All that happened was that my character figured out that he was the last human and then flew off into the stars to try to resurect his people. I didn't get any choice in the matter and the game ended. I don't know if this is how other endings work, but it's food for thought. [/spoiler]

-It can feel unfair at times. I've had instances when I go to three gas giants, troll them for fuel, and can't even recoup the fuel I spent getting there. There wasn;t any obvious reason why and it is a bit frustrating.

-All progress is lost after you die. I like rouge-likes that reward you for doing awsome things (like winning the game) by giving you something that you can start the game with. FTL's version of that was new ships and layouts. Out There doesn't have any of that.

Overall, Out There is a really fun game. I have thoroughly enjoyed my time with it so far. It's more than worth $10, especially if you love exploration.

review: First off, this game is difficult. A little too difficult, some might say, but I found the challenge inviting. It becomes much easier the more that you keep trying. Being a total space nerd, I really enjoy the level of detail. Graphics are lovely. The replay value of this game is high - to an extent. There are multiple missions, technologies, and random events that will draw you into clicking the "restart" button after your inevitable demise.

review: Excellent concept de jeu (unique √† ma connaissance), graphisme somptueux, accompagn√© d'une bonne ambiance concernant le personnage racontant ses p√©rip√©ties √† travers des textes plein d'humour et tout ca pour un prix finalement assez bas pour un tr√®s bon jeu.

author: {'steamid': '76561198046706510', 'num_games_owned': 203, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 1156, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 538, 'last_played': 1608883087}
review:
En rapide (pour ceux qu'on pas le temps, faut y aller !) : 

Le jeu plonge le joueur dans une aventure prenante et immersive. L'al√©atoire est omnipr√©sent et sert tr√®s bien le jeu. Le gameplay semble simple au premier regarde, le rendant simple √† prendre en main, mais cache une complexit√© permettant une r√©elle am√©lioration du joueur. Tr√®s bon jeu !

En d√©taill√© (pour ceux qui veulent plus de d√©tails) : 

Jeu tr√®s immersif avec des textes recherch√©s qui plongent le joueur dans son personnage, au cours d'une aventure tr√®s prenante dans l'univers. 
L'al√©atoire est certes omnipr√©sent et peut rendre les parties extrement difficiles, voire impossibles, mais √ßa ne rend la victoire que plus attendue et plaisante. De plus, l'al√©atoire permet de ne jamais rencontrer les m√™mes situations, ce qui rend alors la dur√©e de vie du jeu potentiellement infinie. 

Le gameplay assez simple √† premi√®re vue rend le jeu facile √† prendre en mains et permet de se concentrer sur la trame narrative d√®s le d√©but et l'exploration des diff√©rents syst√®mes. Cependant, le gameplay est plus complexe une fois qu'on commence √† connaitre le jeu : entre gestion des ressources et am√©liorations du vaisseau qui prennent les m√™mes emplacements que les ressources. Ainsi, le joueur qui cherche √† vraiment √™tre meilleur dans le jeu verra qu'il progresse petit √† petit et arrive √† atteindre des zones plus √©loign√©es qu'auparavant, malgr√© le hasard omnipr√©sent. 

Peut-√™tre l'eussiez-vous compris avant que vous ne lussiez ce paragraphe final, mais je conseille ce jeu √† tout le monde : prise en main facile et complexit√© de gameplay pour ceux qui cherchent √† un jeu de gestion de ressources √† optimiser ; qualit√©s narratives du jeu et voyage interstellaire immersif pour les joueurs qui pr√©f√®rent √™tre berc√©s par l'histoire dans laquelle ils se plongent.

author: {'steamid': '76561198004094690', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 605, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 605, 'last_played': 1428678032}
review:
I give up
Not because it's hard, altough it took me alot of tries to explore over 10 systems, i finaly make it 2 jump from end game, then some kind of bug happens and it doesnt let me click on any stars with the mouse, i tried quitting and continuing the game and everytime i get on the star map it doesnt let me click on anything. 

I have given this game a chance even through all the fustrating restarts. Theres SO many bugs for a game this simple, it's freaking text and pictures. I will waste no more time on this.

author: {'steamid': '76561198027401710', 'num_games_owned': 180, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 2050, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 174, 'last_played': 1623552525}
review: This is basically Faster than light without the combat, perfect game to play when you want to clear your min and phase out.

author: {'steamid': '76561198014739898', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 33, 'playtime_forever': 48, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 48, 'last_played': 1428631671}
review:
I liked the atmosphere, artwork, and music. I wanted to like the rest of the game, but I just couldn't.

It just doesn't feel like my decisions matter. I love roguelikes, I'm a big fan of randomness...but this was just TOO random. Every encounter is "click and hope." Most of the random encounters give you choices of what action to take, but no clues. "Do you push the square, circle, or triangle button? Triangle? Wrong. Bye." Alien encounters give you a paragraph of alien gibberish, and the options to agree or disagree. Probing or drilling for resources may or may not give you enough to last to the next planet.

It's all just "click and hope." And I can see what they were going for, from an artistic standpoint I guess. It's actually pretty neat, and adds to the whole lost in space feel. It's very cool. It's just not fun.

author: {'steamid': '76561198048735421', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 102, 'playtime_forever': 2184, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 504, 'last_played': 1620367872}
review:
I thought it was an FTL clone. I love FTL.
No game could beat the randomness, dificulty, or variety FTL had.









I was wrong...
Oh so wrong...

review: Das Ziel des Spiels ist es zu √úberleben, mit den vorhanden Ressourcen Hauszuhalten und eines der vier Spielziele zu erreichen. An sich besteht das Spielen nur aus "Mausklicken" und auf Ereignisse reagieren welche zuf√§llig stattfinden aber dennoch sehr unterhaltsam und fesselnd, wenn es mal l√§uft. Das Games selbst ist sehr g√ºnstig in der Anschaffung und man macht nichts falsch mit einem Kauf. Eine Runde kann von nur ein paar Minuten bis zu einigen Stunden andauern. Der Wiederspielwert ist ziemlich hoch, da man sich mit dem Endstand der erspielten Punkte einen Platz in der globalen Bestenliste sichern kann...und wer sieht sich nicht gern mal ganz oben stehen :D.

author: {'steamid': '76561198001932746', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 609, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 530, 'last_played': 1589604082}
review:
Certainly an atmospheric and well thought out world, but due to entirely luck based gameplay - this game becomes a tedious waste of time. I've made it incredibly far - just to be dealt, 5 systems in a row with no fuel or oxygen (I had a ship that could use oxygen as fuel). This game could definately be a little more forgiving, after several hours and countless death, I can't help but feel like I have no chance at ever winning, and that the odds are infinately stacked against me.

I don't often say this about a game, but this is a true waste of time.

review:
Tr√®s bon jeu, 
Un veritable challenge pour atteindre la fin (5ou6 fin possible). De nombreux vaisseaux (environs 10) avec tous leur particularit√© (Personnellement celui avec l'arbre est le mieux), une vingtaine de technologie plus ou moins utile, une quinzaine de ressource plus ou moins interessante, des "autochtone".
Un vocabulaire et un carte al√©atoire a chaque partie.

Une question: que voulez-vous devenir? 
Un Empereur?, Un Sauveur? ou juste une capsule cryog√©nique d√©rivant dans le lointain?

Le seul probl√®me selon moi est dans l'animation lors du changement de syst√®me solaire (bug de temps en temps) ainsi que le manque de rappel des objectifs.

author: {'steamid': '76561198019205444', 'num_games_owned': 4268, 'num_reviews': 323, 'playtime_forever': 543, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 431, 'last_played': 1471317164}
review:
You awaken from cryogenic sleep on your journey from the moon to Jupiter only to discover that you're not in our solar system anymore. You've traveled "Out There." Its now up to you to explore a new galaxy and find your way back home. Out There: Omega Edition boils down to a combatless, inventory management game in a beautiful space setting with randomized solar systems and events. For your survival, you need to manage your cargo while maintaining fuel, oxygen and hull to stay alive. Its an easy and relaxing game to play, relying on mostly button presses with your mouse or touch pad. Death is permanent, but since the game is randomized, you'll have a personal story to tell each time you play.

While exploring this strange new galaxy, you'll find abandon space ships that you can take as your own. You'll be required to take a look at your ship in order to manage your inventory with ship components and your cargo. To refuel, repair and oxygenate your spaceship you'll need to click and drag minerals from your cargo and drag them to the maintenance. Its just that simple. Each ship has different requirements for its hull and fuel. Most require helium or hydrogen for the fuel and iron for the hull. Helium will refuel the ship faster. The inventory is a grid and you can click an empty square on the grid to craft additional components from schematics that you'll find scattered throughout the galaxy. Components can also be dismantled for their minerals which is helpful when you abandon your ship for another one.

Minerals stack up to twenty per square. Its odd in a way that twenty hydrogen takes up the same space as twenty platinum or iron. You have no weight limit either. Just a grid limit. Different ships have different grids. Smaller ships have less of a grid, but consume less fuel. I found smaller ships to survive far longer than larger ones strictly for their fuel consumption.

On your way, you'll encounter anomalies that will send you on quests, none of which I've seen through to the end, even after six hours of playing. They're always at the furthest reaches of the galaxy, like your ultimate goal. You'll also meet aliens in picture form and learn words to their unique language.

While the solar systems get randomized or "rogue-like," the map of the galaxy isn't. Its the same galaxy time and time again. You'll encounter the same blue giants, red, yellow and white dwarves, black holes and super novas every time you play. Your ship has a radius that it can travel and if a system is in the radius you can travel there at the cost of fuel and oxygen.

Each solar system can consist of random rock planets, gas giants, anomalies, garden planets and a star (or black hole). Even when you're in these solar systems you need to spend a set amount of fuel and oxygen to orbit and visit the locations. Everything amounts to a beautiful background scene with your ship over it. Again, its nothing fancy, but it does do a good job of a space ambiance.You'll never know what's in a solar system until you visit. Nor will your ship remember what was in a solar system. There is of course a ship component to analyze solar systems.

Gas giants are the most important, they're how you'll get precious fuel. Even visiting them will damage your hull. To get the fuel, you send out a probe and you're given a choice how big of a probe. The larger the probe, the more fuel you'll get. Always spend the maximum amount of fuel on a probe. Otherwise it will never return with enough fuel. Ever. The larger the probe, the easier it is to return damaged or get destroyed. You can easily repair anything broken with iron that you have on board. Even if a probe gets destroyed, you can recover its components and use iron to make a new one. Its a small price to pay to have more than enough fuel on board. Its a constant struggle in the game. You can probe over and over, but the yield will be half of your last attempt, making it ineffective.

Rock planets are how you obtain iron and other resources, but nothing feels as important as iron. To get the minerals you'll have to orbit the planet, then land. When you're done you'll have to take off and all  these procedures cost fuel and oxygen. Again, this is an inventory management game. When you're on the planet, you need to drill much like probing. Always use the largest drill to get the most yield.

Garden planets are the most interesting. You can land on them to instantly replenish your oxygen, drill for different types of minerals, but more importantly, there's life here. You can speak with inhabitants and while they don't speak your language, you'll learn a word or two from them; even give them things or receive schematics or the Omega from them. This Omega is special and can be used to repair things amongst other interesting things further in the game. The garden planets have different minerals that are used for components most of the time.

In terms of components, some of them feel useless, but there are others like shield generators and wormhole generators that feel more useful. You can improve fuel efficiency and other things all through components. The only down side is some components require others, so that's two slots from your cargo used.

When drilling or probing, you're forced to take or abandon things without having the ability to use my maintenance to fuel or repair your ship. It seems only logical that I deliver hydrogen straight from the probe to my maintenance, but instead I need to jettison something from a full cargo hold.

In terms of anomalies, those are abandon ships, quests or cubes. The cubes will replenish one specific thing whether its fuel, oxygen or your hull. They're very helpful and give you a reason to always live dangerously with low fuel, oxygen or hull hoping to find a cube. Visiting stars themselves will heavily damage your ship and it doesn't seem like there's a use for them unless you get a ship component that lets you fly through a black hole or harvest the power of a white dwarf or something. Other anomalies will wormhole your ship to a different solar system.

When you get to each solar system, sometimes there's a random event will play out through text. Sometimes you're given a choice. Things like you're being attacked, do you hide or flee. Again, there is no combat, so your choice determines does your hull get damaged or do you expend extra fuel escaping? The game recaps what you've gained or lost. With everything playing out via text and the fact that you travel from one star to the next, Out There can feel like a single player board.

The game is beautiful, vivid, colorful backdrops of space, planets and other celestial bodies. It feels spacy with great ambient music and that's all you really need for any space game. Just give a feeling of isolation and gorgeous backdrops. Its a place you can sink a lot of time into.

Depending how far you get, the game will shake things up a bit with hostile aliens that will conquer planets. You won't be able to visit these planets, making a tough game even harder with no difficulty settings.

Now for the major problem that I had, your ship has a radius that you can only jump so far in. About 30 minutes into each play through, I'd come across dead end after dead end. The galactic map never changes, so you can remember your route and where not to go. You need to start relying on random luck to find schematics for worm hole generators or anomalies that will randomly teleport you to places. This makes the game feel unbeatable unless you have luck. Back tracking seems like a brutal death sentence.

For anyone that can get into the game, its a good, relaxing time sink that will keep you playing again and again. There's so much here, but unless you can find a new ship or efficiently manage your fuel, you'll be doomed. That still won't stop you from continuing to explore the outermost galaxies of Out There. I'd like to thank Delphine and Plug In Digital for my copy of the game.

Otimo jogo. Roguelike, onde tem que viajar pelo espa√ßo para voltar para a civiliza√ß√£o. √â diferente do FTL pois aqui a viagem e a hist√≥ria √© contada de forma diferente.

Pros:
- Boa hist√≥ria
- Gr√°ficos bonitos, bem envolventes. Principalmente dos mundos.
- Variedade de ra√ßas e mundos.
- Microgerenciamento dos recursos para ir mais longe.

author: {'steamid': '76561197998183960', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 740, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 175, 'last_played': 1435823704}
review: Imagine if you simplified the Spore space stage to its essentials and mated it with a game like Faster Than Light, but then added a rich narrative.  This may come close to a summation, but here your main enemy is the environment.   Out There is a minimalist survival/exploration space game with a unique and colorful atmosphere.  The random nature of your starting star cluster and events encountered lends itself to some great replayability.  At least, I'm quite enjoying it so far...

author: {'steamid': '76561198030225702', 'num_games_owned': 486, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 1208, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 761, 'last_played': 1641762468}
review:
Day 2

Emptiness. Death. Life and  intelligence are accidental.  

I suddenly wake up in my ship ... my mind is fixed on something I can't stop thinking about. I dreamt of countless past lives, of countless universes. They are many, yet the same: vast desolate interstellar labyrinths of vivid color, labyrinth of a single line of survival. I lose control over my mind. The pulsating radiation coming from the screen changes my consciousness - it hypnotizes me. It rearranges the structure of my neocortex.  Am I still human? Or am I becoming ... more? My numbed body cannot stop me from turning towards the stars and activating the reactors, I collect my strength and launch towards the unknown. 

Œ©/10

author: {'steamid': '76561197980174344', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 117, 'playtime_forever': 458, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 296, 'last_played': 1580573452}
review: I enjoyed FTL, and I found quite a few similarities in this game.  Of course, the big difference is that it is based on survival, not combat.  Nevertheless, so far I have found this game enjoyable and recommend picking it up on sale if possible.  The only con I have found about this game is the reliance on random events.  Regardless of how strategic one's moves are, random events are the driving force behind the game.  It would be nice to have some type of setting to control what type of situations are encountered.

author: {'steamid': '76561198015596623', 'num_games_owned': 242, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 151, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 151, 'last_played': 1428006607}
review:
Well, Out There: Œ© Edition is an awesome journey through the space: without violence, relaxing, addictive and really really hard.

You may die a lot of times, yeah, but you won't stop until your character is safe! The possibilities are huge, with many endings and a lot of encounters/events (that's when you pray for your life, it is space, and space is dangerous..).

With such a low price, there are no reasons for you to not buy it. Many hours are waiting you onboard the Nomad.

author: {'steamid': '76561198086151669', 'num_games_owned': 439, 'num_reviews': 183, 'playtime_forever': 299, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 289, 'last_played': 1428397160}
review:
http://niveloculto.com/analisis-out-there-omega-edition/

Dentro de m√≠ hay un se√±or mayor que agita el pu√±o muy fuerte cuando ve a los j√≥venes jugando con el m√≥vil y metiendo ruido en el tranv√≠a. Ese viejo mental, que tan bien lo har√≠a en las tertulias televisivas de sobremesa, cohabita en relativa paz conmigo, ti√±endo muchas de mis reacciones ante los elementos de m√°s rabiosa modernidad (vines, tontos en Youtube‚Ä¶). Y en general me deja tranquilo con muchas otras cosas, aunque me impida mezclarme con todas esas nuevas expresiones culturales.

¬øPor qu√© les suelto este rollo sobre m√≠? Porque creo que es importante ponernos en contexto antes de empezar, y dejar bien claro lo dif√≠cil que me resulta entender el smartphone como plataforma para videojuegos ‚Äúserios‚Äù. Y s√© que es puro prejuicio, porque la plataforma est√° llena de propuestas fant√°sticas, pero son cosas de viejoven, no le den m√°s vueltas. Sin embargo, ese anciano tiene, desde hace tiempo, una p√≥cima de juventud llamada Out There.

El salto a pantalla grande

Recuerdo que mi primera partida al Out There original, en su edici√≥n para Android, fue en un trayecto de barco. A√∫n lleno de escepticismo inici√© la aplicaci√≥n, y lo siguiente que recuerdo es haber llegado al puerto como si no hubiera pasado el tiempo. Primera observaci√≥n: la obra de Mi-Clos Studio, un videojuego de gesti√≥n de recursos y ciencia ficci√≥n que de cuando en cuando nos golpea con muros de texto, casi un librojuego‚Ä¶¬°funciona en el formato m√≥vil!

Y funciona porque, a pensar de ‚Äúcontradecir‚Äù algunas de las esencias del juego en el m√≥vil (no hay partidas cortas, requiere pensar mucho cada movimiento, nos da cosas que leer cada dos por tres‚Ä¶), es tremendamente inmersivo. Es f√°cil dar el salto al espacio que nos propone, con ese astronauta a la deriva que quiere volver a casa y no sabe d√≥nde demonios est√°. Sin embargo, no dejaba de pensar en lo que me gustar√≠a poder jugarlo en ordenador, y mi plegaria acab√≥ siendo respondida con esta Omega Edition.

Con ese salto a la pantalla grande llegan un mont√≥n de a√±adidos: el habitual remozado gr√°fico (que hace a√∫n m√°s bello al juego), m√°s naves espaciales y especies alien√≠genas, m√°s porciones de texto, nuevas tecnolog√≠as y hasta finales nuevos. Sumen las nuevas composiciones de Siddharta Barnhoorn (Antichamber, The Stanley Parable) para la banda sonora, que se unen a las ya existentes, y tendr√°n un viaje apasionante por delante.

Porque a partir de aqu√≠ estar√°n solos en la inmensidad, vagando de estrella en estrella persiguiendo una se√±al cuyo significa desconocen. Un punto en el lejano infinito, que servir√° de consuelo ante las penurias, la escasez de recursos y la soledad m√°s extrema. Una odisea en la que lo habitual ser√° fallar una y otra vez, acabar a la deriva esperando la muerte cuando ya no nos quede combustible, con la nave destruida por un intento fallido de aterrizaje o boqueando buscando los √∫ltimos rescoldos de ox√≠geno mientras pensamos que hubiera sido mejor quedarse en el √∫ltimo planeta jard√≠n que encontramos.

Como S√≠sifo

Esta sucesi√≥n de fracasos, m√°s que frenar al jugador, sirve como acicate. Al fin y al cabo, lo l√≥gico ser√≠a que una empresa de este tama√±o, en la realidad, acertase s√≥lo una de cada mil veces. Abandonado frente al mapa estelar, el jugador ha de enfrentarse al error con cada decisi√≥n: cada salto entre estrellas es susceptible de llevarnos a un nuevo sistema con el que proveernos de combustible, ox√≠geno y hierro con el que reparar la nave, pero el azar y la falta de cabeza nos pueden dejar frente a una solitaria estrella de neutrones o lanzar contra planetas secos que no tienen recursos que ofrecer. BAM, siguiente partida.

En ning√∫n momento se eliminar√° el factor aleatorio que puede convertirnos en un cad√°ver flotante, pero acabaremos aprendiendo, poco a poco. Descubriendo qu√© elementos debemos acumular en cada parte del juego, c√≥mo relacionarnos con los alien√≠genas que vayamos encontrando (fant√°stico el sistema para aprender su lenguaje), si cambiar de nave o no cuando encontremos una abandonada‚Ä¶ Esas cientos de vidas despe√±adas en la misma tarea sin sentido a la que se enfrentaba S√≠sifo valdr√°n para algo. Porque es muy satisfactorio irse haciendo con el control, entender la l√≥gica de ese universo procedural al que nos enfrentaremos en cada partida.

La historia de infinitos fracasos puede tener un final, aunque quiz√°s no sea el que esperemos. A medida que aprendamos, adquiramos tecnolog√≠a alien√≠gena con la que avanzar y una mente que cada vez piensa en t√©rminos m√°s pr√°cticos, aumentar√°n nuestras posibilidades de descubrir lo que pasa en el universo y cu√°l es nuestro papel en √©l. El gui√≥n de Out There es interesante, trufado de peque√±os textos que sirven para meternos m√°s en la cabeza del astronauta y de elecciones en formato ‚Äúelige tu propia aventura‚Äù que podr√°n ayudarnos o sumirnos a√∫n m√°s en la desesperaci√≥n. Y la conclusi√≥n (conclusiones, ahora con los finales a√±adidos) no decepcionar√° a nadie, con un mimo por la ciencia ficci√≥n cl√°sica que se agradece.

Ayudar√° a hacer m√°s soportables las largas horas de error y muerte un apartado art√≠stico maravilloso. El universo se muestra con un esplendor capaz de capturar al jugador, con un dise√±o similar a los c√≥mics pulp. Cada planeta que visitemos, habitado o no, es un homenaje a ellos, y el uso de una paleta de colores extra√±a hace que el escenario sea protagonista y alien√≠gena, siempre ajeno a los colores de la Tierra a la que queremos volver; bello pero no para nosotros. Todo va en la misma direcci√≥n: el cosmos es hermoso, peligroso y fascinante, un hogar imposible para la humanidad.

La carga po√©tica de Out There es innegable, con el hombre como embajador de toda su especie enfrent√°ndose a la inmensidad del cosmos. La desesperaci√≥n de la derrota se une a la esperanza que da poder volver a intentarlo, aprendiendo de cada fallo. Pero la empresa es casi imposible y quiz√° no acabe como esperamos. Y en el fondo, este viaje condenado, este S√≠sifo espacial, es todo lo que tiene que ofrecernos: mil castigos por cada acierto en un entorno maravilloso y plagado de significado.

author: {'steamid': '76561198006944082', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 1675, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 887, 'last_played': 1429440654}
review:
Procedurally generated space roguelikes are few and far between, this game is actually quite unique in what it does. In FTL what will kill you is a missile or sweeping laser hitting you at a bad time, where as in 'Out There' what will get you killed is a decision you made ten turns ago. Like say thinking that you will be good without keeping that common-as-dirt iron cluttering your ship's hold  or thinking you have plenty of fuel to make another jump. 

'Out There' is like slow moving chess, with quiet dreamy music and little vignettes. It is the first game I've played in a long while that emphasized the exploration part of game play and it is a refreshing change. Even talking to aliens is a neat little mystery as you have to guess what they are trying to say and as you go along learning little snippets of language and the backstory as it unfolds. 

There are fun little jabs of humor and it would be relaxing if you weren't on the knife edge of survival at every instant. You can see gameplay elements in managing your ship's resources. You'll be thinking about fuel, oxygen and whatever rare metal dugup and trying to make sophie's choice on which to abandon and which to carry on the chance you might get a technology to use it. Make no mistake this is a rogue like, a pretty, quiet, sedate one but still a roguelike and you will die many many many times. 

It is an interesting reversal of the normal formula. The game is at its most random in the start when you have nothing and a bad roll of the dice can doom you on turn two. But if you can just last long enough to find a good technology, or a new ship, or a lucky streak of events you start to get a lot more options and agency. It is thrilling to get to that point, to get into a good routine.. then it becomes your own damn fault if you got greedy and risky. 

The game is a port from on the phone but the visuals are a nice moving comic motif and the sound score does much to set the mood. For what it is it doesn't feel cheap and runs well. Even though the UI can have a bit finicky things but they are minor.

Anyone who is a fan of exploration and roguelikes will enjoy this title. I know I have. I even bought it on my phone

author: {'steamid': '76561198037732384', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 189, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 187, 'last_played': 1456348771}
review:
I played the game for a few hours and I loved it.
The music and the art is amazing. It has a well written storyline. 

BUT the gameplay is mostly luck once you get used to it. You want a new Technology? Fine, you need to have a huge bucket of luck to find some new useful Technology. It¬¥s the same with Ressources, you will find many Ressources 
you won¬¥t need. But there wont be enough space for those Ressources and you throw them away.
One or two planets later you will probably find a technology. Guess what? You dont have the necessary Ressources. Simply annoying and frustrating.

As I already mentioned the storyline is AMAZING and worth to play. It¬¥s like an interactive-luck based Book ( yeah interactive-luck based book).

Buy it and you won¬¥t regret anything.

author: {'steamid': '76561197999226832', 'num_games_owned': 1306, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 967, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 967, 'last_played': 1428762314}
