author: {'steamid': '76561198021302091', 'num_games_owned': 267, 'num_reviews': 30, 'playtime_forever': 758, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 659, 'last_played': 1610882260}
review:
Out There is an amazing experience. Deeply atmospheric with perfect soundtrack, short presentation which explains the whole setting ideally and at the core is an immensely satisfying roguelike game. Hardest I have played yet, 1 successful completion in about 50+ restarts. I have encountered only five or so repeated events in countless amounts with very imaginative and entertaining writing (honestly, astonishing!). 

To make a simple comparison with FTL (Faster Than Light, game which I adore) [b]Out There[/b] = [b]FTL[/b]  - [b]combat part[/b]. Yet it's in no aspect lacking survival experience with stellar amounts of interstellar travel perils.

Sidenote takeway: thanks to Out There, now I know the difference and relation of Landau-Oppenheimer-Volkoff limit and Chandrasekhar limit to neutron stars, black holes, white dwarfs and other stellar phenomena.

8.5/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198113721988', 'num_games_owned': 399, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 379, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 273, 'last_played': 1506716650}
review:
First off, this game is a WONDERFUL example of what it means to be in a 70s sci-fi movie: Bleak, quiet, and beautiful. You won't win easily, that is very much guarenteed. What IS guarenteed, however, is that you'll get an amazing playthrough most every time. Your hopes will skyrocket the moment you get a new ship, (because that is literally the only way you can have any hope of surviving more than a handful of different sectors.), every interaction with a species alien to you leaves you wondering if you've had an impact on their own life, and your heart will sink the moment you travel to a planet in hopes of there being oxygen, only to find that you're travelling in your own tomb.
This game is beautiful. 10/10 would terraform a planet again.

author: {'steamid': '76561198001112417', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 517, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 235, 'last_played': 1473635303}
review: I kinda like to think of this as FTL "Lite". It has its own ways of making life difficult such as the Need or Greed resource management which is by far the most challenging. If you like loosing at a game often and getting super excited when you win, This if For You.

author: {'steamid': '76561198008999222', 'num_games_owned': 826, 'num_reviews': 89, 'playtime_forever': 683, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 329, 'last_played': 1435968974}
review:
What can I say ?
In one word "terrific" but by terrific I mean the gameplay is gorgeous and scary at the same time, really I'm honest. 
Why the gameplay is so good ? First of all it's frustrating, you have to make choices (oO did he say "make choices" ?) which will change your "very good beginning" in a "out of oxygen". Every time you click, you take a risk, if I understood  probability math I probably killed myself playing this game.
Why the art is very well done ? Space is not only awesome views, mooving planets it's also irradiated gigantic fireball which contains ressources you can't reach, abandonned ships you can steal (but why are the empty... where are the owners... ???), and light years of empty lifeless...
The music matches perfectly the theme and doesn't help my loneliness at all ! 

This game is about events and how you will react to it, you can stay somewhere and wait to die but when the silence will be too hard to support you will have two choices : 
- Crash your ship on a sun somewhere
- Continue your journey and maybe(95%) die trying

author: {'steamid': '76561197968984651', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 674, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 351, 'last_played': 1479637613}
review: I really the atmosphere if traveling alone in space, trying to make your way back home or to somewhere out there? The idea of exploration, taking risks, running low on fuel, and the stories along the way all make for a very interesting in experience for me. Its not a combat game though, its all about discovery, making the right choices to keep you going and surprises along the way that give you a big smile that you made it this far. I really congratulate the group who made this, very different from your average games these days.

author: {'steamid': '76561198131282434', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 1126, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 698, 'last_played': 1552239277}
review:
I first want to say this review is not based on the game itself, it's based on technical issues. For the most part I really like this game, I bought it after hearing it had a similar atmosphere to FTL and it lives up that, minus the combat of course. 

I am leaving a negative review for the time being because I have suffered from game breaking bugs on two occasions. Twice I have made it to one of the endings, except the ending planet or the only planet leading there simply wouldn't load. I would click to travel to the next system and it would just stay at the travel screen with stars going by endlessly and I had to force shut the game. I haven't been able to complete the game because of these bugs.

I like the game, I don't like game breaking bugs killing my progress.

author: {'steamid': '76561198080647536', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 44, 'playtime_forever': 476, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 476, 'last_played': 1428597180}
review:
This game barely gets a thumbs up from be (mainly because its a new concept, nice art, nice music etc.). The biggest problem is that the game is 90% based on luck. No matter how good you are at the game, you always depend on luck to constantly find planets with enough fuel, iron and oxygen.
Just be prepared to get frustrated a lot. For example even though you captured an amazing new ship, spent a lot of time discovering new technology, collecting the rare resources to build tech upgrades etc. etc. And then, bam, a random event makes you lose half of your fuel, and you end up in a solar system without any gas planets. Game over in two turns, and nothing you could do about it. This happens A LOT!
Unfortunately, the devs don't wanna hear anything about it. check the forums, they wanna keep this game a game of chance, to somehow show you the "thoughness" of space travel or whatever. I think its sad, the game could be so much better and more skill based...
I hope modders will fix it, like it happened with FTL.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970576581', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 18, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 18, 'last_played': 1428254312}
review: The visuals and audio are both really well done but I found the design really boring. It also seems luck based, not so much strategy. Feels like rolling the dice again and again to see how far you can get before you die and have to repeat the process all over again. Not worth the $10.

author: {'steamid': '76561198012667128', 'num_games_owned': 2128, 'num_reviews': 99, 'playtime_forever': 1131, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 516, 'last_played': 1579954564}

author: {'steamid': '76561198161673888', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 646, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 428, 'last_played': 1474510012}

author: {'steamid': '76561198044435087', 'num_games_owned': 1604, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 88, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 88, 'last_played': 1430329334}
review:
Voici un jeu que je ne connaissais pas du tout qui m'a vraiment pas mal plu.
Je ne suis pas un adepte des jeux de gestion mais Out There a su me plonger dans une ambiance oppressante o√π la survie est bien mise en avant.
Pour un d√©butant comme moi, je n'ai pas √©t√© perdu par le gameplay, tout est bien expliqu√© au d√©but (via un tutoriel) et on pige assez vite qu'il va falloir vraiment bien g√©r√© le mat√©riel qu'on r√©cup√®re pour esp√©rer survivre le plus loin possible.
Graphiquement, c'est propre et √ßa claque assez bien tout en restant simple. Avec ceci, une bande sonore qui se marie bien et qui accentue cette sensation de solitude dans l'espace.
Sur le peu que j'ai jou√© pour le moment, je suis plut√¥t agr√©ablement surpris et pour le finir, il va falloir se roder de patience car le jeu est tr√®s exigeant (et chaque partie est unique : rogue like).

author: {'steamid': '76561198034451419', 'num_games_owned': 299, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 90, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 27, 'last_played': 1649125797}
review: If FTL were about being alone in space trying to survive instead of crazy space battles

author: {'steamid': '76561198016382276', 'num_games_owned': 2401, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 296, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 265, 'last_played': 1439157514}
review:
I watched a Trailer many, many month ago and thought, this is a bit of FTL, Star Command and Star Control. By the way, i was stunned and thought, this will be the perfect game for me!
But no, it¬¥s more like FTL whithout the micro managment aspect. 

You need luck more than minded Turns. I¬¥m also dissapointed about the fact, that the interactions with Alien civilisations are pretty rudimentary. Everytime you meet an Alien, you will learn one or two words of their mumbling. I thought you would get sometimes missions/quests from them ( even after 4h of playing, i only recieved a gifts which contained always the same). 

If you are a die hard rogue-like fan, than go for it. If not...

author: {'steamid': '76561198030598611', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 52, 'playtime_forever': 704, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 307, 'last_played': 1441066021}
review:
Good graphics and music, as well as atmosphere and feeling of being a particle in infinity of space.
But gameplay based on pure RNG, much much more than it was in FTL and other similar games. Difference between winning and losing in the session is the pure luck, and there is no way to win by skill or knowledge.

I still recommend it, if you like space adventure, and dont mind of  losing to RNG.

author: {'steamid': '76561198122592558', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 160, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 153, 'last_played': 1490172742}
review: After playing this game for a couple of hours i have been blown away. this game offers a resource management fueled adventure, this game is great for when your done playing your action games for the day and are looking to relax to a nice story.

author: {'steamid': '76561198127479614', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 1875, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 635, 'last_played': 1557460280}
review:
This game is brutal and you'll love it. If you enjoyed FTL, but wanted a bit more, then take a look at this. I know its a mobile game thats been upgraded, and normally I'd be hating all over it. However, this grabbed my attention and just wouldn't let go.

 I died and died and got a little further and then died again. I started exploring every planet and every nook and cranny I could find, and I died. I started jumping as far as I could, and I found a new ship, and then died. And after each death I would shake my head and hit restart with ever more determination. 

 Now if you are looking for a space shooter than this isn't what your looking for. Combat is not a big part of the game. Nor is this a "Trading" game. This is a survival game.

 In a weird way it is a fear game, though not a jump scare, creepy walls type of game. No the fear and anxiety come from the isolation. The knowledge that you are indeed on your own, what little help you may find will come at great cost.

 Every choice you make will come with a reaction and you will never know what that might be. Then add in trying to converse with alien species that you have no way of understanding, figuring out mathmatical formulas, and trying desperatly to remember the things you were taught in chemestry class. All while trying to manage your resources, to keep you and your ship alive and running, while still trying to make sure you have enough resources to build any new technology you may come across in your travels. Add all these elements together, toss it out in space, and you have Out There.

author: {'steamid': '76561198058342281', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 665, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 535, 'last_played': 1507086215}
review:
Excellente surprise d√©couverte aujourd'hui m√™me gr√¢ce √† un stream de l'ami Nyo.

Ce petit jeu est grand par ses ambitions. Il n'est pas sans rappeler un FTL mais qui mettrait l'action sur l'exploration et la gestion des ressources pour survivre plut√¥t que sur des combats spatiaux. Le jeu poss√®de √©galement une narration qui vous permet de vivre des voyages tr√®s diff√©rents les uns des autres, subissant des √©v√®nements tant√¥t positifs, tant√¥t n√©gatifs, et le tout offrant une certaine coh√©rence et immersion dans le jeu.

La difficult√© est assez √©lev√©e, mais sans √™tre repoussante. Bien au contraire, le jeu nous pousse dans nos retranchements et nous sommes plut√¥t content de relever le d√©fi qu'il nous lance. Vous recommencerez des parties encore et encore avant d'en voir le bout.

Graphiquement parlant le jeu est tr√®s beau, des arri√®res plans absolument magnifiques et des √©toiles tr√®s bien mod√©lis√©es et qui vont laisser songeur ceux qui r√™ves de conqu√™tes spatiales. Si je devais reprocher une chose au jeu, c'est une interface pas toujours tr√®s intuitive ou pratique pour un jeu pc, r√©sultat, sans doute, d'un h√©ritage li√©e √† la version d'origine qui se trouvait sur iOS et Andro√Æd et qui pouvait se satifsaire d'une telle interface (bien que je dis √ßa sans avoir v√©rifier les possibilit√©s de raccourcis clavier qui pourraient √©ventuellement r√©soudre ce probl√®me donc c'est √† voir ! Et il faut bien reconna√Ætre que c'est loin d'√™tre un √©norme d√©faut, on s'habitue tr√®s vite √† cette fameuse interface quoi qu'il arrive).

L'ambiance sonore est, quant √† elle, tr√®s immersive et particuli√®rement bien sentie. Les musiques sont sign√©es du m√™me compositeur que pour The Stanley Parable, et sont d'une justesse assez bluffante. Collant parfaitement √† l'univers de la SF tout en parvenant, par moment, √† s'en d√©tacher pour apporter ce c√¥t√© √©trange et oppressant que pourrait rev√™tir une exploration solitaire dans l'espace.

En conclusion, tr√®s bonne surprise que je conseille vivement.

author: {'steamid': '76561197993422646', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 11, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 11, 'last_played': 1428266858}
review: Out There est une de ces merveilles rares et pr√©cieuses √† laquelle on pense longtemps apr√®s l'avoir termin√©e. En y jouant, on √©prouve un r√©el sentiment d'errance solitaire √† travers l'espace, un d√©paysement cosmique, une √©trange m√©lancolie... La superbe √©criture donne tout simplement l'impression de vivre une grande nouvelle de SF.

author: {'steamid': '76561198095854746', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 248, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 190, 'last_played': 1562854165}
review: Pourquoi vous perdez votre temps √† me lire ? Beaucoup de rage et de retry mais chaque tentative est une aventure. Go allez l'acheter !

author: {'steamid': '76561198017263934', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 97, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 97, 'last_played': 1428254963}
review:
Rare enough to mention, this game is very unforgiving. You can go from dying on your second jump to receiving heavenly bonuses every time you travel. For this, maybe luck is a bit too important.

But luck or not, I never came even close to half-finishing my journey. Think you can spend that oxygen recklessly to make some space for your cargo? Think again.

The game is a gem of micro-management, and the story gets you fully immersed in what could be only a pressing-buttons text game. Illustrations are gorgeous, lore is immensely rich, and you never know what will happen on your next jump.

author: {'steamid': '76561197990689230', 'num_games_owned': 85, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 406, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 406, 'last_played': 1428304756}
review: really good game! probably could still use a bit of polish, but definitely worth buying at this point I think. It's a bit like FTL, but has enough elements that are different that it can stand by itself. Kudos to the developers!

author: {'steamid': '76561198088730994', 'num_games_owned': 82, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 21, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 21, 'last_played': 1423174704}
review:
Out There: Œ© is just as frustrating, entertaining and fascinating as the first issue of the game. It's also much more beautiful, even more captivating and I can't say I finished it, thanks to all the different endings and storylines.

Get lost in space, get lost in Out There: Œ© Edition ! You won't regret it, not for one second. Say hi to the aliens for me, they're (mostly) nice.

author: {'steamid': '76561198099856775', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 37, 'playtime_forever': 425, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 144, 'last_played': 1554131680}
review: Cool game!

author: {'steamid': '76561197991073166', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 22, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 22, 'last_played': 1428239775}
review:
I played Out There a dozillion times on its iOs version. For some reason, I was in love with its brutality, its unfairness and the sheer feeling of lonliness it was full of. I think what I enjoyed most is that it made no concession whatsoever in its game design. It intends to make you feel tiny in a gigantic universe, and to achieve that, it gives you control only to a certain, very limited extend. You'll die a lot in OT, of course, and sometimes you'll get the feeling that the run was played even before it started. You'll feel anger at the fact that no matter what you would have done you would have died anyway. But that's exaclty what the game means, and I love it for being so tough towards the player, when the vast majority of other games are all about fairness and perfectly balanced gameplay. Because OT is about surviving in space, and surviving in space sometimes just plainly isn't possible.
The omega edition maintains this statement, but with even better graphics, sound design and depth. So if, like the captain of the Nomad, you are an adventurer with a sharp leaning towards suicidal tendencies, do not wait any further, you have found your fix.

author: {'steamid': '76561197980099456', 'num_games_owned': 1090, 'num_reviews': 33, 'playtime_forever': 253, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 253, 'last_played': 1428774815}
review: It's like FTL without crew management, free of rebel stepping on your toes, and battles. Lots of text and narration. Resource managment is the main mechanic of the game. Good and addicting.

author: {'steamid': '76561198002524261', 'num_games_owned': 1379, 'num_reviews': 216, 'playtime_forever': 19, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5, 'last_played': 1464729847}
review:
(I played the beta version of this game, which was outside of Steam, hence the low # of hours)

Out There: Omega Edition is a more narrative take of what FTL did before it. It's a more lonely and alien experience, invoking quite a pulp atmosphere with its comic style and narrative. If you enjoy roguelikes, but don't want to go too in-depth in complex systems, Out There might just be the thing you were looking for.

For first impressions of the beta, you can also check out my video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=4t6c1J0AGrc

author: {'steamid': '76561197996673674', 'num_games_owned': 498, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 77, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 65, 'last_played': 1433506107}
review:
I have played a lot on the mobile version of the game and it's with great pleasure that I re-discover this game with this beautiful re-design. 

Even though I'm really bad and always die, it's a pleasure to come back, enjoy the writing, the music, the graphics; in a word, the great atmosphere that for a while let me think I'm actually out there.

author: {'steamid': '76561198048723685', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 232, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 114, 'last_played': 1492630009}
review:
Apr√®s avoir √©cum√© la version android et la b√™ta, j'ouvre le jour de sa sortie Out There Omega, et autant dire que je n'ai pas √©t√© d√©√ßu.

D√©j√†, pour ceux ayant vu des images des verisons pr√©c√©dentes, l'aspect visuel flatte beaucoup plus la r√©tine. Mention sp√©ciale aux multiples environnement magnifiques des plan√®tes et √† la cin√©matique d'introduction du plus bel effet.
Il est difficile de critiquer un gameplay dont j'√©tais d√©j√† client √† la base, mais Out There, √ßa reste le plaisir d'optimiser absolument tout en tirant les derni√®res ressources de chaque plan√®te, laissant dans notre sillage un d√©sert de syst√®mes vid√©s de leurs richesses. Le plaisir aussi de tenter de soutirer de l'omega √† toutes les races extra-terrestres avec diplomatie avant de forer leur plan√®te sans piti√©. 
J'ai vu beaucoup de critiques sur l'"injustice" de l'al√©atoire, mais pour qui ne laisse rien au hasard et se bat avec fougue contre l'environnement hostile, croyez-moi, rien n'est impossible.

Bref, je ne saurais que trop conseiller Out There et son √©criture si bien tourn√©e, son gameplay tr√®s logique et sa difficult√© rendant toute victoire plus grisante encore. En plus pour sa qualit√© son prix est plus qu'honn√™te.
#TeamVaisseauArbre

author: {'steamid': '76561197964612999', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 121, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 121, 'last_played': 1428236187}
review: I can't reach the end. Even if I play a lot. I assume that if I was an astronaut, I would probably die in space but when I play Out There, I still want to be an astronaut. Maybe I could survive next time...

author: {'steamid': '76561198056253612', 'num_games_owned': 566, 'num_reviews': 31, 'playtime_forever': 72, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 72, 'last_played': 1428165175}
review: Un bon jeu pour mobile. J'ai regrett√© l'avoir achet√© sur PC en moins d'une heure.

author: {'steamid': '76561198031742321', 'num_games_owned': 178, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 385, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 266, 'last_played': 1445965784}
review:
I wanted to recommend this game, but only because it's well polished. Great graphics, great story, and great soundtrack.

Why can't I recommend it to you? Because right now, it's a game about 90% good luck and 10% skill.

This type of games where a high degree of good luck must be involved in order to finish them, turn boring really quickly. I've played Faster Than Light "hundred" of times, because it's 20% luck and 80% skill. The more you play it, the better you're at it. That doesn't happen in this game.

If you want to get frustrated, buy it. You'll still have some satisfaction looking at the graphics though.

author: {'steamid': '76561198135143088', 'num_games_owned': 630, 'num_reviews': 447, 'playtime_forever': 881, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 605, 'last_played': 1448152747}
review:
This game is frustrating as hell, and it will murder you hundreds of times without mercy.

It's also immersive and interesting to play. It doesn't hand you anything, so when you finally do attain some success you really feel the value of it. It manages to maintain a sense of quiet anxiety and an atmosphere of loneliness in the depths of space.

If you can handle some frustration and you're interested in seeing how far you can get before either madness or entropy claims you then check it out.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970613608', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 34, 'playtime_forever': 1655, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1419, 'last_played': 1469423723}
review:
Oregon Trail-like. 2D with a lot of text based descisions to make.

Alien language is cool.
There is a lot of luck involved as you juggle resouces and each star can end up being your last.

Find abandoned ships, very cool to trade off your old ship with your find.

My most unfavorite momments (which occur most often): While running on fumes, travel to a Gas Giant, probe it, and only get 6 Hydrogen.... groan.

Great 2D graphics, great mood music! It's like an old Heavy Metal Magazine Series of unfortunate space Mishaps.

MOST RAGE MOMENT: Made it ONE star away from my goal... low on fuel I jump to the star JUST before my goal.... the pre-entry on the star was an encounter that gave be the choice of gate A or B... I pick a gate and it warped me across the galaxy.... I then died in space lacking fuel...

author: {'steamid': '76561198130483651', 'num_games_owned': 126, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 416, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 353, 'last_played': 1452717871}
review:
This game is amazing! 

-The most simplest way to compare this game is FTL's  wilderness survivalist brother! 

Out There Omega has a beautiful art style that totally captivates your imagination for a insterstellar adventure. Also I feel that this game emerses you in the aspect of being alone in space, with capivating random events, truely facinating extraterrestrials and dimentanal breaking technology,and best of all you experience the vastness of your quest alone...Out there. This truely is an original master piece and I highly recommend this game to anyone who is into the theme ((Space Sci-Fi (Duhh :P)) and anyone that has patience with the truely impossible quest that you have to face.

author: {'steamid': '76561198030851169', 'num_games_owned': 445, 'num_reviews': 33, 'playtime_forever': 513, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 513, 'last_played': 1428181163}
review: Great game

author: {'steamid': '76561198001620434', 'num_games_owned': 464, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 347, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 327, 'last_played': 1433868428}
review:
Out There is a beautiful game, with an interesting storyline, mechanisms which are easy to learn but require thought and planning in order to use effectively.

It reminds me of FTL -minus the battles- and Captain Blood. The player has to tackle alien races while managing resources. The various ships available through exploration offer different advantages and disadvantages and require flexibility in order to make the beast use of each one.

There are various random events and just the right amount of luck to keep the players on their toes.

A beautiful story, blending classic sci-fi themes with a healthy dose of philosophy, Out There is a very interesting game, well worth a try.

author: {'steamid': '76561198097738062', 'num_games_owned': 760, 'num_reviews': 128, 'playtime_forever': 1122, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1121, 'last_played': 1517812907}
review:
First off, the atmosphere of Out There is amazing, and I'd recommend the game for the music alone. On the other hand, the gameplay's kind of simplistic and lacking mechanically - you basically just shuffle resources around, with little overall strategy or depth compared to FTL. At first the game seems impossible, but if you know how to mine resources optimally and which modules to build first, it becomes a cakewalk.

That doesn't matter too much, though, because Out There gets by on the strength of the audiovisuals and the writing. I really haven't been as emotionally affected by a game in a long time.

author: {'steamid': '76561198006501659', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 32, 'playtime_forever': 148, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 91, 'last_played': 1434823756}
review:
Lost in space you try to manage your resources as you travel from starsystem to starsystem in order to reach a cryptic destination. A long the way you will experience many random encounters that can either help you of hamper you greatly. You will encounter alien races that talk gibberish to you. But each time you encounter them you will learn few word and gradually understand what they are saying.

[b]Pros:[/b]
Atmospheric.
Geat music.
High replay value.

[b]Cons:[/b]
Heavy RNG.
Anticlimactic endings.

author: {'steamid': '76561198044814175', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 49, 'playtime_forever': 145, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 145, 'last_played': 1428140110}

author: {'steamid': '76561197971298988', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 562, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 547, 'last_played': 1446708498}
review:
Just got done playing my first 'life' in this game and I really enjoyed it...so much so that I also bought it for Android/my phone.

It is definitely more casual than FTL but similar and still seems difficult.  Excellent soundtrack and in spite of some translation issues (I assume), the journal entries and encounters are cool to read.

A very nice turn based game to play on my laptop and phone that I think will have quite a bit of replay value.  Have to agree with the rave reviews that this game has received!

author: {'steamid': '76561197985082775', 'num_games_owned': 6204, 'num_reviews': 77, 'playtime_forever': 140, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 140, 'last_played': 1428113600}
review:
This really isn't very good.  I was sure I'd like it based on what I'd read on Rock, Paper, Shotgun, which is why I bought it at launch, but it's more of a chore‚Äîone frustratingly sabotaged by luck‚Äîthan a fun or exciting adventure.

You spend all of your time juggling resources.  You'll sacrifice, for example, fuel and hull for the chance to pick up some oxygen at the rocky planets you come across as you travel along the line of stars between you and your ultimate destination.  You'll keep finding rare elements like tungsten and platinum that you can't use for anything until you discover relevant technologies, but they leave you annoyed at the lack of space in your cargo hold.

You'll meet an alien who gives you the mysterious omega element and decide to throw away your highly common silicon to make room for it, and immediately afterwards you'll chance upon a random event in which robotic termites eat your space folder, leaving you stranded.  If you only had some silicon, you could have repaired it.

There's clearly a story simmering in the background.  You encounter all kinds of zany alien life forms, and a lot of them try to communicate with you.  You gradually pick up some language that might help you to make decisions during these interactions if you actually have a run that lasts long enough, and they're all worried about judges or architects or something.  The writing is the sort that makes you feel like it [i]thinks[/i] it's good, like it's really got something to say, but it's actually cringe-worthy much of the time‚Äîand badly in need of proofreading, as well.  Here's an example:

[quote]Day 63 _

Let's say I find a magic lamp drifting in space and it allows me one wish. What would I wish for?

I must admit to a craving for sausages. Maybe I could return to Earth, but discretely, so I can have some sausages without needing to tell my story a thousand times.

No... My wish would be to find out what I really want.[/quote]

That's terrible, right?  Come on.  It's hard to care when the writing is that bad.

So there's really nothing compelling me to continue playing this.  I guess I'm curious to see what it's like to have a nice ship decked out with a bunch of tech that makes life easier, collecting rare elements and building interesting new devices, but getting there is a matter of pure luck.  There's no progress between runs that helps your goal to seem more plausible, either.

Everything that I manage to discover before inevitably running out of fuel after desperately traveling to the nearest fuel-rich gas giant that the game tells me on arrival has nothing left to probe‚Äîall of the technologies and new ship types (with their ample, blessed cargo space) that I've found along the way are gone.  I haven't unlocked anything that makes the crapshoot of space travel more manageable next time.

One of the game's selling points is that it has no combat; it's just you against the environment.  Well, maybe if it did have combat I'd actually feel like I have some control over what happens.  The idea of a game without combat appeals to me!  But it needs to be better designed than this.

Out There is no FTL.  There's no real strategy that you can employ as you play to have a greater chance of success.  In the moment-to-moment gameplay, it's just dull, while in the grand scheme of a full session it's frustrating.  Pass on this.

author: {'steamid': '76561198047839533', 'num_games_owned': 113, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 112, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 112, 'last_played': 1428112341}

author: {'steamid': '76561198002734128', 'num_games_owned': 3358, 'num_reviews': 928, 'playtime_forever': 238, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 47, 'last_played': 1579823159}
review:
This is one tough game...my first two playthrus lasting all of five minutes.  To quickly sum this up, your spaceship has been whisked away to parts unknown and it's up to you to manage your resources wisely in order to get home...and even then, that may not be enough.  There are events that randomly pop up that force you to make a decision, sort of like a "choose your own adventure" book.  The closest comparison I could make to any other game I've played is FTL with a touch of elements from the Infinitite Space series.  It's a great game, though I would have liked an "Easy" mode option so that I could explore a bit more and discover things at my own pace.  At any rate, it's worth the price of admission.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=R3QHm613rzc

author: {'steamid': '76561198024351511', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 630, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 630, 'last_played': 1428188078}
review: This game has been a lot of fun with interesting stories, aliens, and landscapes.  I just wish they had someone edit the writing who speaks English as a first language.  There is a lot of reading in this game and it is sometimes hard to understand what they are trying to say with all of the gramatical errors.

author: {'steamid': '76561198043250032', 'num_games_owned': 2464, 'num_reviews': 329, 'playtime_forever': 162, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 162, 'last_played': 1428077497}
review:
Out There: Œ© Edition is a resource management rogue-like game which recently released on Steam after huge success on mobile platforms. In Out There: Œ© Edition you play as an astronaut who has just woken up from cryogenic stasis on a journey from Earth to Ganymede, you quickly realise you've gone horribly off course and you're nowhere near your destination, you're out there. You must carefully manage your fuel, oxygen and hull in order to stay alive in an unexplored galaxy, along the way you will not only find remnants of the human race who have mysteriously vanished but you will also find alien races and alien artifacts never before seen by man. Out There: Œ© Edition is a story about the survival of one man who is way out of his depth on a journey that shouldn't have taken place.

This game has a fair few similarities to FTL: Faster Than Light, in fact it's these similarities that made me buy the game, so you'll see me compare the two games a couple of times over the course of the review. I'm a huge fan of anything Space related and this title did not disappoint

+Gorgeous art style
+Everything in the game is well designed, in particular the ships and the alien life forms
+There are several different ships, each coming with pros and cons meaning each ship has a unique play style
+Usually when you jump to a new star system you get a journal entry/mini text adventure which all have great stories but they're let down by the writer's knowledge of English (I'll come back to that later)
+The galaxy is procedurally generated each time you play so you'll never see the same galaxy twice
+Interesting storyline with an interesting yet mysterious protagonist
+Outstanding (even outstanding doesn't do it justice) soundtrack that even rivals that of FTL
+Great gameplay based around resource management, kind of like FTL with more resources and no combat
+The game has no combat, a bold move that work fantastically, fighting to survive against the environment is much more interesting than fighting to survive against hostile life forms
+As you get further into a run you begin unlocking more advanced technologies to help you get further
+Abandoned ships always seem to turn up just as your ship becomes obsolete which is perfect
+When you encounter alien life forms you often learn parts of their language
+You frequently come across mysterious alien materials and artifacts which often provide ways of improving your ship
+It's impossible to see everything this game has to offer in one run so you're definitely going to come back for more

+/-When something goes wrong, such as your Hydrogen probe being destroyed, it's incredibly unlikely that you're gonna make it since when something goes wrong in this game EVERYTHING goes wrong

-The game is riddled with poor grammar and spelling mistakes which really takes away from the fantastic story in this game, in all fairness the Dev is foreign and English is probably his/her second language but I still don't see why they couldn't have had someone proof read the game

Verdict:
9

Despite the game's numerous spelling errors and grammatical errors this is a fantastic resource management game with a gorgeous art style and fantastic design.

El K.

author: {'steamid': '76561198047814405', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 134, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 36, 'last_played': 1581007012}
review:
Compelling and intresting story.

Hard to beat but that's what makes me come back for more.

A bit like FTL just without the crew management.

Really is in my top 5 indie games for the past 3 years.

author: {'steamid': '76561197982861438', 'num_games_owned': 415, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 283, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 34, 'last_played': 1457195014}
review:
I played Out There since the beta (on Android). I followed the developement of this game. And i'm very grateful to see the evolution. the level design  looks great compare as the beta. It's note a FTL Clone. Maybe, we can compare this game as a melt between Rogue Legacy  and FTL. 

This is a strategic game, because you have to manage your own ressources in order to reach the end of the game. But you have to know that there are several ends. And it's a strengh of this game. Same as the level design, the gameplay.

The music is a cool soundtrack to the game, giving off an eerie space feel... stunning visuals, like something out of a Sci-Fi movie.

Finally, the randomization of each level, or new game allows us to do not getting bored. 

I was proud to have contributed to the "campaign" so as to bring this game on Steam.

author: {'steamid': '76561198004885007', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 185, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 185, 'last_played': 1428040459}
review:
This is more a mixed review than a negative one.

I bought Out There because it looked similar to FTL, but without the tedium of combat, and in that respect it did not disappoint. Like the starship Voyager, you jump from system to system trying to replenish limited resources, and along the way you meet alien lifeforms and learn new technologies that increase your chances of reaching home. I think the game aptly portrays the feeling of isolation in space, from the ambient soundtrack to the uneasy log entries of the protagonist, a lone astronaut who wakes from cryo-sleep to find himself far across the galaxy.

However, in going from FTL to Out There, I seem to have traded one form of monotony for another. Drilling rocky planets yields iron to repair your hull, but landing on and leaving those planets costs additional fuel. Probing gas giants yields fuel necessary to travel from system to system, but orbiting those planets damages your ship's hull. If either resource (or oxygen) reaches zero, your session ends. Drill, probe, drill, probe. From my experience so far- about three hours- I'd say this routine forms the bulk of each session, which I personally find uninteresting.

There never seems to be enough space to really exploit the technologies you learn on most ship types. Each technology takes up one slot, and most of the ships I've seen so far have no more than a dozen total. Not to mention, around five of those slots will always be taken up by your most essential ship systems. In addition, each unique element / resource takes up its own slot regardless of how little you have of each, and some technologies require multiple elements for construction.  Keep in mind the technologies you learn each session are randomized, so you won't know which metals you'll need at the outset, either. Often I just didn't bother with technology so I could stockpile the three basic necessities, since each slot only stacks up to twenty, and you often need more.

When you meet alien lifeforms, you're usually presented with a choice of Approve or Disapprove, but because you don't know the languages spoken, and because translated words don't carry over from session to session, you may as well flip a coin unless you're writing down all the words you learn on the side. The other events with choices feel equally arbitrary, though I acknowledge this was also built into the design of FTL and may not faze everyone.

In short, if the premise and feeling of the game are what interest you, and the above issues don't bother you, there's a good chance you'll enjoy Out There. If what you're looking for is mechanical depth and varied gameplay, I'd caution you to take a closer look before buying.

author: {'steamid': '76561198062665969', 'num_games_owned': 486, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 292, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 166, 'last_played': 1512103600}
review:
Alrighty, so let me be the first to publicly speak out about how awesome Out There really is!

I've played it within a livestream earlier, as a first look, exclusive preview into the game and how it works... and I have to say, its truly AWESOME!

The is a cool soundtrack to the game, giving off an eerie space feel... stunning visuals, like something out of a Sci-Fi movie, and awesome randomization for unique play everytime!

With random encounters like debris, asteroids, ships and even Black Holes... you never know where the next Solar System will take you!

Resource Management is also very crucial to the longevity of your survival. Balancing collection and use of Oxygen, Fuel & the state of your ships Hull, its important to plan ahead!

[h] So review time! [/h]

[b] PRO'S [/b]

> Very Sci-Fi feel to it, as it should have
> Awesome eerie Soundtrack
> Great factor of Randomization
> Unique game every time you play
> Very Strategic management for survival

[b] CON'S [/b]

> Game can be severly unfair at times
> A few bugs with pop-ups not closing (need to restart game)
> Could use more Planet/Solar System variety

Well thats about it, I hope you do enjoy the game as much as I am, and a big thank you to FibreTigre for granting me Pre-Release access to Out There. Its a fantastic game, :)

[b] Overall Rating [/b]
9/10 - Highly Recommend!

author: {'steamid': '76561198007310984', 'num_games_owned': 483, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 124, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 124, 'last_played': 1428029055}
review:
Star Date: Wrote this on Patch 1.1.2 - April 2, 2015

------------------------------------------------------------------

Where am I?: Time for the journey of a lifetime! You have just been thrown into some random star system and your only task is to get to this other, equally random star system in your laughable spaceship. On the way there, pick up upgrades, mine more resources, and meet the locals but try to not get eaten by them. Avoid being stranded in space as you run out of fuel or suffocate in the endless expanses. That's the premise of the game. It's a combination of FTL's spaceship customization but with a much heavier focus on the storyline which serves to be the centerpiece for this game.

------------------------------------------------------------------

Silence is Golden....

(+) Storyline - The storyline is beautifully written. Each time you play and fail and trust me you'll fail a lot, the events you get will be different. What choices you pick will determine what happens to your poor vessel. Exercise some common sense or not because finding out all the ways to die is part of the fun.

(+) The Aliens - Each habitable population that you meet has a vocabulary that changes each iteration but fear not, as you progress in a campaign you'll slowly learn what they are saying. 'No don't give those worms hydrogen fool! Ok let's get out of this planet while we can. Let's look at the bright side, we learned what thb\e word death is in their language and all it cost was these subsystems and hull sections!'

(+) Ship Customization - There's a plethora of ship upgrades to stick on your ship from improving fuel efficiency to shielding during atmospheric landings. Stick the upgrades to the basic modules for an adjacency bonus. The tutorial didn't explain that but I later found out so I'll share it with you guys for reading this far. :)

(+) Resource Management - Gone all the days you can stick 64 stacks of ships, food, tonnages of metals, people, livestock, etc into your pocket. There's a very limited amount of space on each ship that you get. You'll need some space for backup resources to repair your modules and to fuel your ship. That same space gets occupied by cool new techs you'll want to make your ship better. It's a fine balancing act and the game honestly does force you to make tough choices there.

(+) Visuals - The backgrounds to each planet look gorgeous, especially for the volcanic planet. 

(+) Price - I can't even buy a large sandwich where I live for $9. For the amount of narrative and gameplay you get, it's definitely worth it.

------------------------------------------------------------------

...but it's maddening as well...

(-) Lack of 'Action' - Ok this one isn't a bit fair but it's more of a warning. Incase you didn't read the game's description, i'll state it one more time - THERE'S NO COMBAT. It's not FTL so don't expect FTL. If you like reading and playing through old-school adventures then this is the game for you. If you're studying for the future starfleet command then you're playing the wrong game.

(-) Tooltips - I tried googling too but some things such as a ship's power, ecosystem,  and resistance. What do they mean? Oh there's an adjacency bonus? I wish the game told me. Some ship upgrades give you a qualitative description of their boost but I want to know the exact numbers please.

------------------------------------------------------------------

Overall, it's a gem for those who like an adventure game that has rogue-like survival elements. The game might get a bit repetitive once you've figured out how much in backup supplies you should carry to reasonably get to the next fueling point but there or once you've read through all the possible ingame events. Nonetheless, it'll be a while before you get to the latter part and for $9, you could do a lot worse. Have fun insulting aliens who you can't understand!

I give it a resounding 7.5 Babbalas out of 10 Rytssalas

------------------------------------------------------------------

For those interested in some gameplay: https://youtu.be/lm25rlyX0MM
https://www.youtube.com/user/xBr0wnBear

author: {'steamid': '76561198020479238', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 31, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 31, 'last_played': 1428016884}
review:
This is a really weird game, in a good way.

[u][url=http://youtu.be/JSX3MH-x6fo]Check out my reaction to this wonderfully weird game on video[/url][/u]

Pros:
_Beautiful: The game looks really great. The art style is bold and nice to look at. The planets art are imaginative and appropriately alien.
_Great music: Subtle and ambient, the music is really nice here.
_Rogue-like: Every run is different.
_Interesting and Immersive: The game world is very strange, yet somehow kind of makes sense. You'll want to explore all the weird wonders this game has.
_Good writing: Can be a bit pretentious, but nice and well-written otherwise.
_Great resource management: There's always a compromise at every turn. Everything that goes on is a trade in this game. You're trading space for material, trading materials and space for usable ship parts, as well as fuel and oxigens; and, worst case posible, you're trading in parts of your ship for materials to use during emergency. It's managed to be very intense and thought provoking.

Cons:
_Techno-Babble: Sometimes the game will use terms that you won't understand. Sometimes the game will have an entire paragraph that you won't understand.
_Can be slow: As with any game that is more focus on discovery, the game can go on long stretch without much happening.

Pros/Cons:
_Has no combat: Your ship doesn't have any guns on it, at all. This doesn't matter, because the resource management is the crux of the game's tension and conflict. Whether this is good or bad, depends solely on how you feel about that.

Is it worth 10 bucks? Yes. It's very intriguing and strange and weird. You'll want to experience it, even just for a little bit, just to see what they mean by "FTL with no combat"

author: {'steamid': '76561198041954665', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 56, 'playtime_forever': 68, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 62, 'last_played': 1488617446}
review:
Ich kenne das Spiel als IOS-Version, genauer gesagt die "Standard-Edition". Die Omega-Edition wurde im Vergleich dazu grafisch enorm aufgebohrt, aber man erkennt unweigerlich, dass es eigentlich f√ºr mobile Ger√§te gemacht worden ist. Es gibt auch einige neue "Features", wie z.B. neue Schiffe, die man finden kann. 

Das Spiel selbst hat einen enorm hohen Wiederspielwert. Es gibt mehrere M√∂glichkeiten es zu beenden. Man hat aber nur ein Leben und zuviele falsche Entscheidungen bedeuten den Tod. Eine Partie dauert deshalb zwischen ein paar Minuten und mehreren Stunden. Auf dem iPad habe ich es wegen dieser Kurzweiligkeit und der Atmosph√§re gern gespielt. 

Ein paar Tipps zum √úberleben:
[list]
[*]immer mindestens einen Stapel Eisen im Gep√§ck behalten, damit kann man die meisten Repaturen machen und grundlegende Ausr√ºstung herstellen

[*]wenn H√ºlle und Platz im Schiff es zulassen, jeden Gas-Riesen anfliegen und dort Sonde auf Level 10 starten, wenn die dabei kaputt geht, direkt neubauen bzw. reparieren

[*]das Start-Schiff so schnell wie m√∂glich loswerden

[*]mit dem Start-Schiff au√üer maximal Thorium keine zus√§tzlichen Rohstoffe einsammeln, 1 Stapel O2, 1-2 Stapel Eisen und den Rest mit Helium oder H2 f√ºllen

[*]alle Sterne im Startbereich abfliegen, die sind n√§mlich recht dicht beeinander

[*]auf jedem Gartenplaneten landen und Leben kontaktieren, dabei bekomt man Resourcen, Technologie und lernt die au√üerirdischen Sprachen, au√üerdem wird Sauerstoff aufgef√ºllt und man kann dort auch eine Reserve mitnehmen

[*]das gr√∂√üte Schiff im Spiel ist auch das energieineffizenteste, hat man allerdings mehrere Antriebs-Technologien (immer um die jeweiligen Antriebe herumbauen), ist damit die Chance auf einen Sieg am Gr√∂√üten

[*]mit Omega kann man nicht nur alles reparieren, sondern es zur Not auch als Treibstoff oder Sauerstoff verwenden
[/list]

author: {'steamid': '76561198016432675', 'num_games_owned': 1503, 'num_reviews': 483, 'playtime_forever': 505, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 505, 'last_played': 1467343935}
review:
[b] Target Audience: [/b] [I]  Variety Rougelite Players [/i]

[b] Summary: [/b]  
 
The question really comes into play is if the Omega edition does enough to stand out from it's mobile counterpart. It's got upgraded resolutions and more possibilities, and the base of the gameplay is still a bunch of fun. It's no level of FTL, as it's definitely a lot more simple. I do wish a tiny bit more of variety in the first couple of moves, but in the end, there is a lot of variety when the game opens up, and you learn little by little how to take advantage of things. 

[b]First Impressions and Gameplay:  https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=agkz-KSK8nA[/b] 

[u] Lists: [/u]
[b]Positives:[/b]
[list]
[*] Addictive nature, one more run kind of gameplay.
[*] Lots of variety and opens up as you get further and further into galaxies.
[*] Upgrades all really serve different gameplay styles and there's reason to choose different upgrades depending  on your situation.
[*] Visuals do the job well.
[*] Like the language options as you find more races, you learn more and maybe can answer their questions better.
[*] New ships always feel like a relief and are mixed in reasonably well.
[/list]

[b]Negatives:[/b]
[list]
[*] When things go wrong, things go wrong. You have to be prepared, but sometimes it really does feel like the game will screw you over for no good reason. 
[*] There's a lot of information to process, and at times it can be overwhelming. It's simple on the surface, but if you want to be successful, you got to learn all the trends.
[*] Full screen on multiple screens did not bound to the game's boundaries.
[*] Sometimes, you have to reboot the game as you can't seem to click through. This was noticed in conjunction with recording software.
[/list]

[b] If you want more reviews/information regarding games I've reviewed, visit my curator. [url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/6861768/]Dragnix Curator [/url][/b]

author: {'steamid': '76561197988940224', 'num_games_owned': 678, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 860, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 567, 'last_played': 1446355982}
review:
[h1]Summary[/h1]

Out There provides a unique experience of surviving the elements and fighting with loneliness in outer space. There is no combat, it‚Äôs you against the environment. Strong story elements tie this game together with choices that matter, gorgeous art, high replayability, and management mechanics. 

[h1]Breakdown[/h1]

This review is written with 8 hours in the PC version (2 hours in beta and 6 hours in full release), plus another 2 hours on the mobile version. I've avoided any major story spoilers.

[table]
    [tr]
        [th]Area[/th]
        [th]Rating[/th]
        [th]Notes[/th]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td][b]Story[/b][/td]
        [td][h1]9[/h1][/td]
        [td]The strongest part of the game in my opinion, Out There constantly provides you with short story text describing your journey. Developers state there are 350+ unique text adventures, many with multiple choices with different outcomes (also the choices can be different depending on certain criteria). These are often interesting as it explains a sci-fi event, or reflections of your character as they struggle with their predicament. Some key events are repeated with each playthrough, but with 4 different endings to discover there is a lot of story to get sucked into. The game now also has an opening cutscene of a high production quality, it's nice and short, and gets the story across well.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td][b]Gameplay[/b][/td]
        [td][h1]8.5[/h1][/td]
        [td]The gameplay of Out There can be split into a few different areas but all revolve heavily around decision making. One major area is the management of your ship including what resources to carry for fuel, oxygen. However you need to choose whether building certain components are worth taking more storage space in your ship (ie less fuel to carry for emergencies). Decision making also shines through in the many encounters you have in the game. An example of this is you encounter a cage in space with a creature raging inside of it, do you free it, obeserve it, or leave it. Each has a different outcome. Without giving too much away, there are languages to learn, technologies to use, and ships to board, giving you plenty of unique situations and choices.

The game can be quite punishing if you don't plan ahead, for example "I'll be find doing one more jump, there will be fuel in the next system", but what happens if there isn't fuel there? It took me a few attempts to understand the balance the game requires to progress further into the system. I've now figured some effective strategies which is making the game even more enjoyable.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td][b]Graphics[/b][/td]
        [td][h1]8.5[/h1][/td]
        [td]The game uses gorgeous artwork for planets, galaxies, spaceships, and planets with extra effects to make the planets rotate, etc. The artwork is gorgeous, especially the artwork for planets, I have often found myself staring at them and looking at all the details.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td][b]Sound[/b][/td]
        [td][h1]8[/h1][/td]
        [td]The game uses minimal music to create the eerie atmosphere in out space. There can often be times of silence, which deepens the sense of loneliness. The score is created by Siddhartha Barnhoorn (Antichamber, The Stanley Parable). Other sound effects are using for discovering items, refueling, etc and work well.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td][b]Replayability[/b][/td]
        [td][h1]9[/h1][/td]
        [td]Even after 8 hours, I'm stilling finding new encounters and have only finished one ending. There is plenty to do as it can take a few attempts to understand how things can work, and it's that sense of discover that drives further exploration. The galaxy you travel through is also procedurally-generated for each playthrough, so don't expect the same encounters at similar planets. The game is great value for the price it's sold for.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td][b]Multiplayer[/b][/td]
        [td][h1]N/A[/h1][/td]
        [td]This game does not feature any multiplayer. You can compare top scores with friends however.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td][h1]Overall[/h1][/td]
        [td][h1]8.6/10[/h1][/td]
        [td]Out There provides a unique experience of surviving the elements and fighting with loneliness in outer space. There is no combat, it‚Äôs you against the environment. Strong story elements tie this game together with choices that matter, gorgeous art, high replayability, and management mechanics.[/td]
    [/tr]
[/table]

[h1]Gameplay Videos[/h1]

I've been producing a let's play series which covers my playthroughs of Out There. Episodes 1 and 2 are from the beta, while episodes 3 onwards are from the full Steam release. 

Episode 1:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=M5tITImtLEE&list=PLgrLUq0pLmj1iBl3vGWixW31fnR5WexIi&index=1
This video (ep. 8) shows the starting cinematic at the start of the video:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=FQR_-GS_CS8&list=PLgrLUq0pLmj1iBl3vGWixW31fnR5WexIi&index=8
[h1]Questions or Feedback[/h1]

Feel free to tweet me [url=https://twitter.com/JackAttackNZ]@JackAttackNZ[/url] questions about the game or feedback for this review.

[i]Edit: Formatting fixed.[/i]

author: {'steamid': '76561197960559055', 'num_games_owned': 2826, 'num_reviews': 31, 'playtime_forever': 219, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 219, 'last_played': 1427868469}
review:
Out There is a lite space sim that's heavy on resource management and features the unforgiving session-based gameplay popularized by games of the roguelike genre. Harvest vital resources from planets to fuel and improve your ship, meet alien races and discover how to communicate with them, explore strange objects and phenomenon in space, encounter a wide variety of 'choose your own adventure' style dilemas that define your journey but most of all just claw and scratch to survive and hopefully you'll live long enough to get home.

To put it simply, if FTL cast you in the role of the guns blazing space hero James Tiberius Kirk then Out There: Œ© Edition sees you taking up the mantle of the diplomatic space explorer Jean-Luc Picard. For some that's all I need to say to sell them on this game, for others I made the 25 minute video down below:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zPDWArBp4m0

author: {'steamid': '76561198020430348', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 134, 'playtime_forever': 642, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 366, 'last_played': 1474267715}
review:
Out There is a hard sci-fi space exploration game blending roguelike, resource management and gamebook mechanics.
You are an astronaut awaking from cryonics not in the solar system, but... out there... in a far and unknown place of the galaxy. In Out There, you will have to survive, tinkering your ship with what you can gather drifting in the void, and spot garden planets to refill your oxygen supply.

Space is an hostile place ; dangerous and mysterious adventures will mark each step of your travel. You will not only meet intelligent species that won‚Äôt care about you, but also deal with ancient powers linked to your destiny and the fate of mankind itself.

Survival and understanding of what is really at stake in the galaxy is the core of what Out There has to offer.

FEATURES
‚Ä¢ A dark adventure in deep space
‚Ä¢ 50+ achievements, leaderboard
‚Ä¢ Explore a freshly procedurally-generated galaxy every time
‚Ä¢ 350+ unique text adventures with multiple choices
‚Ä¢ Epic main storyline leading to 4 different endings
‚Ä¢ 10 spaceships with different specs to discover
‚Ä¢ Crafting system with 20 alien technologies built from 15 materials
‚Ä¢ Engage with alien life forms and learn their language
‚Ä¢ No combat! it‚Äôs you against the environment
‚Ä¢ Eerie score by award-winning composer Siddhartha Barnhoorn (Antichamber, The Stanley Parable), featuring vocals by Lara Ausensi (Forest Kingdom II, Shevannai - The Voice of Elves)
‚Ä¢ Fantastic pulp comics graphics
‚Ä¢ High replay value

author: {'steamid': '76561198023891933', 'num_games_owned': 86, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 32, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 32, 'last_played': 1427450060}
review: Well I'm not really a reviewer but I'm going to give my honest impression on this game. The game starts you off with an inciting story and the transition from tutorial to actual game is done without any interruption making the game flow well. As a strategy management game it's pretty minimalistic... but that will make it easier for new players to get into... obviously it's roguelike game so dying means starting all over. The visuals and sounds are pretty unique and appealing in they own way... but as a 2D space exploration game it will lack the immersion that other 3D space games offer(like Kerbal Space Programs)... the story elements where pretty funny, however the choices weren't really part of the in-game "context"... making them feel more like a flip of a coin... rather than a decision based on actual calculations. All in all it is a pretty half decent game. I did make a let's play/first look video of it, if you want to check it out before getting it, right here:  https://youtu.be/kmQbb4JElGI   . I'll personally give it a 4/5 rating, but then again I might be a bit biased because of having early access to the game, and not knowing the eventual release price... this factors could influence the final rating.
